[Hence,] ‡ Offspring, or children; or a child. (IDrd, Ḳ, TA.) You say, heWulaMCi zaroEu fulaAnK ‡ These are the offspring, or children, of such a one. (IDrd, TA.) And huwa zaroEu Alr-ajuli ‡ He is the offspring, or child, of the man. (TA.)
And † The seed, or seminal fluid, of a man. (TA.)

[And † The fruit, or harvest, of a man's conduct; as though it were the produce of what he sowed.] One says, biYosa Alz-aroEu zaroEu Almuconibi † [Very evil is the fruit, or harvest, of conduct; the fruit, or harvest, of the conduct of the sinner]. (TA.)

zaroEapN and zuroEapN↓ and ziroEapN↓ and zaraEapN↓ A place in which to sow. (AḤn, Ṣgh, Ḳ.) You say, maA fiI AlOaroDi zaroEapN, &c., (Ḳ,) or zaroEapN waAHidapN, &c., and in like manner, EalaI AlOaroDi, (TA,) There is not in the land, (Ḳ,) or upon the land, (TA,) a place, (Ḳ,) or a single place, (TA,) in which to sow. (Ḳ, TA.)
[The first also app. signifies An ear of corn: see sabalN.]
zuroEapN: see zaroEapN.

Also Seed, or grain, for sowing, or that is sown; syn. bacorN. (Ḳ.) You say, OaEoTiniI zuroEapF OazoraEu bihaA OaroDiI [Give thou to me seed that I may sow therewith my land]. (TA.) [See also zariyEapN.]
And ‡ The young one of a qabojap [generally meaning a partridge]. (Z, TA.)
ziroEapN: see zaroEapN.
zaraEapN: see zaroEapN.
zariyEN [i. q. mazoruwEN↓ Sown:, &c.: see zariyEapN].
Seed produce that is watered by the rain. (Ḥam p. 657.)
And hence, ‡ Anything soft, or tender; as being likened thereto. (Id.)
ziraAEapN [an inf. n. of 1, q. v.: and] The business, or occupation, of sowing, ‡ ploughing up, tilling, or cultivation, land. (Mgh,* Mṣb,* TA.)
zariyEapN A thing that is sown; (IDrd, Ḳ;) sometimes used in this sense; as though meaning mazoruwEapN↓: (IDrd:) or grain that is sown: zar-iyEapN, with teshdeed, is wrong. (IB.) [See also zuroEapN.]
zar-aAEN: see zaAriEN.
Also ‡ A calumniator: (IAạr:) one who sows rancours in the hearts of friends. (TA.)

zir-iyEN ‡ What grows in land that has been left unsown for a year or more, from what has become scattered upon it in the days of the reaping; (Ḳ;) i. e., of the grain; mentioned by Ṣgh, on the authority of ISh; and by Z, who says that it is also called kaAv-N. (TA.)
zar-aAEapN: see mazoraEapN, in two places.

hom.sense: zaAriEN [act. part. n. of 1:] i. q. zar-aAEN↓ (TA) [One who sows:] ‡ one who ploughs up, tills, or cultivates, land: (Mgh:) pl. zur-aAEN. (TA.) By this pl., in the Ḳur xlviii. 29, are meant Moḥammad and his Companions, the inviters to El-Islám. (Zj.)
Causing to grow, vegetate, or germinate: (Ṣ, TA:) causing to increase: (TA:) pl. with wn. (Ṣ, TA.)
Also The name of a certain dog: (Ibn-ʼAbbád, IF, Ḳ:) whence OawolaAdu zaAriEK meaning ‡ dogs. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Z, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: mazoraEapN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.) and mazoruEapN (Ṣgh, L, Ḳ) and mazoriEapN (Ḳ) A place of zaroE [or seed-produce]; as also muzodaraEN↓; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and zar-aAEapN↓; (Ḥam p. 657;) or this last signifies land that is sown: (TA:) pl. of the first mazaAriEu; (TA;) and of ↓the last zar-aAEaAtN. (Ḥam, TA.)
[Hence the saying,] Ald-unoyaA mazoraEapu AlMxirapi ‡ [The present world is the place in which is produced the fruit, or harvest, to be reaped in the world to come]. (TA.)
mazoruwEN and mazoruwEapN: see zariyEN and zariyEapN.
muzodaraEN: see mazoraEapN.
muzodariEN ‡ One who raises seed-produce (yazodariEu zaroEFA) for himself, in particular. (TA.)

hom.sense: zaraAfapN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and zuraAfapN↓ (Mṣb as on the authority of AʼObeyd [but not found by me elsewhere in the sense here assigned to it]) and zaraAf-apN↓, [which is of a rare form, like HamaAr-apN, q. v.,] (AʼObeyd, IF, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) this last mentioned by El-Kanánee, (AʼObeyd, Ṣ,) and by Kzz in his Jámiʼ, but not known to AʼObeyd on any other authority than that of El-Kanánee, and the first is said by him (AʼObeyd) to be preferable, (TA,) A company, or congregated body, of men: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or ten thereof: (Ḳ, TA:) accord. to some copies of the Ḳ what is termed an EaXiyrap [i. e. a small portion of a tribe,, &c.,] thereof: (TA:) pl. zaraAfaAtN (IF, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb) and zaraAf-aAtN: (IF, Mṣb:) in a poem of Lebeed, zar-aAfaAt, with teshdeed to the r. (TA.) One says, OataAniI Alqawomu bizaraAf-atahimo↓ [or bizaraAfatihimo, i. e. The people, or party, came to me with their whole company; meaning, all together]. (TA.)

Also zaraAfapN and zuraAfapN↓, (Ṣ, O, Mgh, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) the latter, only, mentioned by IDrd, (TA,) who says, I doubt whether it be a genuine Arabic word, or not, (Mṣb, TA,) but some say that the latter is vulgar, (TA,) and zaraAfapN↓ and zuraAf-apN↓, (O, L, Mṣb, Ḳ,) but the first of these four is the most chaste, (L, TA,) [The camelopard, or giraffe;] a certain beast, (Ṣ, Ḳ, [in the Mgh erroneously said to be a beast of prey,]) of beautiful make, the fore legs of which are longer than its kind legs; (TA;)
said to be called by a name signifying jamaAEapN because it has the form of an assemblage of animals; (Mṣb;) in Pers. called OuXoturo GaAwo Palanok, (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) i. e. camel-ox-leopard, (TA,) because it has resemblances to the camel and the ox and the leopard: (Ḳ, TA:) pl. zaraAfaI, or zuraAfaI, or zaraAfiI-u, (accord. to different copies of the Ḳ, the last accord. to the TA,) like zaraAbiI-u. (TA.)

entry.sense: zuraAfapN: see the preceding paragraph, in two places.
zaraAf-apN and zuraAf-apN: see the first paragraph; the former in three places.
Q. 1. zarofana Sudogayohi He disposed the hair hanging down upon each of his temples in the form of a zurofiyn [or ring]: (Ṣ,* Ḳ:) but this is post-classical. (Ṣ.)

zurofiynN and zirofiynN, (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) or the latter is the correct word, for there is no word of the measure fuEoliylN in the language, (Az, TA,) [though the former is agreeable with the Pers. word which is the original,] A ring of a door: (Mgh, Ḳ:) or [a ring] in a general sense: (Ḳ:) pl. zaraAfiynu, occurring in a trad. as applied to rings of a coat of mail belonging to the Prophet, by which rings it was suspended: (TA:) arabicized, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) from the Pers. [zurofiyno]. (Ṣ.)
The latter also signifies A company of men [app. disposed in the form of a ring]. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. zariqa, (MA, TA,) [aor. _a {yazoraqu},] inf. n. zaraqN (Ṣ, MA, KL, TA) and zuroqapN, (MA,) [or the latter is a simple subst.,] He had that colour of the eye which is termed zuroqap [q. v.]; (Ṣ, TA;) [i. e.] he was blue-eyed; (KL;) or gray-eyed; (MA, PṢ;) or of a greenish hue in the eye [so I render the Pers. explanation sbz JXm Xd]. (MA.) And zariqato Eayonuhu; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and Azrq-t↓ Eayonuhu, inf. n. AizoriqaAqN; (Ṣ;) and AzrAq-t↓ Eayonuhu, (Ṣ, MA,) inf. n. AizoriyqaAqN; (Ṣ;) His eye was of the colour termed zuroqapN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) [i. e.] his eye was gray; (MA;) [&c.]
And zariqa, (TḲ,) inf. n. zaraqN, (Ḳ, TḲ,) He (a man, TḲ) was, or became, blind. (Ḳ,* TḲ.)
[And zariqa Aln-aSolu, inf. n. zaraqN, is app. used as signifying The iron head or blade of an arrow, &c. was, or became, very clear or bright: see zaraqN, below.]
And zariqa AlmaMCu The water was, or became, clear; as also Azrq-↓. (Mṣb.)
zaraqato Eayonuhu naHowiI His eye turned towards me so that the white thereof appeared; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also Oazoraqato↓ and Aizoraq-ato↓. (Fr, Ḳ.)

zaraqahu, (Mgh,) or zaraqahu bimizoraAqK, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or birumoHK, (Mṣb,) aor. _u {yazoruqu}, (Mṣb, TA,) inf. n. zaroqN, (Mgh, Mṣb,) He cast at him, (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) or he thrust him, or pierced him, (Mgh, Mṣb,) with a mzrAq [or javelin], (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) or with a spear. (Mṣb.)
[Hence,] zaraqahu biEayonihi, and bibaSarihi, ‡ He looked sharply, or intently, or attentively, at him; he cast his eye at him. (TA.)

zaraqati Alr-aHola, (Ṣ, TA,) or AlHimola, (TA,) She (a camel) made the saddle, (Ṣ, TA,) or the load, (TA,) to shift backwards: (Ṣ, TA:) and Oazoraqato↓ HimolahaA, (Ḳ,) inf. n. UizoraAqN, (TA,) She (a camel) made her load to shift backwards. (Ḳ.) [See also 2.]
zaraqa, aor. _u {yazoruqu} and _i {yazoriqu}, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. zaroqN, (Mṣb,) said of a bird, i. q. caraqa [i. e. It muted, or dunged]. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: [2. zr-q, accord. to Golius, as on the authority of the KL, “i. q. Pers. JkAnyd, Fecit ut stillaret, stillatim emisit:” but it appears from my copy of the KL that this should be zh-q; for I there find tazohiyqN (not tazoriyqN) expl. by the Pers. JkAnydn: then, however, immediately follows, in that copy, another explanation:]

[and The shifting backwards of a camel's saddle from his back: therefore it seems that either tazoriyqN is there omitted before this second explanation, (see 1, last sentence but one, and see 1,) or tazohiyqN is there a mistake for tazoriyqN.]
4: see 1, in two places.
7. Anzrq It (an arrow) passed through, and went forth on the other side: (Lth, Ḳ:) and in like manner a spear. (Ḳ in art. zrnq.)
He, or it, passed, so as to go beyond and away. (TA.)
He entered into a burrow, and lay hid. (Ḳ in art. zrnq.)
It (a camel's saddle, Ṣ, Ḳ, and a load, TA) shifted backwards. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA. [In the CK, Alr-ajulu is erroneously put for Alr-aHolu. See an ex. in art. zhq, conj. 4.])
He (a man, Aṣ) laid himself down on his back. (Aṣ, Ḳ.)
9: see 1, in three places.
11: see 1, second sentence.
Q. Q. 2. tazaworaqa, (Ḳ, TA,) in some of the copies of the Ḳ tazarowaqa, (TA,) He (a man, TA) cast [forth] what was in his belly: (Ḳ, TA:) so says Fr. (TA.)
zaraqN [inf. n. of zariqa, q. v.: and] i. q. zuroqapN, q. v. (Ḳ.)
Blindness: (Ḳ:) in this sense also an inf. n. of which the verb is zariqa. (TḲ.)
The quality of being very clear or bright, in the iron head or blade of an arrow, &c. (ISk, Ṣ. [See, again zariqa, of which it is app., in this sense likewise, an inf. n.])

A sort of taHojiyl [i. e. whiteness in the legs, or in three of the legs, or in the two kind legs, or in one kind leg, beneath the knees and hocks, or beneath the hocks, or beneath the hock, of a horse,] not including the border of the pastern next the hoof: (AO, Ḳ:) or, as some say, (TA, but in the Ḳ “and”) a whiteness not surrounding the bone altogether, but [only] a whiteness of the hair (waDaHN) upon a part thereof. (Ḳ, TA.)
zaroqapN A certain bead (xarazapN) for the purpose of fascination, (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ,) with which women fascinate [men]. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, TA.)

zuroqapN A certain colour, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) well known; as also zaraqN↓: (Ḳ:) it is [in various things; but is generally expl. as being] in the eye: (JK, Ṣ:) [a blue colour, (see 1, first sentence,) whether light or dark or of a middling tint, but generally the first;] sky-colour, or azure; (TḲ;) [blueness of the eye;] or grayness of the eye; (PṢ;) [or a greenish hue in the eye: (see again 1, first sentence:)] accord. to ISd, whiteness, wherever it be: and a xuDorap [by which may be meant greenness, or dust-colour intermixed with blackness or deep ask-colour,] in the sawaAd [here meaning iris] of the eye: or, as some say, a whiteness overspreading the sawaAd of the eye [app. when a person becomes blind: see 1, third sentence; and see also Oazoraqu]. (TA.) [In the present day it is often improperly used as meaning A black colour.]

zuroqumN Having, in an intense degree, that colour of the eye which is termed zuroqap; (Ṣ, Ḳ;*) applied to the male and the female; (Ḳ;) [i. e.] applied also to a woman: (Ṣ:) accord. to Ibn-ʼOsfoor, it is [used as] a subst.; [or, app. as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates;] not [as] an epithet with a subst.; (MF, TA;) but accord. to Lḥ, one says rajulN zuroqumN and AimoraOapN zaroqaMCu: the m is augmentative. (TA.)
zaroqamapN [Intenseness of zuroqap, i. e. blueness, or grayness, in the eye;] the attribute denoted by the epithet zuroqumN. (Lḥ, TA.)
zurayoqN [and app. Oabuw zurayoqK (see ziroyaAbN)] A certain bird. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: zurayoqaMCu [dim. of zaroqaMCu fem. of Oazoraqu] ‡ A mess of crumbled bread (variydapN) dressed with milk and olive oil: (JK, Z, Ḳ:) likened, because of its seasoning, to the eyes that are termed zuroq (Z, TA.)
Also A certain small beast, resembling the cat. (Lth, Ḳ.)

zur-aqN A certain bird used for catching other birds; (IDrd, Ṣ, Ḳ;) between the [species of hawk called] baAziI and the baAXaq [or sparrow-hawk]: (IDrd, TA:) or, accord. to Fr, the white baAziI [or falcon]: (Ṣ, TA:) [but] it is said in the A, laA yuqaAsu Alz-ur-aqu biAlOazoraqi [The zur-aq is not to be compared with the Oazoraq], which latter is the bAzI: (TA:) the pl. is zaraAriyqu. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
And A whiteness in the forelock of a horse; (Ḳ, TA;) or in the hinder part of his head, behind the forelock. (O, TA.) And Some white hairs in the fore leg of a horse; or in his hind leg. (TA.)
Also Sharp-sighted: mentioned by Sb, and expl. by Seer. (TA.)

entry.sense: zar-aAqN, applied to a man, Very deceitful; or a great deceiver. (TA.)
zar-aAqapN, with fet-ḥ and teshdeed, A short javelin; i. e. a spear shorter than the mizoraAqN: pl. zaraAriyqu. (TA.)

Also i. q. minoDaHapN; (IAạr, L and Ḳ in art. nDH; in some copies of the Ḳ, zur-aAqap; and in the CK zarAfap;) i. e. An instrument made of copper, or brass, for shooting forth naphtha [into a besieged place]. (L in that art.)
zuronuwqN:, &c.: see art. zrnq.

zaworaqN A sort of safiynap [or boat]; (Ṣ;) [a skiff i. e.] a small safiynap; (Ḳ;) or a small qaArib: pl. zawaAriqu. (TA.)
Dhu-r-Rummeh says, [referring to a she-camel,] niEomato zaworaqu Albaladi; [making it fem., because] meaning niEomato safiynapu AlmafaAzapi [Excellent, or most excellent, is the boat, or skiff, of the desert, or waterless desert.] (Ṣ, TA.)

Oazoraqu Of the colour termed zuroqap [q. v.]; (Mṣb, TA;) and OazoraqiI-N↓ signifies the same: (TA:) an epithet applied to a man, signifying having what is termed zuroqap of the eye: (Ṣ:) blue, (KL,) [whether light or dark or of a middling tint, but generally the first;] sky-coloured, or azure; (TḲ;) blue-eyed; (MA, KL;) gray-eyed; (MA;) [or having a greenish hue in the eye:, &c.: (see zuroqapN:)] fem. zaroqMCu: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) pl. zuroqN. (Mṣb.) [In the present day it is often improperly used as meaning Black: and is applied to a horse, an ass, a mule, a bird, and any animal, and sometimes to other things, as meaning gray, or ash-coloured.]

[And Blind; properly by reason of a bluish, or grayish, opacity of the crystalline lens; i. e., by what is commonly termed a cataract in the eye.] wanaHoXuru Qlomujorimiyna yawomaYicK zuroqFA, in the Ḳur [xx. 102], means [And we will congregate, or raise to life, on that day, the sinners, or unbelievers,] blind; (Bḍ, Ḳ,* TA;) because the black of the eye of the blind becomes blue, or gray: (Bḍ:) Zj says that they will come forth from their graves seeing, as they were created at the first, and will become blind when congregated: (TA:) or the meaning is, thirsty: (Th, TA:) or with their eyes become blue, or gray, by reason of intense thirst: (ISd, TA:) or blue-eyed, or gray-eyed, (zuroqa AlEuyuwni,) because Alz-uroqapu is the worst of the colours of the eye, and the most hateful thereof to the Arabs, for the Greeks were their greatest enemies, and are zuroq. (Bḍ.)

Applied to the iron head or blade of an arrow, &c., Very clear or bright: (ISk, Ṣ, Ḳ:) and zuroqN [used as a subst.] means spearheads (Ṣ, Ḳ) or the like; (Ḳ;) because of their colour; (Ṣ, TA;) or because of their clearness, or brightness; (TA;) or polished iron heads or blades of arrows, &c. (Ḥam p. 313.) And Clear water: (IAạr, Ṣ, Mṣb:) pl. as above. (TA.)

Hence, AlEaduw-u AlOazoraqu The sheer enemy: or [the fierce enemy;] the enemy that is vehement in hostility; because zuroqap of the eyes is predominant in the Greeks and the Deylem, between whom and the Arabs is a confirmed enmity. (Ḥar p. 148.)
AlOazoraqu The baAziI [i. e. hawk, or falcon: because of his colour]: pl. as above. (TA. [See also zur-aqN.])
And The leopard. (TA.)
Alz-aroqaMCu Wine: (Ḳ:) [app. because of its clearness:] so says AA. (TA.)
And the name of A horse of Náfi' Ibn-ʼAbd-El-'Ozzà. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: OazoraqiI-N: see the next preceding paragraph, first sentence.

Also sing. of AlOazaAriqapu, (TA,) which is the appellation of A certain sect of the [heretics, or schismatics, called] xawaArij, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or Haruwriy-ap; (TA;) so called in relation to Náfi' Ibn-El-Azrak, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) who was [of the family] of Ed-Dool Ibn-Ḥaneefeh: (Ṣ:) they asserted that ʼAlee committed an act of infidelity by submitting his case to arbitration, and that Ibn-Muljam's slaughter of him was just; and they pronounced the Companions [of the Prophet] to have been guilty of infidelity. (TA.)
mizoraAqN A javelin; i. e. a short spear, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) lighter than the Eanazap. (Mgh, Mṣb.)
Also A camel that makes his load to shift backwards. (Az, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: zuroqumN and zaroqamapN are expl. in art. zrq.

hom.sense: 1. zarima, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yazoramu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. zaramN, (TA,) said of one's urine, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and of his flow of tears, and of his speech, (Ḳ,) and of his oath, (TA,) and of anything that had gone back, (Ṣ,) It became interrupted, or stopped; or it stopped; or ceased; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also AizoraOam-a↓. (Ḳ.) And so the former verb said of a sale. (TA.)
And, said of a dog, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and of a cat, (Ḳ,) His dung, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or dry dung, (Ḳ,) stopped in his rectum. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
zaramahu: see 4.
zaramato bihi She (his mother, Ṣ) brought him forth. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 2: see 4.
zr-mhu, (Ṣ, TA,) inf. n. tazoriymN, (TA,) He, or it, rendered him zarim, i. e. niggardly, or avaricious: (Ṣ:) or it (time, or fortune,) cut off from him good, good things, or prosperity. (TA.)

hom.sense: 4. Azrmhu He, or it, interrupted it, stopped it, or caused it to cease; namely, one's urine, and his flow of tears, and his speech; as also zaramahu↓, aor. _i {yazorimu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. zaromN; (TA;) and zr-mhu↓, (Ḳ,) inf. n. tazoriymN. (TA.)
And He interrupted, or stopped, his (another's) urine. (Aṣ, Ṣ, Ḳ.)
Oazoramato She (a camel) interrupted her flow of urine by little and little. (AA, TA.)

entry.sense: 8. AizodiraAmN The act of swallowing [a thing]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) mentioned in the Ṣ in art. zdrm or zrdm [accord. to different copies]; (TA;) and in the Ḳ, as an art. by itself; the reason whereof is not apparent; for it appears to be of the measure AifotiEaAlN; not AifoEilaAlN. (MF, TA.)
Q. Q. 4. AizoraOam-a, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. AizoriYomaAmN: (Ṣ:) see 1.
[Also] He shrank, or drew himself together: (AʼObeyd, Ṣ:) or he shuddered and shrank. (TA.)
And He was angry. (AZ, TA.)

hom.sense: zrm [app. zaromN] Dung, or dry dung, stopping in the rectum of a dog or cat. (TA. [See 1, third sentence.])
zaromN Caution. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: zarimN Anything becoming interrupted, or stopped; stopping, or ceasing; as also Oazoramu↓. (TA.) Scanty, or little in quantity, and becoming interrupted, or stopped: so in the phrase rajulN zarimu Ald-amoEi: or this signifies [simply] a man whose tears are becoming interrupted, or stopped. (TA.)
A she-camel that interrupts her flow of urine by little and little. (AA, TA. [Thus used as a fem. epithet without p.])
A dog, and a cat, whose dung, or dry dung, has stopped in his rectum. (TA.)
Straitened [app. in his means of subsistence]. (Ṣ.)
Niggardly, or avaricious. (Ṣ.)
Low, object, mean, or ignominious, whose near kinsfolk are few; (IAạr, Ḳ;) as also zariymN↓. (TA.)
One who does not remain fixed, or settled, in any place. (Aṣ, Ḳ.)
zariyamN: see the next preceding paragraph.
zuraOomiymN: see muzoraYim-N.
Oazoramu: see zarimN.
Also The cat. (ISd, Ḳ.)

muzoraYim-N Shrinking, or drawing himself together; (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also zuraOomiymN↓; (Th, Ḳ, TA; [in the CK zarAmiyom;]) each with damm: (TA:) or, accord. to AʼObeyd, muzoraYim-N signifies shuddering and shrinking; with the r before the z; and AZ doubted whether the word having this meaning were muzoraYim-N or muzoraYim-N; but Az says that the former is the right, with the z before the r and that it is thus accord. to Ibn-Jebeleh. (TA.)
Also Angry. (AZ, TA.)
And Silent. (IB, TA.)

hom.sense:
zaronabN A certain perfume: or certain sweetsmelling trees: (Ḳ:) or a species of sweet-smelling plant: (Ṣ:) it consists of slender round twigs, between [maA bayona, misprinted mlyn,] the thickness of the large needle and the thickness of writingreeds, black inclining to yellowness, not having much taste nor odour, its little odour being of a fragrant kind like that of the citron: (Ibn-Seenà, book ii. p. 168:) [Freytag says, as on the authority of the Ḳ, but he seems to have taken it from the TḲ, that, “accord. to some, it signifies the leaves of a sweet-smelling plant, which has the name of rjl AljrAd, locusts' foot:” and he adds, as though on the authority of Ibn-Seenà ubi suprá, “salix Aegyptiaca:” referring also to Sprengel, Hist. rei. herb., t. i. p. 270:] also saffron: (Ḳ:) it is of the measure faEolalN; (Ṣ, TA;) and is a genuine Arabic word, though asserted by Ibn-El-Kutbee to be arabicized. (TA.) A rájiz says,
yaA biOabiI Oanoti wafuwki AlOaXonabu
kaOan-amaA cur-a Ealayohi Alz-aronabu
[O, with my father thou shouldst be ransomed, and thy mouth that is cool and sweet, as though zaronab were sprinkled upon it]. (Ṣ.) In the trad. of Umm-Zarạ, where it is said, Almas-u mas-u OaronabK waAlr-iyHu riyHu zaronabK [The feel is the feel of a hare, and the odour is the odour of zaronab], IAth says that it signifies saffron; and she may mean the sweetness of his odour, or the perfume of his garments among the people. (TA.)
Also The [dung such as is termed] baEor of wild animals. (Ḳ.)

Also, [and, as appears from what follows, zaronabapN↓ likewise, if this be not a mistranscription,] The vulva of a woman: (Ḳ,* TA:) or such as is large: or the external portion thereof: (Ḳ:) or a piece of flesh (Ḳ, TA) within the zrwAn [a mistranscription for zaradaAn, a name for the vulva], (TA,) behind the kayonap [or kayon, q. v.]: (Ḳ, TA:) behind the zaronabap↓ is another piece of flesh: so says IAạr. (TA.)

entry.sense: zaronabapN: see the next preceding sentence, in two places.

hom.sense: Q. 1. zaronaqapN [as inf. n. of zaronaqa] The irrigating [land] by means of the zuronuwq [here app. meaning rivulet]. (Mgh, Ḳ.)
And The setting up a [pillar-like structure such as is termed] zuronuwq by a well. (Ḳ.)

One says also, zaronaqotuhu, (Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, (TḲ,) meaning I clad him [app. fiI Alv-iyaAbi in the clothes: see Q. 2]: or zaronaqotu All-ibaAsi Uiy-aAhu I put the clothing upon him; or clad him therewith. (TḲ)
And laA yuzaroniquka OaHadN EalaI faDoli zayodK [No one will exceed to thee the excel-lence of Zeyd]. (TA. [It is there indicated that this is from zaronaqapN as syn. with ziyaAdapN.])
[See zaronaqapN as a simple subst. below.]

Q. 2. tazaronaqa He drew water by means of the zuronuwq, (Mgh, Ḳ, TA,) or the zuronuwqaAni, (TA,) for hire. (Mgh, Ḳ, TA.) Hence the saying of ʼAlee, laA OadaEu AlHaj-a walawo tazaronaqotu, meaning I will not omit, or neglect, the pilgrimage, though I should draw water by means of the zrnwq, or zrnwqAn, and perform it with the hire obtained thereby: thus it is explained: another explanation will be found in what follows. (Mgh, TA.)
tzrnq fiI Alv-iyAbi He clad, and covered, himself in the clothes. (Ḳ.)

And hence, [it is said,] because implying concealment of the excess [of the price] in the sale, (TA,) tzrnq also signifies taEay-ana, (Mgh, Ḳ, TA, [in the CK, erroneously, tagay-ara,]) from Alz-aronaqapu meaning AlEiynapu; (Mgh;) i. e. He bought on credit, for an excess [in the amount of the price]. (TḲ.) And accord. to some, walawo tazaronaqotu, in the saying of ʼAlee mentioned above, means walawo taEay-anotu, (Mgh,) i. e. walawo taEay-anotu Eiynapa Alz-aAdi waAlr-aAHilapi [though I should buy on credit, for more than the current price, the travelling-provision and the camel to be ridden]: (TA:) but the former explanation is the more likely. (Mgh.)
zaronaqapN inf. n. of zaronaqa. (TḲ. [See Q. 1, above.])

Also i. q. EiynapN; (IAạr, JK, Mgh, Ḳ;) i. e. The buying of a thing from a man on credit, for more than its [current] price: (JK, Fáïk:) or the doing thus, and then selling it to him, or to another, for less than the price for which it was purchased. (TA.)
And Increase, excess, or addition; syn. ziyaAdapN. (Ḳ.) [For zaronaqapN in this and the following senses, Freytag, in his Lex., has written zaronaq.]

And Debt. (Ḳ, TA. [In the CK, Ald-iynu is erroneously put for Ald-ayonu: and it is there added, “as though arabicized from zaronaho; i. e. Alc-ahaba labisa:” but what this should be I know not, unless it be a mistranscription for Alc-ahabu layosa; for, in Pers., zaro means “gold,” and naho is a negative.])
Also Perfect, or consummate, beauty. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: zuronuwqN, as some pronounce it, is by others pronounced zaronuwqN, which is of a strange form, [said to be] of the measure faEonuwlN, (IJ, TA,) mentioned by Kr on the authority of Lḥ: (TA:) [the dual] zuronuwqaAni, (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) mentioned by J in art. zrq, the n being regarded by him as augmentative, but by the author of the Ḳ as radical, (TA,) also pronounced zaronuwqaAni, (Ḳ,) signifies Two pillarlike structures (manaArataAni) constructed by the head of a well, (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) on the two sides thereof; (Ḳ;) or two walls; or two posts; (Mgh;) across which is placed a piece of wood, (Ṣ, Mgh,) called the naEaAmap; (Ṣ;) and to this is suspended the pulley by means of which the water is drawn: (Ṣ, Mgh:) or two structures like the signs set up to show the way, by the brink of a well, of clay or of stones: (TA:) accord. to the Ṣ, (TA,) if of wood, they are called diEaAmataAn: or, as El-Kilábee says, if of wood, they are called naEaAmataAni, and the crosspiece is called the Eajalap, and to this the large bucket is suspended: (Ṣ, TA:) pl. zaraAniyqu. (TA.)
zuronuwqN also signifies A rivulet; (Sh, Mgh, Ḳ;) app. a rivulet in which runs the water that is drawn by means of the zrnwq. (Sh, Mgh,* TA.)
zironiyqN i. q. zironiyxN [i. e. Arsenic]; an arabicized word; (Ḳ;) as is also the latter [q. v.]. (TA.)
muzaroniqN A setter-up of what are termed zaronuwqaAni. (TA.)

zironiyxN [Arsenic;] a well-known kind of stone [or mineral, for it is a metal]; of which there are several species; one species is white [i. e. white arsenic]; and another is red [i. e. realgar, or red arsenic, also called sandarac]; and another is yellow [i. e. orpiment, or yellow arsenic]: (Ḳ, TA:) it is an arabicized word from the Pers. [zaroniyxo or zaroniyqo or zaroniIo or zaronaho]. (Mṣb.)

1. zaraI Ealayohi, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or zaraI Ealayohi fiEolahu, (Mgh, TA,) aor. yazoriI, (Mṣb, TA,) inf. n. ziraAyapN, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) with kesr, (Mṣb, TA,) but by some written with fet-ḥ, (TA, [zarAyap, thus in the CK and in one of my copies of the Ṣ and in my MṢ. copy of the Ḳ,]) and zaroIN (Mṣb, Ḳ) and zaroyapN (Mṣb [perhaps a mistranscription for what next follows]) and mazoriyapN and mazoraApN and zuroyaAnN, with damm, (Ḳ,) but accord. to the copies of the T and M zarayaAnN; (TA;) and tzr-I↓ Elyh, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and AzrI↓ Elyh, but this is of rare occurrence, (Ḳ,) and AizodaraAhu↓; (Mṣb;) He blamed, found fault with, or reproved, (Lth, AZ, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) him, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or his deed; (Mgh, TA;) or was angry with him, with the anger that proceeds from a friend: (Ṣ, TA:) and reproached him, upbraided him, or blamed him angrily or severely: (Lth, TA:) and he mocked, scoffed, or laughed, at him; derided him; or ridiculed him. (Mṣb.)
See also 4, last sentence but one.

4. AzrI bihi, inf. n. UizoraMCN, He held it (i. e. a thing, Ṣ, Mṣb, or a case, or an affair, Ḳ) in little, or light, or mean, estimation, or in contempt; (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also AizodaraAhu↓. (Mgh.) And i. q. qaS-ara bihi [app. here meaning (in like manner as it is rendered below in this paragraph) He fell short of that estimation which was required by him, or due to him]; and AizodaraAhu↓, i. e. he contemned, or despised, him; [and so, app., AstzrAhu↓; (see muzodarK;)] or made him to be contemned or despised; syn. Haqarahu or Haq-arahu. (Ṣ, accord. to different copies. [But whether this last explanation be here meant to relate to AzrI bh and AzdrAh or to the latter alone, is not clear.]) He lowered his condition, or estimation. (Ḥam p. 117.) He brought against him the imputation of a fault, or vice, or the like, (ʼEyn, Ḳ, TA,) or a thing, or an affair, or an action, whereby he desired to involve him in confusion. (ISd, Ḳ, TA.) AzrI biEilomihi and zaraI↓ bihi, mentioned, but not explained, by Lḥ, are thought by ISd to signify qaS-ara bihi [app. meaning He fell short of that estimation which was required by, or due to, his knowledge]. (TA.) AzrI Ealayohi: see 1.
5: see 1.
8. AizodaraAhu: see 1: and see also 4, in two places.
zariI-N, applied to a skin for water or milk (siqaMCN) [Of middling size;] between small and large. (ISd, Ḳ.)

zaArK EalaI UinosaAnK Blaming, finding fault with, or reproving, a man; or being angry with him, with the anger that proceeds from a friend; and being displeased with him: thus in a verse of Mejnoon cited voce AisotadaAma: (Ṣ, TA:) making no account of a man, and disapproving his conduct. (AA, Mṣb, TA.)
mizoraMCN A man who blames, or finds fault with, people [app. much, or habitually]. (Ḳ,* TA.)
And [hence,] The lion. (Ḳ.)
musotazorK: see the next preceding paragraph.
ziyzamN and ziyzimN: see art. zm.

R. Q. 1. zaEozaEapN signifies The moving, agitating, shaking, or putting into a state of motion or commotion, (Lth, Ṣ, Ḳ,) a thing, (Ṣ,) or a tree, (Lth, Ḳ,) and the like, (Ḳ,) by the wind: (Lth, Ḳ:) or any vehement moving or agitating or shaking; or putting into a state of vehement motion or commotion. (Ḳ.) You say, zaEozaEotuhu I moved it, agitated it, shook it,, &c. (Ṣ.) And zaEozaEati Alr-iyHu AlX-ajarapa, inf. n. zaEozaEopN, The wind moved, or agitated, or shook,, &c., the tree; as also zaEozaEato bihaA, which may be a dial. var. of the former, or the verb in this case may be made trans. by means of the b because it has the meaning of dafaEato bihaA. (TA.)
You say also, zaEozaEahu, inf. n. as above, meaning He moved it, agitated it, shook it,, &c., vehemently, desiring to pull it out or up or off, and to remove it. (TA.)
[And hence,] zaEozaEotu AlUibila ‡ I drove the camels roughly, or violently; urged them on. (TA.)

R. Q. 2. tazaEozaEa It became moved, agitated, shaken, or put into a state of motion or commotion: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) [or it became moved, agitated, shaken,, &c., vehemently:] quasi-pass. of zaEozaEatohu Alr-iyHu. (TA.)
[And hence,] tazaEozaEati AlUibilu ‡ The camels went roughly, or violently, being so driven, or urged on. (TA.)

riyHN zaEozaEN and zaEozaEaAnN↓ and zuEaAziEN↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) the last with damm, (Ḳ, TA,) but written by J with fet-ḥ, (TA,) [and so I find it in one copy of the Ṣ, but in another copy with damm,] and zaEozaAEN↓, (Ṣgh, Ḳ,) A wind that agitates things, shakes them, or puts them into a state of motion or commotion: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) and riyHN zuEozuwEN↓ [signifies the same; or] a violent wind. (IJ.)
[And hence,] sayorN zaEozaEN ‡ An agitating, or a jolting, pace; (Ṣ, [but not there explained, though the meaning is there implied,] Sgh, Ḳ;) a vehement pace. (L.)
zaEozaEapN [see R. Q. 1].

zaEaAziEu [which is its pl. when it is used as a simple subst.] signifies ‡ The calamities, or adversities, of fortune; (Ḳ, TA;) like zalaAzilu. (TA.) One says, kayofa Oanota fiI hecihi Alz-aEaAziEi ‡ How art thou in these calamities, or adversities? so in the L and the Moḥeeṭ and the A. (TA.)
zaEozaEaAnN: see zaEozaEN.
zaEozaAEN: see zaEozaEN.
Also [Vehement motion, agitation, or shaking;] a subst. from zaEozaEahu as signifying “he moved it,”, &c., “vehemently:” and metaphorically used by Ed-Dahnà in allusion to the cakar. (TA.)
zuEozuwEN: see zaEozaEN.
zaEozaAEapN i. q. Xid-apN [Vehemence; strength;, &c.]. (IB.)
A troop, or force, of many horsemen, (Ḳ, TA,) in a state of motion or commotion. (TA.)
zuEaAziEN: see zaEoziEN.
muzaEozaEN i. q. faAluwcN [A kind of sweet food: see the latter word]. (IAạr, Ḳ.)
1. zaEabotuhu Ean-iI, [aor. _a {yazoEabu},] inf. n. zaEobN, I pushed, thrust, drove away, or repelled, him, or it, from me. (Ṣ, TA.)

[Hence,] zaEaba said of a torrent, aor. and inf. n. as above, It was impelled in its several parts, or portions, by the impetus of one part, or portion, acting upon another; in a valley: (Ṣ, TA:) [it was, or became, copious, and drove along, one portion impelling another; like AizolaEab-a↓:] it ran. (TA.)

If you say raEaba with the unpointed r, (Ṣ, TA.) or thus and also zaEaba, aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) you mean It filled the valley. (Ṣ, TA.) And the latter, It filled everything: said of rain. (TA.) And He filled a vessel. (Ḳ, TA.)

[Hence,] zaEaba AlmaroOapa, (Ḳ, TA,) aor. and inf. n. as above, is a tropical phrase, meaning jaAmaEahaA famalaOa farojahaA bifarojihi: (TA:) or jaAmaEahaA famalaOa farojahaA maniy-FA: (Ḳ,* TA:) [neither of which explanations needs translation:] but, accord. to some, this is said only of one that is large, or bulky. (TA.)

zaEaba Alqirobapa He took up and carried the water-skin, it being full: (Ḳ, TA:) he carried it filled; as also zaOabahaA: (TA:) and both signify he carried it in his bosom: (TA in art. zOb: [see also 8:]) the former also signifies he was impelled onwards (tdAfE) by it, carrying it, by reason of its weight. (TA in the present art.)

zaEaba biHimolihi, said of a camel, (Ḳ, TA,) i. q. AisotaqaAma [app. meaning He went right on, straight on, or undeviatingly, with his load]: (TA:) or, as also AzdEb↓ bihi, he went along with his load oppressed by its weight: or he was impelled onwards (tadaAfaEa) by it: (Ḳ, TA:) or mar-a yazoEabu bihi he went along quickly with it: or he went along easily with it; namely, his load. (TA.)
zaEaba AlwaAdiI The valley became filled, (Ḳ, TA,) so that the several parts, or portions, of the torrent impelled one another. (TA.)
zaEaba fiI qayoYihi He vomited much, so that one portion [of the vomit] impelled on another. (TA.)

zaEabati Alqirobapu i. q. dfEt maMCahaA [The water-skin propelled its water: or the right reading is probably dafaqato maMCahaA, i. e., poured forth its water; or poured it forth with vehemence]. (TA.)

zaEaba also signifies He cut off, or divided off; and so AzdEb↓. (Ḳ, TA.) You say, zaEaba lahu mina AlmaAli, and AzdEb↓, as also Azdhb, He cut off, or divided off, for him [a portion] of the property, or wealth. (TA.) And zaEabotu lahu zuEobapF mina AlmaAli, and zaEobapF, (Ṣ, Ḳ,*) and ziEobFA, (Ḳ,) I gave to him a part, or portion, of the property, or wealth: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or a full, or an ample, or abundant, portion thereof. (TA.)
zaEaba AlX-araAba, aor. and inf. n. as above, He drank all the wine, or beverage. (TA.)

hom.sense: 5. tzE-b He was brisk, lively, or sprightly; (Ḳ, TA;) and quick. (TA.)
He was, or became, angered, or enraged. (Ḳ.)
tzE-b fiI Oakolihi waXurobihi He was immoderate in his eating and his drinking; he ate and drank much. (Ḳ.)
tzE-b Alqawomu AlmaAla The people, or party, divided among themselves the property, or wealth; (Ḳ;) divided it into parts, or portions. (TA.)

entry.sense: 8. AizodaEabotu AlX-aIoCa I carried the thing; took it up and carried it; or carried it off or away; syn. Hamalotuhu: you say, mar-a bihi faQzodaEabahu [He passed by it and carried it off or away]. (Ṣ.) [See also Azdgb.]
See also 1, in three places.
zaEobN Muchness, copiousness, abundance, or a large quantity or number. (TA.)
ziEobN: see what next follows.
zaEobapN: see what next follows.

zuEobapN and zaEobapN↓ A part, or portion, that is given, of property, or wealth; (Ṣ, Ḳ;*) as also ziEobN↓: (Ḳ:) or a full, or an ample, or abundant, portion, that is given, thereof; and so zuhobapN. (TA.) [See 1, last sentence but one.]
zaEuwbN: see what next follows, in two places.

zaAEibN A torrent driving along, one portion of it impelling another; (A, TA;) as also zaEuwbN↓ [but app. in an intensive sense; and muzolaEib-N↓, also, has the same, or a similar, meaning]: or the first and ↓second signify a torrent filling the valley: and the first is also applied to rain, as meaning filling everything. (TA.)
Also A guide of the way, one who is a frequent traveller. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

zumoHN zaAEibiI-N, (A,) and rimaAHN zaAEibiy-apN, (A, Ḳ,) A spear, (A,) and spears, (A, Ḳ,) so called in relation to a certain man named Zá'ib (zaAEibN), (A, Ḳ,) of El-Khazraj, who made spear-heads: (A:) so says Mbr: (TA:) or † the spears thus termed are such as quiver much (Eas-aAlapN), which, when shaken, have a motion like the torrent termed zaAEibN, of which one portion impels another: the I being that of the rel. n.; to give intensiveness to the signification, as in OaHomariI-N: (A:) or ‡ such that, when they are shaken, their kuEuwb [i. e. knots, or joints, or their internodal portions,] are as though they ran one into another, (Ḳ, TA,) by reason of its pliancy: so says Aṣ: and this meaning is tropical; for it is from the phrase mar-a yazoEabu biHimolihi meaning “he went along [impelled by his load, or] easily with his load:” accord. to another explanation, zAEbI- applied to a spear means such that, when it is shaken, the whole of it is [in appearance] impelled in its several parts by the impetus of one part acting upon another, as though its hind part ran into its fore part: (TA:) or zaAEibiy-apN signifies spears, (Ṣ, TA,) universally. (TA.) You say also sinaAnN zaAEibiI-N (Ṣ, TA) A spear-head of Zá'ib. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. zaEaja: see 4.
Also i. q. Tarada [He drove away,, &c.]. (Ḳ.)
And [i. q. zaEaqa, meaning] He called, called out, cried out, or shouted. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense:
4. AzEjhu He disquieted, disturbed, agitated, or flurried, him; (IDrd, Ṣ, Ḳ;) and removed him from his place: (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ:) and zaEajahu↓ signifies the same. (IDrd, Ḳ.) You say, OazoEajotuhu Eano mawoDiEihi, (Mṣb,) or mino maHal-ihi, (A,) and mino bilaAdihi, (L,) I removed him, or unsettled him, from his place, and from his country. (A, L, Mṣb.) And it is said in a trad., raOayotu Eumura yuzoEiju OabaA bakorK, meaning I saw ʼOmar rousing Aboo-Bekr, and not suffering him to remain still. (TA.) And in another, AlHalifu yuzoEiju Als-iloEapa wayaHomaqu Albarakapa, meaning, accord. to Az, [Swearing] lowers in estimation [the commodity that one desires to recommend thereby and does away with the blessing thereof]:
or, accord. to IAth, causes it to be easy of sale and to go forth from the hand of its owner [but does away with the blessing thereof]. (TA.) UizoEaAjN [is the inf. n.; and as inf. n. of the pass. verb,] signifies [The being disquieted,, &c.; and hence,] the quitting of home. (Ḥar p. 392.)

7. AnzEj He was, or became, disquieted, disturbed, agitated, or flurried; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and was, or became, removed, or unsettled, from his place: (Ṣ, A, L, Mṣb, Ḳ:) it may be thus used as quasi-pass. of AzEj: (Kh, Mṣb:) or it should not be so used: (Mṣb:) it is, however, agreeable with analogy, as is also AzdEj↓: (L:) but the word commonly used in its stead is XaxaSa: (L, Mṣb:) zaEaja in this sense is not allowable. (L.)
8. AzdEj: see what next precedes {7}.
zaEajN Disquietude, disturbance, or agitation: (Ḳ, TA:) a subst. [not an inf. n.] in this sense. (TA.)
mizoEaAjN An unquiet woman, who remains not still, or settled, in one place. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ.)

1. zaEira, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yazoEaru}, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. zaEarN, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) His hair, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb,) and his plumage, (A,) was, or became, scanty, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb,) and thin; (A;) as also AzEAr-↓: (A:) and it (hair, and plumage, Ḳ, and fur, TA) was, or became, scanty, and thin; (Ḳ, TA;) as also AzEr-↓ and AzEAr-↓. (Ḳ.)
Also, inf. n. as above, said of a man, † His good things, or wealth, or his beneficence, became scanty, or wanting; he became poor; or he became niggardly. (TA.)
And, inf. n. as above, ‡ It (the disposition) became evil, or bad: but the verb is seldom used in this sense. (TA.) See zaEaAr-apN.
9: see above {1}.
11: see 1, in two places.
zaEarN inf. n. of 1 [q. v.].
See also zaEaAr-apN.
zaEirN: see OazoEaru, in two places:
and see also the paragraph here following.

hom.sense: zuEoruwrN † A man of bad disposition, or illnatured: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) the vulgar say zaEirN↓. (Ṣ. [zaEiru Alxuluqi occurs in the TA in art. lZ.])

A well-known fruit; (Ṣ;) the fruit of a well-known tree; (Ḳ;) the fruit of a tree, of which there is a red species and a yellow, having a round and hard stone; (Mgh;) a fruit of the desert, in make resembling the nabiq [or fruit of the lote-tree], and in the taste of which is acidity; (Mṣb;) it may be the wild nabiq: (Mṣb, voce sidorN:) AA says that the nulok is the zErwr; and IDrd, that the Arabs do not know it: [it is a coll. gen. n.:] the n. un. is with p {zuEoruwrapN}: (TA:) [the name is now applied to the medlar, or a species thereof: accord. to Golius, the “mespilum; special. quod genus aronium vocat Dios. i. 169:”] accord. to ISh, the tree called dulob: (T:) this, says Ṣgh, is different from what J has mentioned. (TA.)

entry.sense: zaEaAr-apN, (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ,) [respecting the form of which see HamaAr-apN,] and zaEaArapN, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) the latter a vulgar form, (Ṣ,) and zaEarN↓, (A,) ‡ Illnature; excessive perverseness or crossness: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) nouns having no corresponding verb: (Ṣ:) or the verb is zaEira↓, but it is seldom used. (TA.)
zayoEarN ‡ A man having little wealth. (Ḳ, TA.)
‡ A place having few plants, or little herbage; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) as also zaEirN↓: (Ḳ, TA: in the CK, zaEorN:) pl. [of the former] zuEorN. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. zaEafahu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yazoEafu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. zaEofN, (Ṣ,) He, or it, killed him on the spot; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also AzEfhu↓, and AzdEfhu↓; (Ḳ;) the last mentioned by Aṣ, as syn. with OaqoEaSahu: (TA:) or cast, or shot, at him, or smote him, so that he died on the spot, quickly: (L, TA:) and killed him quickly. (Ṣ.)
See also 4.
zaEafa fiI Hadiyvihi He added, or exaggerated, or he lied, in his discourse, or narration. (Mj, L.)

entry.sense: 4: see above {1}.
AzEf Ealayohi He despatched him; or hastened and completed his slaughter; (El-Khárzenjee, Ḳ;) as also zaEafahu↓, aor. and inf. n. as above. (TA.)
8. AzdEfhu [originally AizotaEafahu]: see 1.

zuEaAfN, applied to poison, like zuWaAfN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and cuEaAfN [meaning Quick in its effect]; and in like manner applied to death: (Ṣ:) and muzoEifN↓, applied to death, and to a sword, that will not suffer one to linger; killing on the spot; (Ḳ;) as applied to a sword, thus expl. by Aṣ; as applied to death, expl. by Skr as meaning quick. (TA.)
zuEuwfN [a pl. of which the sing. is not mentioned,] Places of destruction. (IAạr, Ḳ.)
HisoIN muzoEafN [Water which the earth imbibes from sand above it, and which, when it reaches what is hard, is arrested thereby,] such as is not sweet. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)
muzuEifN: see zuEaAfN.

AlmuzoEifu is also the name of a certain sword, (Ḳ, TA,) belonging to ʼAbdAllah Ibn-Sebreh, one of the braves of El-Islám; thus accord. to Az: (TA:) or this is with r; (Ṣgh, Ḳ;) and is thus found in the handwriting of Moḥammad Ibn-El-ʼAbbás El-Yezeedee, with a dot beneath the r, to show that it is not z. (Ṣgh, TA.)
AlmizoEaAfapu The serpent; (Ḳ;) as also AlmizoEaAmapu. (TA.) [Accord. to Freytag, mizoEaAfapu Alr-iyqi occurs in the Deewán el-Hudhaleeyeen as meaning The serpent: or the lion.]
[See also art. cEf, passim.]
Q. 1. zaEofara He dyed a garment, or piece of cloth, with zaEofaraAn [or saffron]. (Ṣ, A, Mṣb, Ḳ.)

zaEofaraAnN A certain dye and perfume, (TA,) well-known; (Mṣb, Ḳ;) [namely, saffron:] if it be in a house or chamber, the [lizard called] saAm-u OaboraSa will not enter it: (Ḳ:) pl. zaEaAfiru. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
Also † The rust of iron: pl. as above. (Ḳ.)
muzaEofarN A garment, or piece of cloth, dyed with zaEofaraAn [or saffron]. (A, Mṣb.)
[The kind of sweet food called] faAluwcN, (Ḳ, TA,) and also called mulaw-aSN and muzaEozaEN. (TA.)
† A lion of the colour termed warod [or red inclining to yellow]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) because its [natural] colour is such: or because having upon him marks of blood. (TA)

hom.sense: 1. zaEaqa, aor. _a {yazoEaqu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. zaEoqN, (TA,) He called out, or cried out. (Ḳ, TA.) You say; zaEaqotu bihi, inf. n. as above, I called out, or cried out, to him: (Ṣ:) of the dial. of Syria. (TA.)
And zaEaqa bidawaAb-ihi, (Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) He drove away his beasts: (Ḳ:) or he called out, or cried out, to his beasts, and drove them away quickly. (TA.)

And zaEaqahu, (Ḳ,) and zaEaqa bihi, (TA, as from the Ḳ,) aor. as above, (Ḳ,) and so the inf. n. in both cases, (TA,) He frightened him; as also AzEqhu↓: and OazoEaquwhu↓ They frightened him: (Ḳ:) or they frightened him so that he became brisk, lively, or sprightly: (TA:) or you say, AzEqhu↓ Alxawofu Hat-aI zaEiqa [Fear affected him so that he became brisk, lively, or sprightly, yet fearful]: accord. to Aṣ, one says OazoEaqotuhu↓, and the epithet applied to the object is mazoEuwqN↓, differing form rule; but accord. to El-Umawee, one says zaEaqotuhu, and the epithet so applied is mazoEuwqN↓. (Ṣ.)
zaEaqati Alr-iyHu Alt-uraAba The wind raised the dust: or made it to go to and fro: syn. OavaAratohu, (Ḳ,) or OamaAratohu. (IB.)
zaEaqatohu AlEaqorabu The scorpion stung him. (L, Ḳ.)
zagaqa Alqidora, (Ḳ,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) He put much salt into the cooking-pot; as also AzEqhA↓. (Ḳ.)

And zaEiqa, aor. _a {yazoEaqu}, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) inf. n. zaEaqN; (Ṣ, TA;) and zuEiqa; (Ḳ; [but only the former accord. to the TA, as in the Ṣ;]) He was, or became, brisk, lively, or sprightly, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) but with fear; (Ṣ;) as also AnzEq↓. (Ṣ. [This meaning of the last verb is indicated, but not expressed, in the Ṣ.])

zaEuqa, (Ḳ,) inf. n. zaEaAqapN (TḲ) [and zuEuwqapN], It (water) was, or became, bitter, (Ḳ, TA,) so that it could not be drunk [by reason of its bitterness, or saltness, or bitterness and saltness, or burning saltness, or intense bitterness or saltness: see zuEaAqN]. (Ḳ.)
4: see above {1}, in five places.
OazoEaquwA Als-ayora [app. for fiI Als-ayori] They made haste [in the journey, or rate of going]. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)
AzEq also signifies He produced, or fetched out, by labour [in digging], water such as is termed zuEaAq. (TA.) And AzEqwA They, in digging, came upon water such as is termed zuEaAq. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 7: see 1, latter part, in two places.
AnzEqt Ald-awaAb-u The beasts hastened, or went quickly. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)
And AnzEq Alfarasu The horse went forward, or before. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: zaEiqN Fearing, or fearing by night. (Ḳ,* TA.)
Brisk, lively, or sprightly, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) but with fear. (Ṣ.) [See also mazoEuwqN.]
hawolN zaEiqN Vehement terror. (TA.)
biYorN zaEiqapN A well of which the water is such as is termed zuEaAq. (TA.)
zuEaAqN A disposition to take fright and run away at random. (IF, O, Ḳ.)
And hence, (IF, O,) as an epithet applied to a mountain-goat, Wont to take fright and run away at random. (IF, O, Ḳ.)

Also Salt water: (Ṣ:) or very salt water; like HuraAqN: (TA in art. Hrq:) or water that is bitter, (mur-N galiyZN, Lth, O, Ḳ, both of which epithets, applied to water, signify the same, TA in art. glZ,) so that it cannot be drunk (Lth, O, Ḳ) by reason of its bitterness, or saltness, or bitterness and saltness, or burning saltness, or intense bitterness or saltness: (Lth, O:) used alike as sing. and pl. (TA.)
One says also, Oakalotuhu zuEaAqFA, meaning I ate it with so much salt in it that it was bitter. (Lth, O.) See also mazoEuwqN.

entry.sense: zaEiyqN: see mazoEuwqN.
zaE-aAqN One who drives away the beasts, and cries out after them. (TA.) [See also zaAEiqN.]
Applied to a horse, A good goer; or strong to walk, or go: (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ:) and also (Ibn-ʼAbbád) very quick. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)
zuEoquwqapN The young of the qaboj, (Lth, Ḳ, TA,) which means the Hajal [or partridge], and [sometimes] the karawaAn [or stone-curlew]: pl. zaEaAqiyqu. (TA.)
zaAEiqN One who calls out, or cries out, to his beasts, and drives them away quickly: or who drives them, and cries out to them vehemently. (TA.) [See also zaE-aAqN.]

hom.sense: mizoEaqN Quick: so in the phrase sayorN mizoEaqN [a quick pace or journeying]. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.) And one says also, nazaEa fiI Alqawosi nazoEFA mizoEaqFA, (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ,) i. e. [He drew the bow] quickly. (TA.)
It signifies also miqolaAEN tuqolaEu bihi AlOaraDuwna [app. meaning An implement with which the lands, or fields, are broken up]. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)

mazoEuwqN Frightened; as also zaEiyqN↓: (Ḳ:) [or frightened so as to be rendered brisk, lively, or sprightly, with fear:] see 1, in two places. [See also zaEiqN.] Applied to a colt, Frightened, and sharp in spirit: (Ṣ:) or, applied to a man, sharp in spirit: and, applied to a colt, well fed. (TA.)
OaroDN mazoEuwqapN Land rained upon by vehement rain falling in large drops. (Ḳ, TA.)
TaEaAmN mazoEuwqN Food having much salt put in it; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also zuEaAqN↓. (TA.) And qidorN mazoEuwqapN A cooking-pot in which much salt has been put. (TA.)

entry.sense: 1. zaEila, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yazoEalu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. zaEalN; (Ṣ, TA;) and tzE-l↓; (Ḳ;) He was, or became, brisk, lively, sprightly, active, agile, prompt, and quick; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) and he exulted, or exulted greatly, or excessively, and behaved insolently and unthankfully, or ungratefully. (TA.)
And the former, (Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) He (a horse) curvetted, pranced, leaped, sprang, or bounded, without his rider. (Ḳ.)
And He writhed, or cried out and writhed, by reason of hunger. (TA.)
[In the modern language, He was, or became, weary: one says, zaEilotu minohu I was, or became, weary of it.]
4. AzElhu [in the CK erroneously written zAEalahu] It (pasture, and fatness, TA) rendered him [i. e. a beast] brisk, lively, sprightly, active, agile, prompt, and quick. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)
And AzElhu mino makaAnihi He, or it, removed him, or unsettled him, from his place. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)
5: see 1.

zaEilN Brisk, lively, sprightly, active, agile, prompt, and quick; (Ṣ, TA;) as also UizoEiylN↓: (Ḳ:) the former is applied in this sense to a horse; and ↓the latter, as well as the former, to an ass, [i. e. a wild ass,] as meaning brisk, lively,, &c., and curvetting, prancing, leaping, springing, or bounding: and the former signifies also exulting, or exulting greatly, or excessively, and behaving insolently and unthankfully, or ungratefully: pl. zuE-alN, applied by Tarafeh to male ostriches. (TA.)
Also Writhing, or crying out and writhing, by reason of hunger. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
zuEoluwlN Light, or active, (Kr, Ḳ,) in spirit and in body: (TA in art. zgl:) accord. to Kr and Ibn-ʼAbbád, with E and with g: in the “Mu- sannaf” of AʼObeyd, with g only. (TA.)
[In the modern language, Weary: (see 1, last sentence:) and having its fem. with p.]
UizoEiylN: see zaEilN, in two places.
mutazaE-ilN: see zaEolaAnu.

hom.sense: 1. zaEama, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) aor. _u {yazoEumu}, (Mṣb, MṢ, JM, [not mentioned in the Ṣ nor in the Ḳ, app. because well known,]) inf. n. zaEomN and zuEomN and zEomN, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) the first of the dial. of El-Ḥijáz, (Mṣb, TA,) the second of the dial. of [the tribe of] Asad, (Mṣb,) or Benoo-Temeem, (TA,) and the third of the dial. of some of [the tribe of] Keys; (Mṣb;) [generally best rendered He asserted; for it mostly relates to a thing not certainly known: or] he said; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as in the phrases zaEamati AlHanafiy-apN [The Hanafees said or asserted, or have said or asserted,] and zaEama siybawayohi [Seebaweyh said or asserted, or has said or asserted]; (Mṣb;) [and zaEama Oan-ahu kacaA He said, or asserted, that it was thus;] either truly or falsely: (Ḳ:) mostly used in relation to a thing respecting which there is doubt, (Sh, Az, Mṣb, Ḳ,) and which is not certainly known: (Sh, Az, Mṣb:) or it is mostly used in relation to that which is false, or that respecting which there is doubt, or suspicion: (El-Marzookee, Mṣb:) or, as those skilled in the language of the Arabs say, in relation to a thing of which the speaker doubts, and does not know whether it may not be false: (Lth:) or zaEama zaEomFA means he related a piece of information not knowing whether it were true or false. (IḲooṭ, Mṣb.) Hence the saying, zaEama maTiy-apu Alkacibi [i. e. † zaEama is the conveyer, or vehicle, (properly the camel, or beast, that serves as the conveyer,) of lying]. (Mṣb.) It is said in a trad., biYosa maTiy-apu Alr-ajuli zaEamuwA [† Very evil, or bad, is the man's conveyer zaEamuwA]: i. e., when a man desires to journey to a country, or town, he mounts his camel, or beast, that serves to convey him, and journeys until he accomplishes the object of his want: therefore, that with which the speaker prefaces his speech, and by means of which he attains the object of his desire, when he says zaEamuwA kacaA wakacaA, is likened to the camel, or beast, by means of which he attains the object of want: for zaEamuwA is [generally] said only in the case of a narration that has no authority whereon to rest, and that contains no proof. (TA.) IKh says that Alz-aEomu is used in relation to that which is discommended; and that its primary signification is said by some of the expositors of the Ḳur-án to be The act of lying: (TA: [this signification is also given in the Ḳ, as being contr. to the first:]) some say that it is metonymically used in this sense: (Mṣb:) and it is expl. as having this meaning in the Ḳur [vi. 137], where it is said, faqaAluwA hecaA lil-ehi bizaEomihimo, i. e. [And they have said, “This belongeth unto God,”] with their lying. (Lth, TA.)
[Sometimes] zaEamahu signifies He described him, or it. (Ḥar p. 204.)

And sometimes zaEama signifies He promised: whence the saying of ʼAmr Ibn-Sha-s,
taquwlu halakonaA Uino halakota waUin-amaA
EalaI Qll-ehu OarozaAqu AlEibaAdi kamaA zaEamo
[Thou sayest, or she says, “We perish if thou perish:” but verily upon God lie the means of subsistence of mankind, i. e. it lies upon Him to supply these, as He has promised]. (TA.)

Alz-aEomu is used also in the sense of AlZ-an-u: (Mṣb, TA:) one says, fiI zaEomiI kacaA [In my opinion it is thus]. (Mṣb.) [Hence, likewise,] zaEamotaniI kacaA, (Ḳ,) aor. tazoEumuniI, (TA,) Thou thoughtest me to be thus. (Ḳ, TA.) Aboo-Dhu-eyb says,
faUino tuzoEumiyniI kunotu Oajohalu fiykumu
faUin-iI Xarayotu AlHiloma baEodaki biAljaholi
[And if thou think me such that I used to be ignorant, or to act ignorantly, among you, know that I have purchased intelligence since I was with thee (baEodaki being for baEoda EahodiI biki) in exchange for ignorance]. (TA. [The meaning of tzEmynI is there indicated by the context.])

It is also used in the sense of AlAiEotiqaAdu: whence the saying in the Ḳur [lxiv. 7], zaEama Ql-aciyna kafaruw Oano lano yuboEavuwA [They who have disbelieved our revelations have believed, or firmly believed, that they shall not be raised from the dead]. (Mṣb.)

Sometimes, also, zaEama is used in the sense of Xahida: as in the saying of En-Nábighah,
zaEama AlhumaAmu biOan-a faAhaA baAridN [app. meaning The magnanimous chief bore witness that her mouth was cool]. (TA.)

zaEama bihi, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yazoEumu} (Ṣ, Mṣb) and _a {yazoEamu}, (Mṣb,) inf. n. zaEomN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and zaEaAmapN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or the latter is a simple subst., (Mṣb,) He was, or became, responsible, answerable, amenable, surety, or guarantee, for it; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) namely, property. (Mṣb.)

And zaEama, like qatala, (Mṣb,) or zaEuma, like karuma, (TA,) aor. _u {yazoEumu}, inf. n. zaEaAmapN, He was, or became, chief, lord, master, or prince, (Mṣb, TA,) of a people, (TA,) or EalaI qawomK [over a people]; (Mṣb;) or spokesman of a people. (TA.)
See also 4, in two places.

zaEima, aor. _a {yazoEamu}, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. zaEamN (Ṣ, TA) and zaEomN, (TA,) He coveted, or eagerly desired. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [Like its syn. TamiEa, it is trans. by means of fiI.] One says, zaEima fulaAnN fiI gayori mazoEamK↓, i. e. TamiEa fI gayori maToEamK [Such a one coveted a thing not to be coveted; meaning, a thing of which the attainment was remote, or improbable: see art. TmE]. (TA.) And 'Antarah says,
Eul-iqotuhaA EaraDFA waOaqotulu qawomahaA
zaEamFA laEamoru Oabiyka layosa bimazoEami , (Ṣ,) i. e. I became enamoured of her unintentionally, [or accidentally,] while I was slaying her people; eagerly desiring her love: by the life of thy father, I swear, this is not a [fit] occasion for eager desire: i. e. I can not attain to holding communion of love with thee, [or with her,] any day, while there is this conflict and hostility between the two tribes: (EM p. 222:) layosa bimazoEamK meaning layosa bimaTomaEK: (Ṣ:) or, [as some relate it,]
zaEomFA warab-i Albayoti layosa bimazoEami
[eagerly desiring: by the Lord of the House (i. e. the Kaabeh), &c.]. (TA. [zaEomFA is there expressly said to be thus: but the measure does not require its being so.])

entry.sense: 3. zAEm, (Ḳ,) inf. n. muzaAEamapN, (TA,) i. q. zaAHama [q. v.]: (Ḳ:) the E is a substitute for the H. (TA.)

hom.sense: 4. AzEm He made a person to be such as is termed zaEiym; (Mṣb, TA;) as meaning responsible, answerable, amenable, surety, or guarantee. (Mṣb.) You say, OazoEamotuka AlmaAla, (Mṣb,) or AlX-aIoCa, (TA,) I made thee, or have made thee, responsible,, &c., (Mṣb, TA,*) [for the property, or the thing;] i. e. zaEiymFA bihi. (Mṣb, TA.)

He made one to covet, or eagerly desire. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) You say, OazoEamotuhu. (Ṣ.) [And OazoEamotuhu fiI AlX-aIoCi I made him to covet, or eagerly desire, the thing; like as you say, OaTomaEotuhu fiyhi. See zaEima.]
He obeyed (Ḳ, TA) the zaEiym [i. e. chief, lord, or prince]. (TA.)
It (an affair) was, or became, possible. (Ḳ.)
It (milk) began to become good, or pleasant; [or fit to be drunk;] as also zaEama↓, (Ḳ,) inf. n. zaEomN. (TA.)

AzEmt said of a young she-camel, or of one full-grown, She was thought to have fat in her hump. (IKh, TA. [The TA states it to have been asserted by IKh that the verb is only used in this sense, or (for the passage is ambiguous) in this sense and the first mentioned above.])
Also, (Ḳ,) or zaEamato↓, (TA, [but this I think to be probably a mistranscription,]) said of the earth, or land, (AlOaroDu,) It put forth the first of its plants, or herbage. (IAạr, Ḳ, TA.)

entry.sense:
5. tzE-m i. q. takac-aba [q. v.]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) [it seems here to mean He spoke falsely; and to be trans.; for] a poet says,
Oay-uhaA Alz-aAEimu maA tazaE-amaA [app. meaning O thou asserter of that which thou hast spoken falsely]. (TA. [This hemistich is there cited as an ex. of tzE-m as expl. in the Ḳ; and I find no other explanation of this verb.])

hom.sense: 6. tazaAEamaA They two competed in discoursing of a thing, and differed respecting it: accord. to Z, it means they talked of, or related, zaEamaAt, i. e. [mere assertions, or] stories in which no confidence was to be placed. (TA.) Sh says that Alt-azaAEumu is mostly used in relation to a thing respecting which there is doubt. (TA.)

One says also, tzAEm Alqawomu, meaning The people, or party, became responsible, one for another: and hence, tzAEmwA EalaI kacaA they leagued together, and aided one another, against such a thing. (TA.)

entry.sense: zuEomN [originally an inf. n. of zaEama, like zaEomN and ziEomN,] is a word used by the vulgar as meaning kiborN [i. e. Pride; and, as often used in the present day, pretension: because implying false, or vain, assertion]. (TA.)
zaEamN and zaEaAmapN↓ Responsibility, answerableness, amenableness, or suretiship; substs. from zaEama bihi: (Mṣb:) or the latter is an inf. n. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

zaEimN, applied to roasted meat, (Ḳ, TA,) Dripping with its gravy; or succulent, and dripping with its juice or fat; (TA;) having much grease, or gravy; quickly flowing [therewith] over the fire. (Ḳ.)

zaEomapN [inf. n. of un. of zaEama; An assertion;, &c.: pl. zaEamaAtN]. One says, hecaA walaA zaEomataka and wlA zaEamaAtika [meaning This I think, and I think not to be true thine assertion and thine assertions]; Oatawah-amu being understood after lA: these words are used as meaning the rejection of what has been said by the person to whom they are addressed. (Ḳ, TA. [In the CK, erroneously, zaEomatika and zaEomaAtika.]) They said also, zaEomapN SaAdiqapN laMtiyan-aka [i. e. It is a true assertion: I will assuredly come to thee]; using the nom. case: though they said, yamiynFA SaAdiqapF laOafoEalan-a [i. e. I swear “a true oath: I will assuredly do” such a thing]; using the accus. case. (Ks, TA.) And one says, taHaAdavaA biAlz-aEamaAti, meaning They two talked of, or related, each to the other, [mere assertions, or] stories in which no confidence was to be placed. (Z, TA.)
zuEomiI-N (with damm, TA) Mendacious: and veracious: (Ḳ:) thus bearing two contr. significations. (TA.)
zuEomuwmN: see the next paragraph.

hom.sense: zaEuwmN, a fem. epithet, (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.,) applied to a she-camel, and to a sheep or goat, Of which one doubts whether there be in her fat or not, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and which is therefore felt with the hands, in order that one may know if she be fat or lean: (Ṣ:) or a sheep or goat of which one knows not whether there be in her fat or not: (Aṣ, TA:) or, as some say, of which men assert that there is in her marrow. (TA.) And, as a fem. epithet, Having little fat: and having much fat: thus bearing two contr. senses: as also muzoEamapN↓ [app. in both senses]: (M, Ḳ:) and mazoEuwmapN↓ also signifies having little fat; of which people, when they eat of her, say to her owner, “Didst thou assert her to be fat?” applied to a she-camel. (TA.)
Also Impotent in speech; (Ḳ;) and so zuEomuwmN↓. (Ṣ,* Ḳ.)
zaEiymN Responsible, answerable, amenable, surety, or guarantee. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.) Hence, in the Ḳur [xii. 72], waOanaA bihi zaEiymN [And I am responsible for it]. (TA.)

Also The chief, lord, master, or prince, or a people; (Mṣb, Ḳ;) or [in the CK “and”] their spokesman: (Ḳ:) their chief is thus called because he speaks for them; like as he is called qayolN and miqowalN: (Ḥam p. 705:) pl. zuEamaMCu. (Ḳ.)
Also Described; syn. mawoSuwfN. (Ḥar p. 204.)
zaEaAmapN: see zaEamN.

Also High, or elevated, rank or condition or state; or nobility. (Ḳ.) And Chiefdom, lordship, mastery, or princedom: (IAạr, Ṣ, Ḳ:) [accord. to the Mṣb, an inf. n. in this sense:] thus expl. by IAạr as occurring in the following verse of Lebeed: (TA:)
taTiyru EadaAYidu AlOaXoraAki XafoEFA
wawitorFA waAlz-aEaAmapu lilogulaAmi
(Ṣ and TA in the present art. and in art. Ed) [The portions of inheritance of the sharers fly away, two together and singly; but the chiefdom is for the boy]: by his saying XafoEFA wawitorFA, he means that the male's share of inheritance is like that of two females [so that he has two portions when the female has one]: but other explanations, those here following, are given of AlzEAmp as used in this verse. (TA. [See also EadiydapN.])

A weapon, or weapons; syn. silaAHN. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) So, accord. to J, in the verse of Lebeed: for, he says, they used, when they divided the inheritance, to give the weapon, or weapons, to the son, exclusively of the daughter. (TA.)
A coat of mail: (Ḳ:) or coats of mail: and thus it is expl. by IAạr as used in the verse of Lebeed. (TA.)
The chief's share of spoil. (Ḳ.)
And The best and most of the property of an inheritance and the like: (Ḳ:) and thus, also, it has been expl. as used in the verse of Lebeed. (TA.)
Also, and zaE-aAmapN↓, An animal of the ox-kind; [probably meaning one of the wild species;] syn. baqarapN. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: zaE-aAmapN: see the next preceding sentence.

hom.sense: mazoEamN A thing, or an affair, in which no confidence is to be placed; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) this saying, or asserting, it to be thus, and this saying, or asserting, it to be thus: (Ṣ:) [pl. mazaAEimu.] One says, fiI qawolihi mazaAEimu (Ṣ, TA) i. e. [In his saying are things in which no confidence is to be placed; or] no confidence is to be placed in his saying. (TA.) And hecaA OamorN fiyhi mazaAEimu This is an affair that is not right; (TA;) [wherein are things] respecting which there is dispute. (Ḳ, TA.) And zaEama gayora mazoEamK He said that which was not good, or right, or just; and asserted what was impossible. (Mṣb.)
Also A thing that is, or is to be, coveted, or eagerly desired; syn. maTomaEN. (Ṣ, TA.) See two exs. near the end of the first paragraph.

entry.sense: muzoEamN: see its fem., with p {muzoEamapN}, voce zaEuwmN.
OamorN muzoEimN A thing, or an affair, that makes one to covet, or desire eagerly. (TA.)
mazoEuwmN: see its fem. mazoEuwmapN, voce zaEuwmN.
mizoEaAmapN A serpent. (Ḳ.)
huwa muzaAEamN No confidence is to be placed in him, or it. (So in the TA. [But I incline to think it a mistranscription for fiyhi mazaAEimu. See mazoEamN.])

1. zagiba, aor. _a {yazogabu}, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. zagabN; (Mṣb;) and zg-b↓, (JK, Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) inf. n. tazogiybN; (Ṣ;) and AzgAb-↓; (Ḳ;) It, or he, was, or became, downy; or had upon it, or him, what is termed zagabN meaning as expl. below; (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ;) in any of its senses: (TA:) said of a young bird, (JK, Ṣ, A, Mṣb,) meaning [as above, or] its zagab [or down] grew forth: (A:) or its feathers were small: and, said of a boy, or a young child, his zagab [or downy hair] grew forth: (Mṣb:) and Aizolagab-a↓ is also said of a young bird [in the same sense as the verbs above: (see art. zlgb:) or] as meaning its feathers came forth. (Ṣ.)
[Hence,] baHorN yazogabu † A sea, or great river, that becomes [foaming, or] in a state of commotion, and full. (JK.)
2: see the preceding paragraph {1}:
and that here following {4}.

4. Azgb, said of a grape-vine, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) i. e., app., accord. to [J and] F, like Oakorama, but accord. to others of the leading lexicologists it seems to be [Azgb-↓,] like AiHomar-a; as also AzgAb-↓; It produced what resembled zagab [or down], at the knots of the shoots, whence the bunches of grapes would grow: (TA:) this it does when the sap flows in it, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) and it begins to produce leaves. (Ḳ, TA.)

A'Obeyd, in applying to the truffles termed banaAtu Oawobara the epithet mzgbp, [written in art. wbr in copies of the Ḳ muzogibapN↓, and in the T and Ṣ and M muzag-ibapN↓, but in the present art. in the TA it seems to be indicated that it is probably muzogib-apN↓,] signifying having zagab [i. e. down], assigns to it a verb [which may be Oazogabato or zag-abato↓ or Aizogab-ato↓, meaning They had, or produced, a kind of downy substance]. (TA.)
8. Azdgb maA EalaI AlxiwaAni He took away, or swept away, [or devoured,] the whole of what was on the table of food: like Azdgf. (TA.) [See also 8 in art. zEb.]
9: see 4, in two places.
and see also 4.

zagabN [Down:] or the yellow [down resembling] small hairs upon the feathers of the young bird: (Ṣ:) or small and soft hair and feathers: or each of these when first coming forth: (A, Ḳ:) i. e. (TA) the small and soft hair when it first appears, of a young child, (Mṣb, TA,) and of a colt [or foal]; (JK,* TA;) and likewise of an old man, when his hair becomes thin and weak; (Mṣb;) and the feathers when they first appear, (Mṣb, TA,) of the young bird: (TA:) and small feathers that do not become long nor good: (JK, Mṣb:) n. un. with p {zagabapN}: (TA:) and what remains upon the head of an old man when his hair has become thin. (Ḳ.)

[Hence,] Oaxacahu bizagabihi † He took it at its commencement, or in its first and fresh state. (JK, Ḳ.) And Oaxacahu bizagabi raqabatihi [lit. He took him by the down of his neck;] meaning † he overtook him. (JK.)
zagibN: see Oazogabu, in three places.
zugabN: see Oazogabu.

zugaAbapN and zugaAbaI↓ The smallest of zagab [or down]: (JK, Ḳ:) or something less in quantity than zagab: or something smaller than zagab. (TA.) One says, maA OaSabotu minohu zugaAbapF (JK, A, Ḳ, TA) i. e. † [I obtained not from him, or it,] as much as what is termed zgAbp: (L, TA:) or ‡ the least thing: (A:) or † anything. (Ḳ.)
zugaAbaI: see the next preceding paragraph.

Oazogabu [Downy;] having upon it, or him, what is termed zagab; as also zagibN↓: fem. of the former zagobaMCu; and pl. zugobN. (TA.) You say faroxN Oazogabu [A downy young bird]: (A:) and firaAxN zugobN [downy young birds]. (Ṣ.) And rajulN zagibN↓ [A downy man]: (JK:) or rajulN zagibu↓ AlX-aEari [a man having downy hair]. (Mṣb, TA.) And raqabapN zagobaMCu [A downy neck]. (JK, A, Mṣb.) And qiv-aMCu Oazogabu (AḤn, A, TA) ‡ [A species of cucumber] having upon it what resembles the zagab [or down] of fur, which falls off by degrees when they become large, leaving them smooth. (AḤn, TA.) [For another epithet of similar meaning, see 4, in three places.]

Also † A species of fig, (AḤn, Ḳ,) larger than the waHoXiI- [or wild], upon which is zagab [or down]: when stripped of this, it comes forth black: it is large, thick, and sweet: but it is a worthless sort of fig. (AḤn, TA.)

Applied to a horse, Black and white; or white in the hind legs as high as the thighs; syn. Oabolaqu. (Ḳ.) And [in like manner] applied to a mountain, Of which the whiteness is intermixed with its blackness; as also zugabN↓. (JK, Ḳ, TA. [In some of the copies of the Ḳ, for mina AljibaAli, we find mn AlHibaAli: that the former is the right reading, contr. to the assertion of Freytag app. based on the explanation in the TḲ, appears from its being added that the fem.]) Alz-agobaMCu is the name of a certain mountain in El-Kibleeyeh; (Ḳ, TA;) in some copies of the Ḳ, El-Kabaleeyeh. (TA.)
muzogibapN, or muzag-ibapN, or muzogib-apN: see 4.
Q. 1. zagobara It (a garment, or piece of cloth,) had what is termed zigobir, or zigobur, &c., i. e. ziYobir [or nap]. (O, Ḳ.)

zigobirN, (O and TA, and so in a copy of the Ḳ,) or zagobarN, or zigobarN, (as in two different copies of the Ḳ,) and zigoburN, (O and TA, and so accord. to a copy of the Ḳ,) or zagoburN, (accord. to another copy of the Ḳ,) of a garment, or piece of cloth, i. q. ziYobirN [i. e. The nap: see ziYobirN, in art. zbr]. (O, Ḳ.) [Hence, app., supposing zagobarN to be a dial. var., having the signification expl. above,] Oaxaca AlX-aIoCa bizagobarihi He took the thing altogether, (O, Ḳ,* TA,) leaving nothing of it; as also bizaOobarihi, and bizawobarihi. (O, TA.)

Q. 1. zagoradapN The braying that is reiterated (L, Ḳ) in the fauces, or throat, (L,) or in the jawof [meaning chest], (Ḳ,) of the camel: (L, Ḳ:) an inf. n., of which the verb is zagorada: you say, zagorada AlbaEiyru. (TḲ.)

Hence the zagoradap of women on the occasions of rejoicings. (TA.) [One says, of a woman, zagoradato, more commonly in the present day zagoraTato, meaning She uttered shrill, quavering, or rapidly-reiterated, sounds, or cries of joy: which sounds, or cries, are termed zagaAriydu↓, and now more commonly zagaAriyT.]
zagaAriydu: see above.

1. zagalahu, aor. _a {yazogalu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. zagolN, (TA,) He, or it, poured it out, or forth, with an impetus, or with force. (Ḳ. [See also 4.]) And He, or it, spirted it forth; (Ḳ;) as also Azglhu↓. (TA.) You say, Oazogalotu↓ AlX-araAba I spirted forth the wine, or beverage. (JK.) And zagalati AlmazaAdapu mino EazolaAYihaA The leathern water-bag poured [or spirted] forth from its spout. (TA.)
And zagalati Aln-aAqapu bibawolihaA: see 4.

zagala AlOum-a He (a kid, TA) sucked the mother: (Ḳ, TA:) [and ragala is a dial. var. thereof:] so says Er-Riyáshee: or, as in the L, zagalati Albahomapu Oum-ahaA the young lamb or hid overpowered its mother and sucked her. (TA.)

hom.sense: 4. Azglhu, inf. n. UizogaAlN, He poured it out, or forth. (TA. [And zagalahu app. signifies the same.]) One says, Oazogala mino EazolaMCi AlmazaAdapi AlmaMCa He poured forth, from the spout of the leathern water-bag, the water. (TA.) And Oazogilo liI zugolapF↓ mino siqaAYika, (Ṣ,) or mino UinaAYika, (Ḳ, [in the CK Azogalo, i. e. Aizogalo, from zagalahu,]) Pour thou out, for me, somewhat (Ṣ, Ḳ) [or a gulp or mouthful] of milk from thy skin, (Ṣ,) or from thy vessel. (Ḳ.) See also 1, in two places. One says also, Oazogalati Aln-aAqapu bibawolihaA (Ṣ, Ḳ) and zagalato↓ bihi (Ḳ) The she-camel ejected her urine (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA) in repeated small quantities (zugolapF zugolapF↓), and interrupted it. (Ṣ, TA.) And Oazogalati AlT-aEonapu biAld-ami, like Oawozagat [i. e. The wound made with a spear or the like emitted blood in repeated gushes]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
Oazogalato waladahaA She suckled her child. (JK, TA.) And Azgl faroxahu He (a bird) fed his young one with his mouth, or bill: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) [and Argl is a dial. var. thereof.]

Oazogalota, said by 'Ásim to Mis'ar, when the latter was reading, or reciting, to him, and did so incorrectly, means Thou hast become like the zugoluwl, i. e. young infant: mentioned by Z: (TA:) or he said Oazogalota, which is a dial. var. of the former verb. (TA in art. rgl.)

entry.sense: zagalN i. q. giX-N [meaning Adulterated, or counterfeit, coin: so in the present day]. (TA.) [See also zugaliI-N.]

hom.sense: zugolapN A mouthful, or the quantity that fills the mouth; of milk [&c.]; heard in this sense by Az from an Arab of the desert; (TA;) a gulp of wine or beverage [&c.]: pl. zugolN [perhaps a mistranscription for zugalN: if not, it is a coll. gen. n.]. (MA.) See 4.
The quantity that is emitted, or poured forth, at once, [without interruption,] of urine, (Ṣ, Ḳ,), &c. (Ḳ.) See, again, 4.
The quantity that one spirts forth from his mouth, of wine or beverage. (Ḳ.)
Alz-ugolapu also signifies The Aisot [i. e. podex, or anus]. (El-Hejeree, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: zugaliI-N [A maker of adulterated, or counterfeit, coin; a meaning indicated in the TA, and obtaining in the present day:] an epithet from Alz-agalu, used by the vulgar and by persons of distinction. (TA.)

zugoluwlN Light, or active, (Kr, JK, Ṣ, Ḳ,) in spirit and in body, (IKh, TA,) and quick; an epithet applied to a man: (JK:) mentioned by Kr with E and with g: (TA:) in the “Musannaf” of AʼObeyd, with g only. (TA in art. zEl.)
Also A young infant: (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ:) pl. zagaAliylu. (TA.) One says SiboyapN zagaAliylu Little children. (TA.) And kayofa zugoluwluka How is thy little one? (A, TA.)
And An orphan. (IKh, TA.)
And The young one of the pigeon. (TA.)
[Freytag explains it as signifying also “Pallus ovis, cameli lactens;” but whether this be intended to express a single meaning is not clear to me:]
[also, on the authority of Dmr, as signifying A man light in respect of dignity and manners: app. as being likened to a young child.]
zaguwlN, applied to [the young one of] a camel and [of] a sheep or goat, Persistent in suching. (Ḳ.)
muzogilN [without p because applied only to a female,] A woman suckling her child. (JK, TA.)
mazogalapN A drinking-vessel that holds a [zugolap i. e.] gulp, or as much as is swallowed at once [of wine or beverage]. (MA.)

hom.sense: 1. zaf-a AlEaruwsa, (Ḳ,) or zafafotuhaA, (Ṣ,) or zaf-atohaA Aln-isaMCu, (Mṣb,) aor. _u {yazofufu}, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. zaf-N (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and zifaAfN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or the latter is a simple subst.; (Mṣb;) and Azf-hA↓, (Ḳ,) or AzffthA, (Ṣ,) or Azf-thA AlnsMC; (Mṣb;) and Azdf-hA↓, (Ḳ,) or AzdffthA, (Ṣ,) [or Azdf-thA AlnsMC;] UilaI zawojihaA; all signify the same; (Ṣ, Mṣb,* Ḳ;) i. e. He, [or I,] or the women, sent [or conducted] the bride [with festive parade or pageantry, and generally with music,] to her husband: (Mṣb, Ḳ:) accord. to Er-Rághib, zf- AlErws is a metaphorical phrase, from zafozafapu Aln-aEaAmi; because she is conducted with joyous alacrity. (TA.)

zaf-a,, aor. _i {yazofifu}, inf. n. zafiyfN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and zaf-N and zufuwfN, (Ḳ,) or zafiyfN is a simple subst., (Mṣb,) said of an ostrich, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and of a camel, (Ṣ,), &c., (Ḳ,) He hastened, or was quick; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also Azf-↓: (IAạr, Ḳ:) accord. to Lḥ, said of a man and of others; and Azf-↓, he says, is the more unusual of the two: (TA:) or zaf-a, aor. _i {yazofifu}, is said, in this sense, of a man: and, accord. to the Mj, said of an ostrich, inf. n. zafiyfN, it means he hastened, or was quick, so that a [sound such as is termed] zafiyf was heard to be produced by his wings: (Mṣb:) or zaf-N and UizofaAfN↓ are like camiylN [which signifies the going a gentle pace; or a pace above that which is termed AlEanaqu, and above that which is termed Alt-azay-udu]: (Ḳ,* TA: [in the CK, Alz-amiyl is put for Alc-amiyl:]) or the first running of the ostrich: (Ḳ:) or zafiyfN has this last meaning: (TA:) or signifies the going quickly and with short steps: (Lḥ, TA:) or the going quickly, with short steps, and quietly. (TA.) You say, zaf-a Alqawomu fiI maXoyihimo The people, or party, hastened, or were quick, in their walking, or marching, or going along: and hence, in the Ḳur [xxxvii. 92], faOaqobluwA Uilayohi yazif-uwna, (Ṣ,) i. e. [And they advanced towards him] hastening, or going quickly. (Fr, TA. [But there are other readings, for which see Bḍ.]) [Hence also,] one says zaf-a raOoluhu, meaning ‡ He was, or became, light of intellect, lightwitted, or irresolute. (Ṣ, Z, TA. [See also art. rOl])

zaf-a, inf. n. zafiyfN (O, Ḳ) and zaf-N, (Ḳ,) said of a bird, (O, Ḳ,) in his flight, (O,) He cast himself: (ʼEyn, O, Ḳ:) or he spread his wings: and so zafozafa↓ [app. in either sense]: (Ḳ:) and the latter, he moved [or flapped] his wings in running. (TA.)

zaf-ati Alr-iyHu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _i {yazofifu}, (Ṣ,) inf. n. zafiyfN and zufuwfN, (TA,) The wind blew along, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) not violently: (Ṣ:) or blew gently and continually: (TA:) and zafozafat↓ signifies the same: (Ḳ, TA:) or the latter, inf. n. zafozafapN, signifies it blew violently: so in the T: or it blew gently: (TA:) or zafozafapN signifies the moaning (Haniyn) of the wind, and its sounding among the trees. (Ṣ.)
zaf-a, (O, Ḳ,) inf. n. zafiyfN, (TA,) said of lightning, It shone, or gleamed. (O, Ḳ, TA.)
4. Azf-, inf. n. UizofaAfN, intrans.: see 1, in three places.
Azf- AlEaruwsa: see 1, first sentence.
Azf-hu He made him to hasten, or go quickly; (Ṣ, L, Ḳ;) namely, a camel, (Ṣ, L,) and an ostrich. (Ṣ.)
[And accord. to Freytag, it occurs in the Deewán el-Hudhaleeyeen as meaning He led him to do light, vain, things.]

entry.sense: 8. Azdf- AlEaruwsa: see 1, first sentence.
Azdf- AlHimola He carried, took up and carried, or raised upon his back, the load. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)

10. Astzf-hu Als-ayolu, (Ibn-ʼAbbád, A, O, TA,) thus correctly, but in the copies of the Ḳ Als-ayoru, (TA,) The torrent found it light to carry (Aisotaxaf-ahu, Ibn-ʼAbbád, A, O, Ḳ), and took it away. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, A, O, TA.)
R. Q. 1. zafozafa, [inf. n. zafozafapN,] said of a man, He walked in a comely manner. (TA.)
zafozafapN also signifies The running vehemently. (Ḳ.)
And A certain manner, or rate, of going, of camels, said to be beyond, or above, what is termed Alxababu. (TA.)
Said of a bird: see 1, latter part.

And zafozafat said of the wind: see, again, 1, latter part. The inf. n. signifies The wind's putting in motion the dry herbage, and making a sound therein: (Ḳ, TA:) you say, of the dry herbage, zafozafatohu Alr-iyHu [The wind put it in motion,, &c.]. (TA.)
The inf. n. signifies also The noising, or noise-making, of a procession, or company of men riding or walking along. (IDrd, Ḳ.)
And The sounding of an arrow when it is twirled round upon the nail [of the left thumb: see dar-a Als-ahomu, in art. dr]. (TA.)

It is related in a trad., that the Prophet said to a woman, maA laki tuzafozafiyna, (O, Ḳ, TA, in some copies of the Ḳ tuzafozifiyna,) with damm to the first letter; (Ḳ) to which she replied “The fever, may God not bless it;” and he said “Revile not thou the fever, for it does away with the sins of the sons of Adam like as the blacksmith's skin with which he blows his fire does away with the dross of the iron:” (O, TA:) the meaning is, [What aileth thee] that thou art made to tremble, or quake? (turoEadiyna: O, Ḳ, TA: in some copies of the Ḳ turoEidiyna:) [see also mazofuwfN:] or it is with fet-ḥ to the t, (O, Ḳ, TA,) i. e. tazafozafiyna [for tatazafozafyna, from tazafozafato↓], (O,) meaning, that thou tremblest, or quakest? (O, Ḳ:) or it is with kesr to the [latter] z, [tuzafozifiyna,] meaning, that thou moanest, as does he who is sick: (TA:)
or, as some relate it, it is with r [in the place of the z, i. e. tuzaforifiyna, having the second of the meanings expl. above in this sentence, or nearly so]. (Ḳ.)
R. Q. 2. tazaforafato: see the next preceding paragraph (R.Q.1), last sentence.

zif-N Small feathers of the ostrich, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and (Ṣ, in the Ḳ “or”) of a bird (Ṣ, Ḳ) of any kind: (Ḳ:) or small feathers, like down, beneath the thickset feathers: (IDrd, O, TA:) accord. to some, only of the ostrich: (O, TA:) [pl., app., zifaAfN: see zafaAzifu.] One says Oaloyanu mino zif-i Aln-aEaAmi [More soft than the small feathers of the ostrich]. (TA.)
