zaf-apN ‡ A time; one time; syn. mar-apN: (Ḳ:) one says, jiYotuhu zaf-apF, or zaf-atayoni, ‡ I came to him once, or twice. (TA.) A single act of zafiyf [i. e. hastening, or going quickly]. (TA. [This seems to be the primary signification.])

zuf-apN A company, or congregated body, of men. (O, Ḳ.) Hence the saying of the Prophet to Bilál, on the occasion of the marriage of Fátimeh, Oadoxili Aln-aAsa EalaI-a zuf-apF zuf-apF, meaning Bring thou in the people to me company after company. (O, TA.)
zafafN, in a male ostrich, The quality of having abundant and dense zif-, i. e. small feathers. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
zafuwfN: see zafozafN.

Hence it is applied to a she-camel, as being likened to an ostrich in her quickness; (TA;) meaning [Quick: or] good in pace, and quick. (Ḥam p. 750.) And Alz-afuwfu is the name of a certain horse that belonged to Noamán Ibn-El-Mundhir. (O.)
Also A twanging bow. (TA.)

hom.sense: zafiyfN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and Oazaf-u↓ and zif-aAniI-N↓, (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ,) or zif-aAnN↓, without I, (L, TA,) Quick, (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ṣ, L, Ḳ,) like cafiyfN, (Ṣ,) and light. (L, TA. [In the CK the explanation is omitted.])
It is also an inf. n.: (Ṣ, Ḳ, &c.:) or a simple subst. (Mṣb.) [See 1, in several places.]

entry.sense: zif-aAnN: see the next preceding paragraph.
zif-aAniI-u: see the next preceding paragraph.

zafozafN and zafozaAfN↓ [the latter of which is omitted in the CK] A wind that blows violently, with continuance; as also zafozaAfapN↓, (Ḳ, TA,) or zafozafapN: (CK:) or zafozaAfapN↓ and zafozafN a wind making a moaning (Haniyn), and sounding among the trees: (Ṣ:) or zafozafN a quick, or swift, wind: or zafozafapN and zafozaAfapN↓ and zafozaAfN↓ a violent wind, having a zafozafap, i. e. sounding: the pl. of zafozafN is zafaAzifu. (TA.)
Also, (i. e. the first and second words,) Light [in motion or action]. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)
And The ostrich; (Ḳ;) so called because of his lightness of pace; or because of his zafozafap, meaning his moving [or flapping] of his wings when running; (TA;) and so zafuwfN↓. (Ḳ.)
zafaAzifu pl. of zafozafN.
It is also used by a Hudhalee poet [app. referring to birds] as meaning cawaAtu zifaAfK [i. e., supposing zifaAf to be pl. of zif-N, agreeably with analogy, Having small, downy, feathers]. (TA.)

[zaAf-N act. part. n. of zaf-a in the phrase zaf-a AlEaruwsa: fem. with p {zaAf-apN}: pl. of the latter zawaAf-u. Hence,] zaHafato zawaAf-uhaA, a phrase mentioned by Lḥ, meaning All-awaAtiIzafafonahaA [i. e. The women who conducted her to her husband walked along gently]. (TA.)
Oazaf-u A male ostrich having abundant and dense zif-, i. e. small feathers. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
See also zafiyfN.
mizaf-apN A [vehicle of the kind called] miHaf-apN in which, or upon which, the bride is sent [or conducted] to her husband. (Kh, Ṣ, Ḳ.)

[mazofuwfN pass. part. n. of zaf-a in a sense not mentioned, and perhaps not used. Hence,] baAta mazofuwfFA a phrase meaning bAt tuzafozifuhu Alr-iyHu [i. e. He passed the night made to tremble, or quake, by the wind]. (TA.)
2. zf-t He smeared a receptacle [such as a wine-skin and a wine-jar] with zifot. (Mṣb.)

zifotN [Pitch: or tar: or a sort of pitch: or crude pitch:] i. q. qaArN: (A, Mgh, Ḳ:) or qiyrN: (Mṣb:) or qaTiraAnN: (A, Mṣb:) or it is like qiyrN: (Ṣ:) it is not the qiyr with which ships are smeared, but [like this inasmuch as] it is also a black substance, with which wine-skins are seasoned; for the qyr of ships dries upon them, whereas the zft of skins does not dry: (TA:) or [crude pitch; i. e.] a produce of the pine, or pitch-tree; which is of two sorts, moist and dry; the latter being either cooked, or congealed of itself; such as flows of itself from the trees is called zft; such as is prepared by cooking, and art, qaTiraAnN. (TḲ.) [See also kuforN: and see De Sacy's “Abd-allatif,” p. 273.]

Also, (Ḳ,* TA,) i. e. zifotN, (TA,) [not muzaf-atN, which Freytag has supposed to be here intended in the Ḳ, and not without some reason, for the passage is ambiguous,] A certain medicine; (Ḳ, TA;) a thing that comes forth from the earth, [app. a sort of bitumen, perhaps another name for qaforN yahuwdiI-N bitumen Judaicum, or Jew's pitch,] that is an ingredient in medicines: not the zft commonly known. (TA.)

muzaf-atN Smeared with zifot; (Ṣ, A,* Mgh, Ḳ;) applied to a wine-skin, (A,) or a vessel, or receptacle for wine; i. q. muqay-arN. (TA.) The receptacle thus termed quickly occasions alteration [or fermentation] in the wine [contained in it]. (Mgh.) You say jar-apN muzaf-atapN A jar smeared with zifot. (Ṣ.) And it is said in a trad., nahaI Eani Almuzaf-ati [He forbade the use of that skin, or vessel, which is smeared with zft, for the beverage called nabiyc]. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. zafara, aor. _i {yazofiru}, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. zafiyrN (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) and raforN (Ḳ) and UizofiyrN, (M, [like UiroziyzN, app. an inf. n., or perhaps a simple subst.,]) He drew in his breath to the utmost, by reason of distress: (Ṣ:) it originally signifies he drew back his breath vehemently, so that his ribs became swollen out: (Er-Rághib:) zafiyrN is the beginning of the cry of the ass, (Lth, Ṣ, A, Er-Rághib,) and of the like, (Lth,) and is generally used in this sense; (Er-Rághib;) and XahiyqN is the ending thereof; (Lth, Ṣ, A, Er-Rághib;) for the former is the drawing in of the breath, and the latter is the sending it forth: (Lth, Ṣ:) or the verb signifies he sent forth his breath, after prolonging it: (M, Ḳ:) or he sent forth his breath with a prolonged sound: [i. e., he sighed, or uttered a long sigh, or sighed vehemently; or he groaned:] or he filled his chest, by reason of grief, and then sent forth his breath: (TA:) or he breathed, raising his voice, like one moaning, or in grief. (Ḥar p. 20.)

[Hence,] zafarati Aln-aAru † The fire made a sound to be heard from its burning, or its fierce burning: (Ḳ:) and this [sounding] is termed zafiyrN. (TA.) [See also HadomN; where zaforN, its inf. n., is expl., on the authority of AZ, as signifying The flaming, or blazing, of fire.] And AlbaHoru yazofiru bitamaw-ujihi ‡ [The sea makes a roaring by its tumultuousness]. (A, TA.)
zafarati AlOaroDu † The land put forth its plants, or herbage. (TA.)

zafara, aor. _i {yazofiru}, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) inf. n. zaforN; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and Azdfr↓; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) He carried, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) a thing, (Ḳ,) or a load, or burden, (Ṣ, A,) as, for ex., a filled water-skin. (TA.) You say, yazofiruwna Eanohu AlOavoqaAla [They bear, or carry, or take off from him, and carry, his burdens]. (A.)
He drew, (Ḳ, TA,) and carried, (TA,) water. (Ḳ, TA.)

entry.sense: 2: see the next paragraph {5}.

hom.sense: 5. tzf-r occurs in the Saheeh of El-Bukháree as meaning taxab-aTa [q. v.]: but El-Jelál says, in the Towsheeh, that this is not known in the language of the Arabs. (MF.)

[Freytag explains it as meaning He ate fat food, breaking the fast; like zf-r↓; (which latter generally means, in the present day, he rendered greasy;) but this I believe to be post-classical. See De Sacy's Chrest. Ar., sec. ed., i. 270.]

entry.sense: 8: see 1, near the end of the paragraph.

ziforN A load, or burden, syn. HimolN, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) on the back, (Ḳ,) or on the head, that is heavy, and in consequence of which the bearer breathes vehemently, or groans (yazofiru): (A:) pl. OazofaArN. (Ṣ, A.)
A [water-skin of the kind called] qirobap: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) a skin in which a pastor carries his water: pl. as above. (TA.)
The apparatus of a traveller, (Ḳ,) comprising the water-skin, &c. (TA.)
A lamb; syn. HamalN: so in the Bári'. (Ḳ.) This signification and that of HimolN are both correct. (TA.)

hom.sense: zafarN A prop of a tree. (Ḳ, TA.)

[In modern Arabic, it means Grease, greasy food, or flesh-meat: app. from the Pers. zafaro or zafor, signifying “filth:” and hence, obscenity. Hence also the vulgar epithet zifir (app. for zafirN), meaning Greasy: and foul, or filthy: and obscene. See 5.]

entry.sense: zufarN ‡ A sea, (Ḳ,) that makes a roaring, (yazofiru,) by reason of its tumultuousness. (TA.)
‡ A river containing much water, (Ḳ,) so that it resembles a sea. (TA.)
‡ A large gift, (Ḳ,) as likened to a sea. (TA.)
‡ A liberal man; likened to a sea that makes a roaring, (yazofiru,) by reason of its tumultuousness; (A;) as also zaAfirapN↓. (TA.)
One who carries loads, or burdens; meaning, who has strength to carry water-skins. (Ḳ.) [See also zaAfirapN.]
† One who has power to bear responsibilities. (Sh, Ṣ.*)
Hence, † A lord, master, chief, or the like: (Ṣ:) or, for the same reason, a great lord, or the like; (TA;) as also zaAfirapN↓. (Ḳ, TA.)
† A courageous man. (Ḳ,* TA.)
† A lion. (Ḳ.)
See also zaAfirapN, in three places:
and zafiyrN.

zaforapN A drawing-in of the breath to the utmost, by reason of distress: (Ṣ:) [or a drawing-back of the breath vehemently, so that the ribs become swollen out: (see 1:)] or an emission of the breath after prolonging it; as also zuforapN↓ and muzodafarN↓ and muzaf-arN↓, (Ḳ, TA,) or muzofarN↓, (as in a copy of the Ḳ,) and muzaf-arapN↓: (CK, but omitted in the TA and in my MṢ. copy of the Ḳ:) [or an emission of the breath with a prolonged sound; i. e., a sigh, or a long or vehement sigh; or a groan: or an emission of the breath after filling the chest with it by reason of grief: (see, again, 1:)] pl. zafaraAtN, because it is a subst., not an epithet; but sometimes, by poetic license, zaforaAtN. (Ṣ.) El-Jaadee says,
xiyTa EalaIzaforapK fatam-a walamo
yarojiEo EalaI diq-apK walaAhaDami
meaning As though he were sewed up after a drawing-in of the breath to the utmost, by reason of distress, so that he seemed to be constantly so drawing in his breath, on account of the largeness of his belly, [and did not become restored to slenderness nor lankness of the belly.] (Ṣ.) And another says,
fatasotariyHu Aln-afosu mino zaforaAtihaA
[And the soul finds rest from its drawing-in of the breath to the utmost, by reason of distress; or from its sighs, &c.]. (Ṣ.)

Also zaforapN (Ḳ, TA) and zuforapN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ,* TA [but not the other words mentioned above, as is implied in the CK,]) The middle (Ṣ, Ḳ) of a thing, (Ḳ,) or of a horse: (Ṣ:) or the chest, or belly: pl. of the former, zafaraAtN. (TA.) One says, Uin-ahu laEaZiymu Alz-uforapi↓ Verily he is great in the middle: (Ṣ, TA:) or in the chest, or belly. (TA.)
One says also, of a camel, or other beast, maA OaXad-a zaforatahu, meaning How strong is the knitting together of his joints! (TA.)
zuforapN: see zaforapN, in four places.
zafiyrN A calamity; a misfortune; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also zufarN↓. (TA.)
zaAfirN One who [carries or] helps to carry loads, or burdens: (TA:) and zawaAfiru [pl. of zaAfirapN↓] female slaves that carry water-skins (Ṣ) or [other] loads, or burdens. (TA.)
See also the next paragraph.

hom.sense: zaAfirapN: see what next precedes.
Also † A bulky camel; (Ḳ;) and so zufarN↓: (Ṣgh, Ḳ:) because he carries loads, or burdens. (TA.)
† The kaAhil [or withers, or upper portion of the back, next the neck,] with what is next to it. (TA.) [Because loads are borne upon it.]

† The side, or angle, (rukon,) of a building, (Ḳ,) upon which it [mainly] rests, or is supported: pl. zawaAfiru. (TA.) [Hence the expression] limajodihimo zawaAfiru ‡ Their glory has props that strengthen it. (A, Ḳ.*)

‡ A man's aiders, or assistants, (Ṣ, TA,) and his kinsfolk, or tribe, syn. EaXiyrap, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) as also zawaAfiru; because they bear his burdens: (A:) his aiders, or assistants, and particular friends. (TA.) You say, humo zaAfiratuhumo Einoda Als-uloTaAni ‡ They are the persons who undertake and perform their business with the Sultán. (Ṣ.) And huwa zaAfiru↓ qawomihi, and zaAfiratuhumo, also, Einoda Als-uloTaAni, ‡ He is the chief of his people, and the bearer of their burdens, with the Sultán. (A.) See also zufarN, in two places.
† A company, or congregated body, (Ḳ,) of men; (TA;) as also zufarN↓. (Ḳ,* TA.)
† An army; or a collected portion thereof; or a troop of horse; syn. katiybapN, as also zufarN↓. (Ḳ.)
‡ [A rib: pl. zawaAfiru.] You say farasN Xadiydu Alz-awaAfiru ‡ A horse having strong ribs. (A.)
‡ A bow: (Ḳ:) pl. zawaAfiru: (A:) so called as being likened to a rib: (TA:) [or perhaps from its sound.]

† The part of an arrow exclusive of the feathers: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or the part exclusive of two thirds, next the head: (ʼEesà Ibn-ʼOmar, Ṣ, Ḳ:) or the part from a little below the head to the head: (ISh:) or about a third part of an arrow, and of a spear. (TA.) [Perhaps so called from its sound.]
Oum-u zaAfirapK The baborap [or female of the babor]. (T in art. Am.)

entry.sense: Oazofaru A horse large in the sides: (Ḳ:) or in the ribs of the sides: or in the chest, or belly: or in the middle: (TA:) pl. zuforN. (Ḳ.)
Alz-aforaMCu, used as a subst., The pudendum; like AlmaEoTaMCu; syn. Als-awoCapu. (IAạr, TA in art. mET.)
muzaf-arN, or muzofarN and muzaf-arapN: see zaforapN, in two places.
mazofuwrN A beast, (Ḳ,) or camel, (TA,) having his joints strongly knit together. (Ḳ, TA.) You say also, huwa mazofuwru Alxaloqi [He is strongly compacted in make]. (TA.)
muzodafarN The part of the breast (juWojuW) of a horse from which the breathing termed zafiyr [see 1] proceeds. (AO, O, Ḳ.)
See also zaforapN, in two places.

Oazofalu [whether with or without tenween is not shown; but accord. to general opinion, a word of this measure, if not an epithet, is perfectly decl., i. e. with tenween;] Anger; and sharpness, or hastiness of temper. (Ḳ.)

OazofalapN A company, or collection, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) of men, and of camels: (TA:) and OazofalaI↓ is like OajofalaI, (Ṣ,) syn. therewith, (Ḳ,) signifying a collection, or an assemblage, of any things. (TA.) One says, jaAWuwA biOazofalatihimo (Fr, Ṣ, TA) and biOajofalatihimo (Fr, TA) They came with their company. (Fr, Ṣ, TA.) And jaMWuwA OazofalapF and OajofalapF They came in a company. (Fr, Ṣ and Ḳ * in art. jfl.)
OazofalaI: see the next preceding paragraph.
Uizofal-apN i. q. xif-apN [Lightness, levity,, &c.]: (Sb, Ṣ, Ḳ:) so in the saying, Oaxacotuhu Uizofal-apN [Lightness, or levity,, &c., seized him, or affected him]. (Sb, Ṣ.)

hom.sense: 1. zafanahu, (TA, and Ḥar p. 124,) aor. _i {yazofinu}, (TA,) inf. n. zafonN, (TA, Ḥar,) in its primary acceptation, He pushed, or thrust, or he pushed, or thrust, away, (TA, Ḥar,) vehemently: and he struck [or kicked] with the leg, or hind leg. (Ḥar.) You say, danawotu minohu fazafananiI I approached him, and he pushed me, or thrust me, from him. (TA.) And huwa yazofinu AlmaTiI-a He drives, or urges on, the saddlecamel. (TA.) And Alr-iyHu tazofinu Als-aHaAba and Alt-uraAba [The wind drives along the clouds and the dust]. (TA.) And AlOamowaAju tazofinu Als-afiynapa [The waves drive along the ship]. (TA.) And AlmuHotaDaru yazofinu binafosihi, i. e. [He who is at the point of death] urges on his soul. (TA.)

And zafana, aor. _i {yazofinu}, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ, in the CK _u,) inf. n. zafonN (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb) and zafanaAnN, (TA,) He danced; (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and played, or sported. (TA.) It is said in a trad. of Fátimeh, kaAnato tazofinu liloHasani She used to dance to El-Ḥasan. (TA.)

entry.sense: zafonN: see what next follows.

And Straight and slender palm-branches stripped of their leaves [and cut to certain required lengths], conjoined, one to another, [side by side, by means of split pieces of such branches passing through holes punched in the former,] like the woven mat: (Ḳ:) [of such are made chests for cooking utensils and provisions, &c.:] of the dial. of Azd. (TA.)

zafuwnN, applied to a she-camel, i. q. zabuwnN [That pushes, or thrusts, or that pushes, or thrusts, away, or that kicks, or strikes, and pushes,, &c., her milker with her hind leg, or with her stiflejoint; or that is wont, or accustomed, to do so]: or lame; as also zaAfinapN↓; (Ḳ;) as though she danced in her gait, in consequence of lameness. (TA.)

zaf-aAnN A dancer: [whence] one says, AlS-uwfiy-apu zaf-aAnapN jaf-aAnapN The Soofees are dancers, providers of food with their jafanaAt [or bowls, which many of them, leading a mendicant-life, as darweeshes, are in the habit of always carrying with them]. (TA.)
zaAfinapN: see zafuwnN.
Also A woman that suffices her man, or husband, in respect of the means of jimaAE. (Ḳ.)
ziyafonN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and ziyfan-N (Ḳ) Tall; (Ḳ;) and strong; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and some add, light, or active. (TA.) [In one copy of the Ṣ, I find it written zayofan; which its measure in poetry shows to be wrong.]

zayozafuwnN, applied to a she-camel, Swift, (Ḳ,) and light, or active: IJ says that it is app. of the measure fayofaEuwlN, from Alz-afonu [as meaning “the act of dancing”]; or it may be a quadriliteral-radical word: IB says that dayodabuwnN [which see in art. ddn] is similar to it. (TA.)
Also, applied to a bow, That makes a sound, or sounds, in consequence of being put in motion: and in this sense it is said by IJ to be of the measure fayofaEuwlN, from Alz-afonu. (TA.)
rajulN fiyhi Uizofan-apN A man in whom is motion, or commotion: and rajulN Uizofan-apN A man in a state of motion, or commotion: mentioned by Sb, and expl. by Seer. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. zaq-a faroxahu, said of a bird, aor. _u {yazoququ}, (Ṣ, M, Mṣb,) inf. n. zaq-N; (M, Mṣb, Ḳ;) and zaqozaqahu↓, (IDrd, M,) inf. n. zaqozaqapN; (Ḳ;) It fed its young one (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) with its mouth [or bill]; (Ṣ, M;*) it ejected food [from its bill] into the mouth of its young one. (IDrd, TA.)
[Hence,] one says, maA zilotu Oazuq-uhu biAlEilomi ‡ [I ceased not to instil into him, or to nourish him with, knowledge, or science]. (TA.)

zaq-a bisaloHihi, mostly said of a bird, (M,) or zaq-a bicaroqihi, said of a bird, (TA,) aor. as above, (M,) and so the inf. n.; (M, Ḳ, TA;) and zaqozaqa↓, (M, TA,) [bisaloHihi or] bicaroqihi, (TA,) inf. n. zaqozaqapN; (Ḳ;) He cast forth his excrement; (M;) it (a bird) muted, or dunged. (M, Ḳ, TA.)

entry.sense: 2. zq-q, (M, TA,) inf. n. tazoqiyqN, (Ṣ, TA,) He stripped off a hide, or skin, by commencing from the head, (Ṣ, M, TA,) in order to make of it a ziq- [q. v.]. (M, TA.) The doing thus is different from the mode now practised. (Ṣ.)
R. Q. 1. zaqozaqa, inf. n. zaqozaqapN: see 1, above, in two places.

[As inf. n. of the same verb,] zaqozaqapN also signifies A bird's uttering its cry, or voice, at dawn: (Lth. Ḳ:) or it is a word imitative of the cry, or voice, of the bird; (M, TA;) and he who thus explains it does not restrict it by adding “at dawn.” (TA.)
Also [as an onomatopæia] A weak laughing. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ.)
And The being light, or active, (Ḳ, and Ḥar p. 375,) and quick. (Ḥar ibid.)
Also a word of the dial. of Kelb, app. meaning The being quick in speech, (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ, TA,) and making one part thereof to follow close upon another. (Ibn-ʼAbbád, TA.)
And The dancing a child; (Lth, Ṣ, M, Ḳ;) as also ziqozaAqN, [which is likewise an inf. n. of the same verb,] (Lth, M, Ḳ,) with kesr. (Ḳ.)
zuq-N one of the names of Wine: (Moḥeeṭ, Ḳ:*) pl., as in the Moḥeeṭ, ziqaqapN; but accord. to the Ḳ, zaqaqapN. (TA.)

ziq-N [A skin for holding wine, &c.:] any receptacle, consisting of a skin, that is used for wine and the like: or, as some say, not thus called unless it be stripped off from the part next the animal's neck: or, accord. to AḤn, one in which wine is conveyed: (M:) or a skin for water or milk; syn. siqaMCN: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or a skin of which the hair is clipped, not plucked out, (Lth, Ḳ,) for wine and the like, (Lth,) or for wine, &c.: (Ḳ:) or a receptacle, (ZarofN, Mṣb, and Ḥar p. 335,) of skin, in which are put clarified butter and vinegar and wine: (Ḥar ibid.:) or, as some say, a Zarof smeared with zifot: (Mṣb:) AḤát says that it is such as is smeared with zifot or with qiyr: (TA:) pl. (of pauc., Ṣ) OazoqaAqN (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ) and Oazuq-N, mentioned by El-Hejeree, (M,) and (of mult., Ṣ) ziqaAqN (Ṣ, M, Ḳ) and zuq-aAnN [in the CK erroneously written ruq-AqN]. (Ṣ, M, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA.)
zuq-apN A certain small bird; (Ḳ;) a certain aquatic bird, that remains still until it is almost seized, and then dives, and comes forth far off: pl. zuqaqN. (M.)
zaqaAqN: see zaq-aAqN.

zuqaAqN A sik-ap [meaning street]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or [rather a by-street, or lane;] a narrow Tariyq [here meaning street], (M,) less than a sik-ap, (M, Mgh, Mṣb,) whether a thoroughfare or not: (Mgh, Mṣb:) masc. (Ṣ, Mṣb) and fem.: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) Akh says that the people of El-Ḥijáz make AlT-ariyqu and AlS-iraATu (Ṣ, Mṣb) and Als-abiylu (Ṣ) and Als-uwqu and Alz-uqaAqu (Ṣ, Mṣb) and Alkal-aMCu, which is the market of El-Basrah, (Ṣ,) fem.; and Temeem make them masc., (Ṣ, Mṣb,) i. e. all of these: (Ṣ:) pl. [of pauc., but also used as a pl. of mult.,] Oaziq-apN (Ṣ, M, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and [of mult.] zuq-aAnN. (Sb, Ṣ, M, Ḳ.) mano hadaIzuqaAqFA, occurring in a trad., means He who has guided the erring and the blind to his way. (TA.)
[Hence,] Alz-uqaAqu [The strait of Gibraltar;] the passage of the sea between Tanjeh and El-Jezeereh el-Khad- rà, in the west, (Ḳ, TA,) by El-Andalus; called zuqaAqu sabotapa. (TA.)

hom.sense: zaq-aAqN The maker of the [kind of skin called] ziq-. (TA.)

Also, as in the copies of the Moḥeeṭ and the A [and in the JK], or zaqaAqN↓, like saHaAbN, accord. to the Ḳ, but the former is probably the right, (TA,) One who drinks water (Moḥeeṭ, A, Ḳ) at the table, (Moḥeeṭ, Ḳ,) while having food in his mouth. (Moḥeeṭ, A, Ḳ.) [As shown in the A, it is an epithet applied to a greedy man.]

entry.sense: zaqozaAqapN Light, or active, in her walk; (Ḳ, TA;) applied to a woman. (TA.)
muzaq-aqN A ram skinned from his head to his hind leg; (Lḥ, TA;) as also mazoquwqN↓: (Lḥ, Ḳ, TA:) contr. of muraj-alN (TA) and of marojuwlN. (Ḳ, TA.)
And A skin of which the hair is clipped, not cut off. (Ḳ, TA.)
And hence, as being like such a skin, † A head of which all the hair is cut off. (Ḳ,* TA.) And † A man having all the hair of his head cut off. (TA.)
muzaq-aqapN A large she-camel: (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ:) or a she-camel whose skin is filled with fat after her fleshiness. (En-Naḍr, TA.)
mazoquwqN: see the next preceding paragraph.
muzaqozaqN Any work that is accomplished quickly. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. zaqabahu fiI juHorihi, (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ,*) and fiI Alkuw-api, (TA,) He made him (a field-rat, Ṣ, TA) to enter [into his hole, and into the aperture in a wall]. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)
See also 7.

entry.sense: 2. zq-b, (AZ, TA,) inf. n. tazoqiybN, (AZ, Ḳ, TA,) He (the bird called muk-aMC) sent forth his voice, or cry. (AZ, Ḳ.)

7. Anzqb He entered (T, Ṣ, Ḳ) into his hole, (JK, Ṣ, Ḳ,) said of a field-rat; (JK, Ṣ;) as also zaqaba↓; (Ḳ;) or into a thing; as also Anzbq: (T, TA:) or he entered into it and concealed himself. (IḲṭṭ, TA in art. nms.)

zaqabN, (Ḳ,) and TariyqN zaqabN, (Lḥ, Ṣ,) [in which the latter word may be either a substitute for the former or an epithet,] A narrow road or way: (Lḥ, Ṣ, Ḳ:) pl. zuqubN: (TA:) and n. un. with p {zaqabapN}; or this and the pl. are alike. (Ḳ, TA.) The phrase maTaAribN zaqabN occurs in a verse of Aboo-Dhu-eyb cited voce maTorabN; [the former word being with tenween for the sake of the measure;] or, as some relate it, zuqubN: (Ṣ, TA:) in this instance, zqb is a substitute for mTArb: or, accord. to AʼObeyd, mTArb signifies narrow roads or ways, and zqb signifies narrow: (TA:) or TariyqN zaqabN signifies an obscure narrow road or way. (JK.)
One says also, ramayotuhu mino zaqabK, meaning I threw, or shot, at him, or it, from a near spot. (JK, Ḳ.)

1. zaqomN is syn. with laqomN [The act of gobbling a thing; i. e. eating it quickly, and hastily; or drawing it with the mouth, and eating it quickly: or swallowing it: (see also 5 and 8:)]: (AA, Ḳ, TA:) or laqomN XadiydN [vehement gobbling;, &c.]: (TA:) you say, zaqamahu, aor. _u {yazoqumu}, inf. n. zaqomN, meaning laqimahu [He gobbled it;, &c.]. (TḲ.)
[And particularly] The eating what is termed Alz-aq-uwm, as meaning a certain food in which are dates and fresh butter: (Ṣ:) [or so zaqomu zaq-uwmK; for] you say, zq-m↓, inf. n. tazoqiymN, he ate Alz-aq-uwm; as also zaqamahu, inf. n. zaqomN. (TA.)

hom.sense: 2: see above {1}.
[Freytag explains it as signifying He gave a person a thing to eat; but without indicating his authority.]

entry.sense: 4. Azqmhu AlX-aIoCa He made him to swallow the thing. (Ṣ, Ḳ.*)

5. tazaq-umN is syn. with talaq-umN [The swallowing a thing in a leisurely manner]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) [or simply the swallowing a thing: for] you say, tzq-m All-uqomapa [He swallowed in a leisurely manner the gobbet, or morsel, or mouthful: or simply] he swallowed the gobbet. (TA. [See also 1 and 8.])

Also The drinking milk much, or abundantly: and the subst. is zqm [app. zaqomN↓, as it is written without any syll. signs; meaning, I suppose, A copious draught of milk]. (TA.) Accord. to IDrd, one says, tzq-m fulaAnN All-abana, meaning Such a one drank immoderately of the milk; or drank the milk immoderately. (Ṣ, TA.)
8. Aizodaqamahu He swallowed it. (Ṣ, Ḳ. [See also 1 and 5.])
zaqomN: see 5.
zaqomapN Plague, or pestilence; syn. TaAEuwnN. (Th, Ḳ.) One says, ramaAhu Qll-ehu biAlz-aqomapi [God smote him, or may God smite him, with the plague, or pestilence]. (TḲ.)
zaq-uwmN Fresh butter with dates; (M, Ḳ;) in the dial. of Ifreekeeyeh: (M, TA:) or a certain food of the Arabs, in which are dates and fresh butter. (Ṣ.)
Also Any deadly food. (Th, TA.)

The food of the people of the fire [of Hell]. (ISd, Ḳ.) A certain tree in Hell: (Ḳ:) [respecting which] I’Ab says that when the saying [in the Ḳur xliv. 43 and 44] Uin-a Xjarapa Qlz-aq-uwmi TaEaAmu QloOaviymi [Verily the tree of Alz-aq-uwm shall be the food of the sinner] was revealed, Aboo-Jahl said, “Dates and fresh butter: we will swallow it leisurely:” therefore God revealed [these other words of the Ḳur, xxxvii. 62 and 63,] Uin-ahaA XajarapN taxoruju fiI OaSoli QlojaHiymi TaloEuhaA kaOan-ahu ruWuwsu QlX-ayaATiyni [Verily it is a tree coming forth in the bottom of Hell, the fruit thereof being as though it were the heads of the devils, or of terrible serpents, foul in aspect, having manes, as expl. by Bḍ]: (Ṣ:) it is thus called after a tree of which a description here follows. (Bḍ in xxxvii. 60.)

A certain tree having small leaves, stinking (dafirap), and bitter, found in Tihámeh: (Bḍ ubi suprà:) AḤn says, (Ṣ, TA, [but this passage is only in one of my two copies of the Ṣ,]) on the authority of an Arab of the desert, of Azd es-Saráh, that the zaq-uwm is a dust-coloured tree, (Ṣ, TA,) having small round leaves, without thorns, (TA,) having a pungent odour (cafirap [perhaps a mistranscription for dafirap i. e. stinking]), and bitter, having knots in its stems, (Ṣ, TA,) many in number, and a small and very weak flower, which the bees eat, or lick, for making honey; (Ṣ, TA;) its flower is white; and the heads of its leaves are very foul, or ugly: (Ṣ,* TA:) [or] a certain plant in the desert (AlbaAdiyap), having a flower resembling in form the jasmine. (Ḳ.)

Also A certain tree in Areehà [i. e. Jericho], of [the district called] the Ghowr, having a fruit like the date, sweet, with an astringent and bitter quality; the stone of which has an oil greatly esteemed for its beneficial properties, wonderful of operation in dispersing the cold kinds of flatus, and phlegmatic disorders, and pains of the joints, and gout in the foot (niqoris), and sciatica, and the flatus that is confined in the socket of the hip: the weight of seven drachms thereof is drunk three days or five days; and sometimes, or often, it makes to rise and stand the crippled and those who are deprived of the power of motion: it is said that its original was the [species of] Uiholiylaj [or myrobalan] called kaAbuliI-, which the Benoo-Umeiyeh removed (from India, TA), and planted in Areehà; and when it had long remained, the soil of Areehà altered it from the natural character of the Ahlylj. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. zakaOahu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yazokaOu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. zakoCN, (Ṣ,) He paid it in ready money, quickly, or promptly; or was quick, or prompt, in doing so. (ISk, Ṣ.) [The verb is doubly trans. in this sense:] you say, zakaOahu OalofFA He paid him a thousand (meaning a thousand dirhems, TA) in ready money, quickly, or promptly. (Ḳ, TA.) And zakaOotuhu Haq-ahu, inf. n. as above, I paid him his due; as also nakaOotuhu Hq-h, inf. n. nakoCN. (ISh, TA)

And zakaOati Aln-aAqapu biwaladihaA, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (Ṣ,) The she-camel cast forth her young one at her hind legs, or hind feet, (Ṣ, and so in some copies of the Ḳ,) or at her hind leg, or hind foot: (so in other copies of the Ḳ:) or, in labour, cast forth her young one. (T, TA.) And one says also, qabaHa Qll-ehu Oum-FA zakaOato bihi, and lakaOotu bh, i. e. [May God remove from good, or prosperity, a mother that cast him forth from her womb, or] that brought him forth. (TA.)

And zakaOahu, aor. as above, (Ḳ,) and so the inf. n., (TA,) He beat him, or struck him. (Ḳ.) So in the phrase zakaOahu miAYapa sawoTK; [He beat him, or struck him, with a hundred stripes of the whip]. (TA.)
And zakaOa jaAriyatahu; He compressed his young woman, or female slave. (Ḳ.)
zakaOa Uilayohi He had recourse to him, or it, for refuge, protection, preservation, concealment, covert, or lodging; he leaned, or stayed himself, upon him, or it. (AZ, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 8. AizodakaOa minohu Haq-ahu He took, or received, from him his due; (Ḳ;) as also AntkO. (TA.)
zukaON: see what next follows, in two places.

zajulN zukaOapN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and zukaON↓, (Ḳ,) and maliIoCN zukaOapN (Ṣ) and zukaON↓, (TA,) and zukaMCu↓ Aln-aqodi, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) A wealthy man, quick, or prompt, in paying: (Ṣ,* Ḳ:) [or rather this is the meaning when you combine the two epithets mlIC and zkOp or zkO: otherwise the meaning is only a man quick, or prompt, in paying: for] you say, latajidan-ahu zukaOapF nukaOapF meaning Thou wilt assuredly find him to be one who pays what he owes (TA) without putting off. (Ḳ in art. nkO.)
zukaMCu Aln-aqodi: see the next preceding paragraph.

mazokaON A refuge; an asylum; a place to which one has recourse for refuge, protection, preservation, concealment, covert, or lodging: [and applied to a man:] a poet says, speaking of Bishr Ibn-Marwán,
waniEoma mazokaOu mano DaAqato macaAhibuhu
[And excellent, or most excellent, is the refuge of him whose ways have become strait]. (TA.)
1. zakara, (A, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yazokuru}, (TḲ,) inf. n. zakorN; (TA;) and zk-r↓, (Ḳ,) inf. n. tazokiyrN; (TA;) ‡ He filled (A, Ḳ) a vessel, (TA,) or a water-skin. (A.)
2: see 1:
and 5.
5. tzk-r ‡ It (a child's belly) became large, (Ḳ,) or full, (Ṣ, A,) so that it was like a zukorap, (A,) and in good condition; (Ḳ;) as also zk-r↓, inf. n. tazokiyrN. (Ḳ.)
† It (beverage, or wine,) became collected (Ḳ) in a zukorap. (TA.)
zukorapN A certain small receptacle; (Mṣb;) a receptacle of skin, (A,) or a skin, (Ḳ,) or a small skin, (Ṣ, Mgh,) for wine, (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Ḳ,) or for vinegar: (Ḳ:) pl. zukarN. (Mṣb.)

hom.sense: 1. zakama, (Ḳ,) inf. n. zakomN, (TA,) He filled a water-skin: (Ḳ, TA:) and zakobN signifies the same as zakomN, i. e. the act of filling: this is the primary meaning. (TA.)
See also 4.
zakama binuTofatihi ‡ He emitted his sperma genitale (M, A, Ḳ) like the discharge of mucus from the nose of the mazokuwm. (A.)

zakamato bihi Oum-uhu † His mother brought him forth [in an absolute sense (as in a saying here following), or], accord. to IAạr, easily. (TA.) One says, laEana Qll-ehu Oum-FA zakamato bihi † [May God curse a mother that brought him forth]. (TA.)
zukima He (a man, Ṣ) was, or became, affected with zukaAm: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) [it is app. from zakamahu; but is thought to be] from Oazokamahu, q. v.; [and therefore] anomalous. (Mṣb.)

entry.sense: [2. zak-amahu is said by Golius to be syn. with Oazokamahu. But the only mention of zk-m that I find is in art. zkn in the Ṣ, where it is said that zk-n Ealayohi and zk-m signify Xab-aha Ealayohi, and lab-asa.]
4. Azkmhu He (God, Ṣ, Mṣb) caused him (a man, Ṣ) to be affected with zukaAm; (AZ, Aṣ, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also zakamahu↓. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: zakomapN: see zukaAmN.

Also † Progeny: so says IAạr: or, accord. to Yaạḳoob, it is zukomapN↓. (TA.) One says, huwa OaloOamu zakomapi sawoCK [or zukomapi↓, i. e. He is the basest, most ignoble, or meanest, of evil progeny; or] meaning that he is not a good son. (TA.)
Also The moaning, or hard breathing, (zaHorap,) with which the child comes forth; as also [zaHomapN and] zajomapN. (Ḳ,* TA.)
zukomapN: see zukaAmN.
Also ‡ The last of the children of his two parents. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.) You say, huwa zukomapu Oabawayohi He is the last of the children of his two parents. (Ṣ, TA.)
See also zakomapN, in two places.
Also ‡ Heavy, and coarse, rough, or rude. (Ḳ, TA.)

entry.sense: zukaAmN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and zakomapN↓, (Ḳ,) or zukomapN↓, with damm, (Mṣb,) [A coryza, or catarrhus ad nares; a rheum, in the most usual sense of the term, meaning a defluxion from the head, chiefly from the nose; commonly called a cold in the head;] a defluxion of redundant humour from the two anterior venters of the brain to the nostrils: (Ḳ:) well known: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) from zakomN meaning the act of “filling.” (TA.)
mazokuwmN [pass. part. n. of zakama]. You say qirobapN mazokuwmapN A filled water-skin. (TA.)

And, applied to a man, (AZ, Aṣ, Ṣ,) Affected with zukaAm: (AZ, Aṣ, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) [regularly formed from zakamahu or zukima; but thought to be] from Oazokamahu; (AZ, Aṣ, Ṣ, Mṣb;) [and therefore] anomalous. (Mṣb.)

1. zakaA, aor. yazokuw, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) inf. n. zakaMCN, (Ṣ,) or zukuw-N, (Mṣb, [accord. to which the former seems to be a simple subst.,]) or both, (Ḳ, TA,) the latter like Euluw-N, as in the M, but accord. to [some of] the copies of the Ḳ zakowN, (TA,) It increased, or augmented; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA;) it received increase and blessing from God; it throve by the blessing of God; (Er-Rághib, TA;) and produced fruit; (TA in art. zkI;) and zakiIa, (Ḳ in that art.,) aor. yazokaI, inf. n. zakaApN, (TA in that art.,) signifies the same, (Ḳ, TA,) mentioned by ISd, on the authority of Lḥ, as a dial. var. of zakaA, aor. yzkw; (TA;) and so AzkI↓; (Mṣb, Ḳ;) and tzk-I↓: (Ḳ in art. zkI:) it is said of seed-produce, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Er-Rághib, TA,) and of wealth, or cattle, &c., and of other things: of anything that increases, or augments, one says yazokuw, inf. n. zakaMCN. (TA.) [This is the primary meaning: or, accord. to some, the primary meaning is, It was, or became, pure:] some say that the root denotes purity: and some, that it denotes a state of increase, or augmentation. (Mgh.) You say also zakati AlOaroDu The land throve, or yielded increase. (Mṣb.) And zakaA AlgulaAmu [The boy grew, or throve], inf. n. zukuw-N and zakaMCN, on the authority of Akh. (Ṣ.) And zakaA Eamaluhu † [His deed, or work, throve]. (Ḳ in art. dr.) It is said in a trad. of ʼAlee, AlmaAlu tanoquSuhu Aln-afaqapu waAlEilomu yazokuw EalaI AlUinofaAqi † [Wealth, what one expends diminishes it, but knowledge increases by expending]: zakaMC being thus predicated of knowledge, though this is not a corporeal thing. (TA.) Accord. to El-Umawee, (Ṣ,) said of a man, zakaA, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. yazokuw, inf. n. zukuw-N, (Ṣ,) means He enjoyed, or led, a plentiful, and a pleasant or an easy, and a soft or delicate, life; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) was in a state of abundance of the goods, conveniences, or comforts, of life. (Ṣ.) And likewise said of a man, (having the same aor. and inf. n., TA,) it means also He was, or became, good, or righteous; (Jel in xxiv. 21, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA;) and pure from sin. (Jel ibid.) [Hence,] hecaA AlOamoru laA yazokuw bifulaAnK means This thing, or affair, will not be suitable to such a one; will not befit him. (Ṣ.)

hom.sense: 2. zk-Ahu, inf. n. tazokiyapN: see 4.

Also He purified him, or it. (Er-Rághib, TA.) Sometimes the agent of the verb in this sense is a man; as in the saying in the Ḳur [xci. 9], qado OafolaHa mano zak-aAhaA [Verily he prospereth who purifieth it; namely, his soul]: sometimes it is God; as in [the saying in the Ḳur xxiv. 21,] walekin-a Qll-eha yuzak-iI mano yaXaMCu [But God purifieth whom He willeth]: and sometimes it is the Prophet; as in the saying [in the Ḳur ix. 104], xuco mino OamowaAlihimo SadaqapF tuTah-iruhumo watuzak-iyhimo bihaA [Take thou, from their possessions, a poor-rate, whereby thou shalt cleanse them and purify them; where (J says in the Ṣ) they say that tuzak-iyhimo means the same as tuTah-iruhumo]; and in the saying [in the Ḳur ii. 146], yatoluw Ealayokumo MyaAtinaA wayuzak-iykumo [Who reciteth to you our signs, and purifieth you]. (Er-Rághib, TA.)

[Hence, accord. to what is said in the Ḳur ix. 104, i. e. because the act which it signifies is believed to purify the performer, or because it is believed to purify, or to occasion an increase of, the rest of his property,] zk-I maAlahu, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) inf. n. as above, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) He gave the zakaAp [or poorrate] from his property. (Ṣ, Mgh.) And zk-Ahu, (Ṣ,) or zk-Ahumo, (Mgh,) He took (Ṣ, Mgh) his, (Ṣ,) or their, (Mgh,) zakaAp [or poor-rate]. (Ṣ, Mgh.)

zak-ayotuhu also signifies I attributed to him zakaMC, i. e. [purity, or] goodness, or righteousness. (Mṣb.) [And hence, I praised him.] And zk-I nafosahu, (Ṣ, Mgh,) inf. n. as above, (Ṣ,) He praised himself. (Ṣ, Mgh.) The doing this is forbidden in the Ḳur liii. 33. (Er-Rághib, TA.) Hence, also, tazokiyapu AlX-uhuwdi The pronouncing the witnesses to be veracious, and good, or righteous. (Mgh.)

huwa yuxas-iI wayuzak-iI He plays, and says, “Is it even or odd [or rather odd or even]?” (TA in art. xsw;) he takes, or holds, something in his hand, and says, “Is it even or odd [or odd or even]?” (TA in the present art.) [See zakaA below.]

4. AzkAhu He (God) made it to increase, or augment; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) [made it to thrive; and put it into a good, or right, state, or condition;] namely, seed-produce, (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA,) and wealth, or cattle, &c., and any other thing capable of increase; (TA;) as also zk-Ahu↓, (Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) inf. n. tazokiyapN. (TA.)
Also He put it into a bag, or some other receptacle; namely, property: thus expl. by Aboo-Moosà. (Nh, TA.)
See also 1, first sentence.

entry.sense: 5. tzk-I: see 1, first sentence.
Also He became purified; or he purified himself: (TA:) also pronounced Aiz-ak-aI, aor. yaz-ak-aI. (Bḍ in xxxv. 19.)
And He endeavoured to attain much piety; from Alz-akaMCu. (Bḍ in lxxxvii. 14.)
And He gave the poor-rate. (Ṣ.)

zakaA, (Ṣ, Ḳ,* TA,) without tenween, and accord. to some with tenween, and not having the article Al prefixed to it; and in like manner xasaA, which is coupled with the former, is without tenween, and accord. to some with tenween, and not having the article Al prefixed to it; (TA;) [but each has Al prefixed to it in the Ḳ;] i. q. AlX-afoEu (Ṣ, Ḳ) mina AlEadadi (Ḳ) [or XafoEN, as meaning An even number; a number consisting of pairs; or a single pair]: said to be so called because the pair are more, or more perfect, or better, (OazokaI↓,) than is the one. (TA.) You say xasaA Oawo zakaA or xasFA Oawo zakFA [Odd or even?]. (TA.) [See more voce xasaA.]

zakaApN, or zakewpN, [accord. to El-Ḥareeree, to be written with A when prefixed to a pronoun, and also in the dual number, (see De Sacy's Anthol. Gram. Arabe, p. 67 of the Arabic text,) but this rule I have not found to be generally observed, even in the best MSS., nor have I in the similar cases of SalewpN and HayewpN, (to which it is also applied,) in the best copies of the Ḳur-án,] of the measure faEalapN, [i. e., originally zakawapN,] like SadaqapN [which is one of its syns.]; a noun of the class of homonyms: (IAth, TA:) it signifies Increase, or augmentation, (IAth, Er-Rághib, TA,) as also zakaMCN↓ [mentioned in the first paragraph as an inf. n.], (Mṣb,) resulting from the blessing of God; and this is [said to be] the primary meaning; and is considered as relating to the things of the present world and to those of the world to come. (Er-Rághib, TA.)
And Purity. (IAth, TA.) And [particularly] The dryness of the earth or ground; which is its purity from defilement. (TA.)

And Purification: a meaning which it is said to have in the saying in the Ḳur [xxiii. 4], waQl-aciyna humo lilz-akewpi faAEiluwna, (IAth, Mgh, Er-Rághib, TA,) i. e. And who are acting in their religious service for God's purification of them; or for their purification of themselves: for lilz-akewp is not here an objective complement of faAEiluwna; the l therein denoting the aim and the cause. (Er-Rághib, TA.)

Also, [as being a mode of purification of oneself,] Good, or righteous, conduct: and in this sense it has been expl. as used in the Ḳur xviii. 80: or as meaning goodness, or righteousness: (TA:) which zakaMCN↓ [also] signifies. (Mṣb.) And Religious service; as being the means of purification: so [accord. to some] it signifies in the saying [in the Ḳur xix. 14], waHanaAnFA mino ladun-aA wazakewpF [And the disposition to mercy, or compassion, from us, and religious service]: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or it here means Tuhorap [i. e. purification, or purity]:
and [accord. to some, if we except the instances mentioned above in the next two preceding sentences,] this is the only instance in the Ḳur-án in which it is used in any other sense than that which next follows. (Kull p. 199.)

And [The poor-rate;] the portion, or amount, of property, that is given therefrom, (M, IAth, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ, Er-Rághib, TA,) as the due of God, (Er-Rághib, TA,) by its possessor, (M, Ḳ, TA,) to the poor, (M, Mgh, Er-Rághib, TA,) in order that he may purify it thereby: (M, IAth, Ḳ, TA:) [in the Ṣ it is merely said that “the zakewp of property is well known:” the giving it is obligatory, provided that the property is of a certain amount, and has been in possession eleven months: the portion given varies according to the nature and amount of the property; but is generally a fortieth part thereof, or of its value; i. e. two and a half per cent.:] it is thus termed [for the reason assigned above; or] as being a cause of the hope of increase, (Mṣb, Er-Rághib, TA,) or as causing the soul, or person, to thrive, or grow, by means of good things and blessings [procured thereby], or for both of these reasons. (Er-Rághib, TA.) zakaApu AlfiTori [The alms of the breaking of the fast, given at the end of Ramadán,] is obligatory upon every person of the Muslims, the free and the slave, the male and the female, the young and the old, the poor and the rich; and purifies the faster from unprofitable and lewd discourse: it consists of a SaAE [q. v.] of dates, or of barley, [or of raisins or some other ordinary kind of food,] or half that quantity of wheat. (El-Jámiʼ eṣ-Ṣagheer, voce zakaAp.) [The pl. is zakawaAtN.]
Also, [as being an attribution of purity or goodness or righteousness,] Praise. (IAth, TA.)
And The pure, or best, part of a thing: (Ḳ, TA:) on the authority of Aboo-ʼAlee. (TA.)
zakaMCN an inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) See also the next preceding paragraph, in two places.
Also [The increase of the earth; or] the fruits caused to come forth by God. (TA.)
zakiI-N i. q. zaAkK↓, (Akh, Ṣ,) which signifies Increasing [&c., as act part. n. of zakaA, q. v.]: (Ḥam p. 722:) [and growing, or thriving]: applied in this sense to a boy. (Akh, Ṣ.)

gulaAmFA zakiy-FA in the Ḳur xix. 19 means [A boy] pure from sins: or growing, or increasing, in goodness and righteousness: (Bḍ:) or purified by nature: or such as shall in the future become purified. (TA.) And nafosFA zakiy-apF in the Ḳur xviii. 73 means [A soul, or person,] pure from sins: some read zaAkiyapF↓; but the former is more forcible: [or,] accord. to AA, ↓the latter means that has never sinned: and the former, that has sinned and then been forgiven. (Bḍ.) [Or] rajulN zakiI-N signifies A good, or righteous, man: and the pl. is OazokiyaMCu. (Mṣb, Ḳ,* TA.) And also A man enjoying, or leading, a plentiful, and a pleasant or an easy, and a soft or delicate, life: pl. as above. (Ḳ, TA.)
And OaroDN zakiy-apN Good, fat land. (TA in art zkI.)

zakawiI-N [generally meaning Of, or relating to, the poor-rate] is the rel. n. of zakaApN; like as HaSawiI-N is that of HaSaApN; because the rel. n. reduces the word to its original form: zakaAYiI-N is vulgar and wrong. (Mṣb.)

OazokaI More, or most, profitable: (Bḍ in ii. 232:) or better, or best: (Jel ibid:) more, or most, pure: (Bḍ in xxiv. 28:) more, or most, lawful, (Bḍ and Jel in xviii. 18,) and good, or pleasant: or more, or most, abundant and cheap. (Bḍ ibid.) See also zakaA as a noun.

hom.sense: 1. zakiIa, (Ḳ,) aor. yazokaI, inf. n. zakaApN, i. q. zakaA, aor. yazokuw, as meaning It increased, or augmented; (Lḥ, ISd, Ḳ,* TA;) and produced fruit: (TA:) and tzk-I↓ signifies the same. (Ḳ.)
Also He thirsted. (Th, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 5: see above {1}; and see art. zkw.
zakiI-N: see art. zkw.

hom.sense: 1. zalalota, [third pers. zal-a,] aor. tazil-u; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and zalilota, [third pers. likewise zal-a,] aor. tazal-u; (Fr, Ṣ, Ḳ;) inf. n. zaliylN, (Lḥ, Ṣ, Ḳ,) which is of the former verb, (Ṣ,) and zal-N, (Lḥ, Ḳ,) also of the former verb, (Mṣb,) and zuluwlN and zil-iylaI [or, accord. to the Ṣ, this is a simple subst.,] and zil-iylaMCu (Lḥ, Ḳ) and mazil-apN, (Ḳ,) [all app. of the former verb,] and zalalN, (Fr, Ṣ, Ḳ,) which is of the latter verb; (Fr, Ṣ;) Thou slippedst (Ḳ) in mud, or in speech, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or in judgment, or opinion, or in religion: (TA:) or you say, zal-a Eano makaAnihi, aor. yazil-u, inf. n. zal-N [&c. as above]; and zal-a, aor. yazal-u, inf. n. zalalN; the former verb of the class of Daraba; and the latter, of the class of taEiba; meaning he, or it, moved away, or aside, [or slipped,] from his, or its, place: and zal-a fiI manoTiqihi, or fiEolihi, aor. yazil-u, like yaDoribu, inf. n. zal-apN, he made a slip, or mistake, in his speech, or his action. (Mṣb.) faUino zalalotumo, in the Ḳur ii. 205, means But if ye turn away, or aside, from entering thereinto fully: (Jel:) this is the common reading: but some read zalilotumo. (TA.) And you say, zal-a zal-apF He committed a slip in speech and the like. (TA.) Accord. to IAth, zaliylN signifies The passing of a body from one place to another: and

hence it is metaphorically used in like manner in relation to a benefit: one says, zal-ato minohu UilaI fulaAnK niEomapN, inf. n. zaliylN, meaning ‡ A benefit passed, or was transferred, from him, (i. e. a benefactor,) to such a one. (TA.)

zal-a, inf. n. zaliylN and zuluwlN, also signifies He (a man) passed along quickly: (ISh, Ḳ:) and zal-a, inf. n. zaliylN, he ran: and zaliylN, a light, or an agile, walking or pacing: (TA:) [and zalalN, mentioned above as an inf. n., seems to have the same, or a similar, signification:] a rájiz says, (Ṣ,) namely, Aboo-Moḥammad El-Hadhlemee, (TA,) or Aboo-Moḥammad El-Fak'asee, (O,)
Uin-a lahaA fiI AlEaAmi ciI Alfutuwqi
wazalali Aln-iy-api waAlt-aSofiyqi
riEoyapa mawolFI naASiHK Xafiyqi , (Ṣ in the present art.,* and in art. Sfq,* and art. ftq, but in this last with rab-K in the place of mawolFI, and TA,) [i. e. Verily they have, in the year of little rain, (thus Alftwq, as here used, is expl. in the Ṣ in art. ftq,) and in the passing along lightly to the place which is the object of the journey, and in the being removed from a tract which they have depastured to a place in which is pasture, (thus AltSfyq, as here used, inis expl. in the Ṣ in art. Sfq,) the tending of a master honest in his conduct, or desirous of their good, benevolent, or compassionate]: he is speaking of his camels: (Ṣ in art. ftq:) he means that they pass along lightly [so I render tazil-u] from place to place in search of herbage: and Alny-p means the place to which they purpose journeying. (Ṣ.)
[Hence,] zal-a Eumuruhu † His life went, or passed, [or glided,] away. (Ḳ, TA.)

zal-ati Ald-araAhimu, (Ṣ, Mṣb,* Ḳ,) aor. _i {yazolilu}, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) inf. n. zuluwlN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or zaliylN, (Mṣb,) The dirhems, or pieces of money, poured out, or forth: (Ḳ:) or were, or became, deficient in weight. (Ṣ, Mṣb,* Ḳ.)

zal-a, inf. n. zalalN, (Ḳ,) said of a man, (TA,) [and app. of a wolf, (see Oazal-u,)] He was, or became, light [of flesh] in the hips, or haunches: (Ḳ:) or zalalN signifies a woman's having little flesh in the posteriors and thighs. (Ṣ.)

zal-a, aor. yazil-u, accord. to analogy, as an intrans. v., from Oazolalotu Uilayohi meaning “I gave to him” of food, &c., should signify He took, or received: and hence the saying of the lawyers, wayazil-u Uino Ealima Alr-iDaI And he shall take, or receive, or the food [if he have knowledge of permission, or consent]. (Mṣb.)
zul-a i. q. duq-iqa [app. as meaning He, or it, was made, or rendered, thin, or slender]. (IAạr, TA.)

entry.sense: 2: see the next paragraph {4}, near its end.

4. Azl-hu, (Ḳ,) inf. n. UizolaAlN, (TA,) He, or it, made him, or caused him, to slip in mud, (Ḳ, TA,) or in speech, or in judgment, or opinion, or in religion; (TA;) and Astzl-hu↓ signifies the same. (Ṣ,* MA, Ḳ,* PṢ. [But respecting this latter, see what follows.]) It is said in the Ḳur [ii. 34], faOazal-ahumaA AlX-ayoTaAnu EanohaA [And the Devil made them, or caused them, both, to slip, or fall, from it, namely, Paradise (Aljan-ap)]; and one reading is OazaAlamuhaA, i. e. removed them: or, as some say, it means caused them to commit a slip, or wrong action, in consequence of it [referring to the tree]: or, accord. to Th, caused them to slip in judgment. (TA.) And in the same, iii. 149, Qsotazal-ahumu↓ AlX-ayoTaAnu The Devil made them, or caused them, to slip: (Jel:) or, as some say, sought to make them commit a slip, or wrong action. (TA.)
One says also, Oazal-a fulaAnFA UilaI Alqawomi He sent forward such a one to the people, or party. (TA.)
And Oazal-ahu Eano raOoyihi He made him to turn from his opinion. (MA.)

And as zaliylN signifies the “passing” of a body from one place to another, one says, speaking metaphorically, (IAth, TA,) Oazal-a Uilayohi niEomapF ‡ He did to him a benefit: (Ṣ, IAth, Ḳ:) whence, (TA,) it is said in a trad., mano Ouzil-ato Uilayohi niEomapN faloyaXokurohaA † He to whom a benefit is done [let him be grateful for it]. (AʼObeyd, Ṣ,* Mgh, Mṣb.) And Oazolalotu lahu zul-apF † I did to him a benefit: one should not say zllt [thus written, app. for zal-alotu↓: but see muzal-ilN]. (TA.) And Oazolalotu Uilayohi [alone] † I gave to him: or I did to him a benefit. (Mṣb.) And Oazolalotu Uilayohi mina AlT-aEaAmi wagayorihi † I gave to him of the food and other things. (IḲṭṭ, TA.) And Oazal-a Uilayohi mino Haq-ihi XayoYFA † He gave to him somewhat of his due. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) And Oazal-a Eanohu niEomapF † He drew forth from him a benefit. (TA.)
10: see 4, in two places.

R. Q. 1. zalozalahu, (Ṣ,* Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) inf. n. zalozalapN and zilozaAlN and zalozaAlN and zulozaAlN, (Ḳ,) or the first of these is an inf. n. [by universal consent], (Ṣ,) and so is the second, but the third is a simple subst., (Zj, Ṣ, Mṣb,) though this and the fourth [which is the least known] have the authority of certain readings of passages of the Ḳur, namely, xcix. 1 for both of these, and xxxiii. 11 for the latter of them, (TA,) He put it, or him, into a state of motion, commotion, or agitation: (Mṣb, Ḳ, TA:) or into a state of convulsion, or violent motion. (Zj, TA.) You say, zalozala Qll-ehu AlOaroDa [i. e. God made the earth to quake: or to quake violently:] (Ṣ:) [or] put the earth into a state of convulsion, or violent motion. (Zj, TA) And jaMCa biAlUibili yuzaloziluhaA He came with, or brought, the camels, driving them with roughness, violence, or vehemence. (TA.) Some say that zalozalapN is from Alz-alalu fiI Alr-aOoIi [i. e. “the making a slip in judgment, or opinion”]: so when one says, zulozila Alqawomu the meaning is, The people, or party, were turned away from the right course, and fear was cast into their hearts. (TA.) It is said in a trad., Aall-ehum-a Qhozimi AlOaHozaAba wazalozilohumo i. e. [O God, rout, defeat, or put to flight, the combined forces, and] make their state of affairs to be unsound, or unsettled. (TA.) Accord. to IAmb, OaSaAbati Alqawoma zalozalapN means An affrighting befell the people, or party; from the saying in the Ḳur [ii. 210], wazuloziluwA Hat-aI yaquwla Alr-asuwlu i. e. And they were affrighted [so that the Apostle said]: (L, TA:) or were vehemently agitated. (Ksh, Bḍ.)

maA zalozalotu qaT-u maMCF Oaborada mino maMCi Alvgwbi [or Alv-agabi, as it is written in the explanation of this saying, the latter being app. the right reading], said by Aboo-Shembel, means I have not put into my throat, or fauces, ever, water slipping into it cooler than the water of the vagab [or pool left by a torrent in the shade of a mountain]. (Az, TA.)

R. Q. 2. tazalozala It was, or became, in a state of motion, commotion, agitation, convulsion, or violent motion. (Mṣb, TA.) You say, tazalozalati AlOaroDu (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA) The earth [quaked: or quaked violently:] was, or became, in a state of motion, commotion,, &c.: (Mṣb:) the verb in this phrase [and in others] is quasi-pass. of R. Q. 1. (Ṣ, TA.) And tazalozalato nafosuhu His soul reciprocated in his chest at death. (TA.)

zul-N Slippery: (Ṣ:) a place in which one slips; (Ḳ;) and zalalN↓ signifies the same; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and zaluwlN↓ [likewise, i. e.] a place in which the foot slips. (TA.) You say maqaAmN zul-N and zalalN↓, and maqaAmapN zul-N and zalalN↓, [A standing-place] in which one slips. (Ḳ.) And zuHoluwqapN zul-N and zalalN↓ A slippery [sloping slide or rolling-place, &c.]. (Ṣ.) [See also mazil-apN.]

zal-apN A slip (Ṣ, Mṣb,* Ḳ) in mud, or in speech; a subst. from 1 meaning as expl. in the first sentence of this art.; (Ṣ, Ḳ:) as also zil-iylaI↓: (Ṣ: [but this latter is mentioned by Lḥ and in the Ḳ as an inf. n.:]) a slip, or lapse; (Ḳ:) a fault, a wrong action, a mistake, or an error; (Mṣb, Ḳ;) or a sin, or crime; (Ḳ,* TA;) a fall into sin or crime. (Mṣb in art. Evr.) One says, zal-a Alr-ajulu zal-apF qabiyHapF The man [made a foul slip; or] fell into the commission of a disapproved, or hateful, or foul, act; or committed an exorbitant, an abominable, or a foul, mistake: whence the trad., naEuwcu biQll-ehi mino zal-api AlEaAlimi [We seek protection by God from the slip of the learned man]: and the well-known saying, zal-apN AlEaAlimi zal-apu AlEaAlami [The slip of the learned man is the slip of the world at large]. (TA.)
A benefit, or good action; (Mgh,* Ḳ;) as also zul-apN↓: (Ḳ:) a gift. (Mṣb.)

A feast, or repast, that is prepared for guests. (Lth, O, Mṣb.) One says, Ait-axaca fulaAnN zal-apF [Such a one made, or prepared, a feast for guests]. (Lth, O, Mṣb.) Hence, (Lth, TA,) it is also a name for Food that is carried from the table of one's friend or relation: a word of the dial. of El-'Irák: (Lth, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or in this sense it is a vulgar word, (Ḳ, TA,) used by the common people of El-'Irák (TA.) And i. q. EurosN [as meaning A marriage-feast]. (ISh, Az, Mṣb, Ḳ.) So in the saying, kun-aA fiI zal-api fulaAnK [We were at the marriage-feast of such a one]. (ISh, Az, Mṣb, TA.)

hom.sense: zul-apN: see zal-apN.
Also A straitened state of the breath [unless Aln-afasi be a mistranscription for Aln-afos the soul, which I think not improbable]. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: zil-apN Stones: or smooth stones: (Ḳ:) pl. zilalN. (TA.)

hom.sense: zalalN an inf. n. of 1, [q. v,] (Fr, Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) in two [or three] senses. (Ḳ.)
See also zul-N, in four places.
Also A deficiency: so in the saying, fiI miyzaAnihi zalalN [In its weight is a deficiency]. (Lḥ, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: zulaAlN A certain animal, of small, white body; which, when it dies, is put into water, and renders it cool, or cold: (TA:) [Golius describes it as a worm that is bred in snow; of which Aristotle speaks in his Hist. Animalium, l. 19; and he adds, on the authority of Dmr, that it is of the length of a finger, generally marked with yellow spots; and swelling in water such as is termed mAC AlzlAl.]
And Clear, as applied to anything. (TA.)
zaluwlN: see zul-N:
and see also zulaAlN.
zaliylN: see zulaAlN.
Also [The kind of sweet food called] faAluwc [q. v.]. (Ṣgh, Ḳ.)

zil-iy-apN, an arabicized word from the Pers. ziyluw, (Ḳ in art. zlI, in the CK zayoluw, [“a sort of woollen blanket,”]) A carpet; syn. bisaATN: (Ḳ in the present art.:) a certain sort of busuT [or carpets, said by Golius to be generally woollen and villous, but by Freytag to be woollen but not villous]: (Mṣb:) [in Johnson's Pers. Arab. and Engl. Dict. expl. as meaning a coverlet of woollen, without a pile, neither striped nor painted:] pl. zalaAliI-N. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
zil-iylaI: see zal-apN.
zalozilN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and zalozalN, and MF adds zulazilN↓, (TA,) Household-goods; or utensils and furniture of a house or tent; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also zalazN. (Sh, TA.)
zulozulN Light, or agile; (TA;) as also Oazal-u↓: (IAạr, TA:) the former applied as an epithet to a boy, or young man. (TA.) [See also zulozuwlN.]
And A skilful player on the drum. (Fr, Ḳ.)
zulazilN: see zalozilN.
zalozalapN: see what next follows.

zalozaAlN [Motion, commotion, agitation, convulsion, or violent motion; and particularly an earthquake, or a violent earthquake;] a subst. from R. Q. 1: (Zj, Ṣ, Mṣb:) or an inf. n. of R. Q. 1, as also zilozaAlN and zulozaAlN and zalozalapN↓ [which last is often used as a simple subst., as such having for its pl. zalaAzilu, and is expl. in Jel xxii. 1 as signifying a violent earthquake]. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: zulozuwlN Light, or active, (Ḳ, TA,) in spirit and body; (TA;) acute, sharp, or quick, in intellect; clever, or ingenious. (Ḳ, TA.) [See also zalozulN.]
Lightness, or activity. (Ḳ.)

Conflict, or fight, and evil condition. (Sh, Ḳ.) One says, tarakotu Alqawoma fiI zulozuwlK waEuloEuwlK (Aṣ, Sh) i. e. [I left the people, or party.] in conflict, or fight, and evil condition. (Sh, TA.)

entry.sense: zalaAzilu [a pl. of which the sing. is not mentioned,] Difficulties; (Ṣ, TA;) and terrors, or causes of fear. (TA.) [See also zalozaAlN.]
zulaAzilN: see zulaAlN, in two places.

zaAl-N Deficient in weight; applied to a dirhem, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) and to a deenár: (TA:) pl. zawaAl-N, (Mṣb,) or zul-alN. (TA.) One says, mino danaAniyrika zil-alN waminohaA wuz-anN [Of thy deenárs are such as are deficient in weight, and of them are such as are of full weight]. (TA.)
Oazal-u Quick, or swift. (IAạr, Ḳ.)
See also zulozulN.

Also Light [of flesh] in the hips, or haunches: (AA, Ṣ, Ḳ:) and having little flesh in the posteriors and thighs; or having small buttocks sticking together; syn. OarosaHu; (M, TA;) in the copies of the Ḳ, erroneously, OaXaj-u: (TA:) or it signifies one who is more than OarosaH; (Ḳ,* TA;) whose waist-wrapper will not retain its hold: (TA:) fem. zal-aMCu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) applied to a woman; i. q. rasoHaMCu: (Ṣ:) or having no buttock: pl. zul-N. (TA.) Als-imoEu AlOazal-u means The wolf that has little flesh in the rump and thighs, (Alc-iYobu AlOarosaHu, Ṣ, in the Ḳ ciYobN OarosaHu,) begotten between the wolf and the she-hyena; (Ṣ, Ḳ; [the words wAlxif-apu wAlqitAlu wAlX-ar-u here immediately following in the CK should be erased; their proper place being in the second of the lines below in that edition, where they are again inserted; as observed by Freytag;]) and this epithet (AlAzl-) is inseparable: (Ṣ:) or, accord. to IAth, AlOazal-u primarily signifies the small in the buttock: and as an epithet applied to the wolf, the light, or active; and it is said to be from zal-a signifying “he ran.” (TA.) It is said in a prov., huwa OasomaEu mina Als-imoEi AlOazal-i [He is more quick of hearing than the smE that is lean in the rump and thighs; or than the light, or active, smE]. (Ṣ, TA.)
qawosN zal-aMCu A bow from which the arrow slips, by reason of the rapidity with which it goes forth. (Ḳ.)

Uizilozilo [said by Freytag to be written in the CK zilozilo, but in my copy of that edition it is Aizilozilo,] is a word uttered on the occasion of the zalozalap, (so in copies of the Ḳ,) or on the occasions of zalaAzil: (so in the TA:) [app. an ejaculation expressive of alarm, or of distress: the Turkish translator of the Ḳ thinks that it is originally Oazulozila, contracted and altered in the vowels for the purpose of alleviating the utterance on account of the straitness of the time:] but IJ says that a word of four radical letters does not receive an augmentative like this as an initial; and holds it to be, as to the letter and the meaning, from AlOazolu [i. e. “straitness, distress,”, &c.], and of the measure fiEiloEilo. (TA.)
mazal-apN: see the next paragraph. [Its primary signification is probably A cause of slipping: compare maboxalapN and majobanapN, &c.]

hom.sense: mazil-apN and mazal-apN↓, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) the former the more chaste, (Mṣb,) the latter mentioned by AA, (TA,) A slippery place; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA;) such as a smooth rock, and the like; and such the SiraAT is said to be. (TA.) [See also zul-N.]
The former is also an inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: muzal-ilN One who bestows many benefits (Ḳ, TA) and gifts. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. zalaja, aor. _i {yazoliju}, inf. n. zalojN and zalajaAnN and zaliyjN; and Anzlj↓; He went a gentle pace: and he walked, or ran, quickly: (L:) or zalojN signifies the being quick in going and in other things: and the going quickly: (TA:) and zalajaAnN, the advancing, or preceding, (O, Ḳ, TA,) quickly, (O,) or in journeying: (TA: [see also zalaxaAnN:]) or, as some say, the going a gentle pace. (TA.) You say of a she-camel, zalajato, aor. _i {yazoliju}, inf. n. zalojN, She went swiftly, [appearing] as though she did not move her legs by reason of her swiftness. (Lth, TA.) And zalajato occurring in a verse of Dhu-r-Rummeh, [app. referring to draughts of water,] is expl. as meaning They descended quickly into the entrance of the gullet, by reason of vehemence of thirst. (TA.) You say also, zalajato rijoluhu His foot slipped; as also zalaxato. (AZ, L and TA in art. zlx.) And mar-a yazoliju, inf. n. zalojN and zaliyjN, He, or it, passed, going lightly upon the ground. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) And, of an arrow, yazoliju EalaI wajohi AlOaroDi [app. It goes along lightly upon the ground]: and yamoDiI maDaMCF zalojFA [app. meaning the same]. (TA.) And zalaja Als-ahomu, aor. _i {yazoliju}, inf. n. zuluwjN and zaliyjN, The arrow fell upon the ground, and did not go straight to the animal at which it was shot. (TA. [See also zalaxa.])
zalaja, aor. _i {yazoliju}, also signifies He escaped from difficulties, troubles, or distresses. (TA.)
And He drank vehemently of anything. (TA.)
See also 4.

entry.sense: 2. zl-j, inf. n. tazoliyjN, He uttered, and made current, his words, or speech, (Ḳ, TA,) and an ode, or an oration. (TA.)
And tazoliyjN signifies also The striving to retain life with a bare sufficiency of the means of subsistence; Alt-azoliyju being expl. by mudaAfaEapu AlEayoXi biAlbulogapi. (Ḳ.)
4. Azlj Als-ahoma He made the arrow to fall upon the ground, and not to go straight to the animal at which it was shot. (TA. [See also 4 in art. zlx.])
Azlj AlbaAba He closed, or made fast, the door with the mizolaAj [q. v.]; (Ṣ,* Ḳ;) as also zalajahu↓, (Ḳ,) inf. n. zalojN. (TA. [See, again, 4 in art. zlj.])

hom.sense: 5. tzl-j He, or it, slipped, or slid along or down; syn. tazal-aqa: (Ṣ, TA:) his foot slipped. (KL. [See also 5 in art. zlx.])
One says of an arrow, yatazal-aju Eani Alqawosi or yanozaliju↓ [It slips from the bow]. (Ṣ and Ḳ, accord. to different copies.)
Also He persevered, or persisted, in drinking the beverage called nabiyc, (Lḥ, Ḳ, TA,) and wine; (Lḥ, TA;) like tsl-j. (TA.)

entry.sense: 7: see 1, first sentence:
and see also 5 and zaluwjN, and mizolaAjN.

hom.sense: zalojN, as an epithet applied to a place, (Ṣ, TA,) Slippery; syn. [zaloqN and] zalaqN; [like zaloxN;] as also zalajN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) and zaliyjN↓. (TA.)
See also zaAlijN.

[Explained by Freytag as meaning “Quod aliquis in jaculando multum tollit manum, ut majori vi mittat telum,” on the authority of Meyd, it is app. a mistranscription for zaloxN, q. v.; or it may be a dial. var. of the latter.]

entry.sense: zalajN: see the next preceding paragraph.
zulujN Smooth rocks; (Ḳ;) because the feet slip from them. (TA.)

zalajaI, like jamazaI [in measure and meaning], and zaliyjapN↓, (Ḳ, TA,) and zaluwjN↓, (TA,) applied to a she-camel, Quick, or swift, (Ḳ, TA,) in pace, or journeying: or, as some say, that quickly finishes in being milked. (TA.)
zilaAjN: see mizolaAjN.
zaluwjN Quick, or swift; (Ḳ;) as also zaAlijN↓, applied to anything. (Ḥam p. 764.) See also zalajaI. [And see zaluwxN.]
An arrow, such as is called qidoH, that slips (yanozaliju↓) quickly from the hand, (Ḳ, TA,) or from the bow. (TA.) See also zaAlijN.
Applied to a well, i. q. zaluwxN [q. v.]. (TA in art. zlx.)

EuqobapN zaluwjN A far-extending, long [stage of a journey]; (Lḥ, Ḳ;) as also zaluwqN. (Lḥ, Ḳ in art. zlq, and TA. [In the CK, in this art. and in art. zlq, EaqabapN: in my MṢ. copy of the Ḳ, in this art., EqabpN; but in art. zlq, EuqobapN, which is the right reading. See also zaluwxN.]) So in the saying, sironFA EqbpF zaluwjFA [We journeyed a farextending, long stage]. (Lḥ, TA.)
zaliyjN: see zalojN:
and its fem. zaliyjapN: see zalajaI.
zaAlijN: see zaluwjN.

Also An arrow that slips (yatazal-aju or yanozaliju [see 5]) from the bow; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and so zaluwjN↓ [q. v.]: (Ḳ:) or an arrow that is shot by the archer, and falls short of the butt, striking violently upon a rock, and bounding up from it to the butt: but such is not reckoned muqaroTis: (AHeyth, TA: [see also zaAlixN:]) and zalojN↓, as though an inf. n. used as an epithet, an arrow that falls upon the ground, and does not go straight to the animal at which it is shot. (TA.)
Also Escaping from difficulties, troubles, or distresses. (Ḳ.)
And Drinking vehemently (Ḳ) of anything. (TA.)
[mizolajN, written in Freytag's Lex. mizolj, there expl. as meaning Quickly, or swiftly, passing; on the authority of the Deewán el-Hudhaleeyeen.]

muzal-ajN Small in quantity or number: (Ḳ:) a mean, paltry, small, or little, gift: (Ṣ, TA:) one hat is imperfect, or incomplete: and anything that is not done superlatively, excellently, consummately, thoroughly, or soundly: (TA:) anything low, base, vile, mean, paltry, inconsiderable, or contemptible. (Ḳ. [See also muzal-axN.])
Love (Hub- [in the CK, erroneously, Hab-]) that is not pure, or not genuine. (Ḳ.)
Having little taste. (Ḥam p. 404.)
Small in body. (Ḥam ibid.)

And hence, (Ḥam ibid.,) A man (Ḳ) deficient, or defective, (Ḳ, Ḥam,) in manliness, or manly virtue or moral goodness, (Ḥam,) and weak: (TA:) or defective in make: and deficient in prudence, or discretion, and precaution, or sound judgment, or firmness of mind or of judgment: (TA:) and niggardly. (Ḳ.)
One who is consociated with a people, not being of them: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) or, as some say, i. q. daEiI-N [i. e. one whose origin, or lineage, is suspected; or an adopted son;, &c.]. (TA.)
Also Life striven to be retained (mudaAfaEN) with a bare sufficiency of the means of subsistence. (TA.)

hom.sense: mizolaAjN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and zilaAjN↓ (Ḳ) [A kind of latch, or sliding bolt; like mizolaAqN and mizolaAxN;] a [thing like the] migolaAq, except that it is opened with the hand, whereas the mglAq is not to be opened save with the key: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) a wooden thing by means of which one closes or makes fast [a door]: (Ḥam p. 764; in explanation of the former word:) so called because of the quickness with which it slips (lisuroEapi QnozilaAjihi↓): but ISh describes the kind of mzlAj used by the people of El-Basrah as having a crooked iron key, which slips into a hole in the door, by means of which the door is locked: pl. mazaAliyju. (TA.)
Also the former word, applied to a woman, Having little flesh in her posteriors, or posteriors and thighs; or having small buttocks, sticking together; syn. rasoHaMCu. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
1. zalaxato rijoluhu, aor. _a {yazolaxu}, inf. n. zuluwxN, His foot slipped; (AZ, A, L, TA;) like zalajato; (AZ, L, TA;) as also tzl-xt↓. (A.)

[Hence,] one says of water, zalaxa Eani AlS-axorapi ‡ [It slipped, or slid down, from the rock]. (A, TA.) And of an arrow, yazolaxu EalaI wajohi AlOaroDi vum-a yamoDiI ‡ [It slides along upon the ground; then penetrates]. (A, TA. [See also zalaja.]) And zalaxa fiI maXoyihi ‡ He hastened, or was quick, in his going, or gait. (A, TA.) [See also zalaxaAnN.] And zalaxa mino fiyhi kalaAmN ‡ [Speech slipped from his mouth]. (A.)
zalaxahu biAlr-umoHi, aor. _i {yazolixu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. zaloxN, (TA,) i. q. zaj-ahu [He pierced him, or thrust him, with the pointed iron foot of the spear]; (Ḳ;) as also zax-ahu. (TA.)
And zalaxa raOosahu, inf. n. zaloxN, He broke his head so as to slit, or cleave, the skin; syn. Xaj-ahu. (Kr, TA.)
zalixa, aor. _a {yazolaxu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. zalaxN, (TA,) He was, or became, fat. (Ḳ.) zalixato is said of camels, meaning They were, or became, fat. (TA.)

entry.sense: 2. zl-xhu, inf. n. tazoliyxN, He made it, or rendered it, smooth. (Ḳ.)
[And app. He, or it, made him to slip: see its pass. part. n., below.]
See also a verse cited voce zul-axapN.
4. Azlx qadamahu He, or it, made his foot to slip. (A, TA.)
[Hence,] Azlx Als-ahoma ‡ [He made the arrow to slide along upon the ground: see 1, third sentence]. (A, TA. [See also 4 in art. zlj.])

Azlx AlbaAba He closed, or made fast, the door with the mizolaAx [q. v.]. (A, TA.) You say, [so in my copy of the A, but app. it should be “you do not say,”] Oazolaxotu AlbaAba when you require, for opening it, a key. (A. [See, again, 4 in art. zlj.])
5. tzl-x [He, or it, slipped, or slid along or down]: see 1, first sentence: and see zul-axapN. [See also 5 in art. zlj.]

hom.sense: zaloxN A slippery place, from which the feet slip because of its moistness (Ṣ, Ḳ) or its smoothness; (Ḳ;) for it is [like smooth rock, or is] smooth rock; (Ṣ, TA;) as also zalixN↓. (Ḳ.) And one says also mazal-apN zaloxN [using the latter word as a corroborative]. (TA.)

It is also an inf. n. used as an epithet; (TA;) meaning † Slippery; (Ṣ, A, TA;) applied to a standing-place, (Ṣ,) or to a place [absolutely]; (A, TA;) like zalojN; (Ṣ, TA;) as also zalixN↓. (A, TA. [In this sense, zaloxN is said in the A to be tropical: app. because it is an inf. n. used as an epithet.]) It is also applied to a well (rakiy-ap), meaning Smooth and slippery at its top [or mouth], so that he who stands upon it slips into it; (TA;) and so zaluwxN↓, (Ṣ, TA,) and zaluwjN. (TA.)

Also The limit, or extreme limit, to which an arrow is shot: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) a rájiz says,
mino maAYapK zaloxK bimir-iyxK gaAlo [app. meaning From a hundred fathoms, a limit, or an extreme limit, to which one shoots with a long four-feathered arrow rising in its flight so as to exceed the usual limit; from three hundred to four hundred cubits being said to be the limit, or extreme limit, to which an arrow is shot; and gaAlo being used by poetic license for gaAlK]: (Ṣ:) or, accord. to ADk, zlx here signifies the furthest limit to which an arrow is shot by him who endeavours to shoot it to the utmost distance: or, accord. to Lth, the raising the hand, or arm, in shooting an arrow to the furthest possible distance: so says Az; who adds that he had not heard this last explanation on any other authority than that of Lth, but hoped it might be correct. (L, TA.) [See also zalojN.]

entry.sense: zalixN: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.
zulaxapN: see zul-axapN, below.

zalaxaAnN and zaloxaAnN † The advancing, or preceding, accord. to the Ḳ, in going, or gait, but accord. to the parent-lexicons, in haste, or quickly; as also zljAn [i. e. zalajaAnN, which is an inf. n.; and in like manner zalaxaAnN and zaloxaAnN, accord. to the TḲ, are inf. ns., of which the verb is zalaxa, aor. _u {yazoluxu}, though it is more probably _a]. (TA.)
zaluwxN: see zaloxN.
Also A quick, or swift, she-camel. (TA. [See also zaluwjN.])
And Eqbp zaluwxN [i. e. EuqobapN, see zaluwjN,] A long, far-extending [stage of a journey]. (TA.)
zul-axN: see the next paragraph.

zul-axapN A sloping slide (zuHoluwfapN, Ṣ, Ḳ) down which children slide. (Ṣ. [In one copy of the Ṣ, yatazal-axu↓ minohaA AlS-iybaAnu: in two other copies, yatazal-aju: and in one of these, EalayohaA is put in the place of minohaA.])

Also ‡ A pain that attacks in the back, (A, Ḳ,) which consequently becomes hard, or rigid, and rough, (Ḳ,) depriving one of the power of motion (A, Ḳ) by reason of its violence: (A:) and some pronounce the word zulaxapN↓, without teshdeed to the l; and some, erroneously, with j: (TA:) or it is a disease that attacks in the back and the side: (ISd, TA:) [and zul-axN↓ appears to signify the same, or to be a coll. gen. n.: for] AA cites the following verse:
waSirotu mino baEodi AlqawaAmi OabozaxaA
wazal-axa↓ Ald-ahoru biZahoriI zul-axaA [app. meaning, And I have become, after goodliness of stature, or symmetry, or justness of proportion, protuberant in the breast and hollow in the back; and time has produced, in my back, pain that deprives me of the power of motion]. (Ṣ, TA.)
EanaqN zal-aAxN † A vehement [pace of the kind termed] Eanaq [q. v.]. (TA.)
zaAlixN ‡ An arrow that slides along (yazolaxu) upon the ground, and then penetrates. (A, TA. [See also zaAlijN.])
muzal-axN, applied to a man, ‡ Mean, ungenerous, or sordid; [as though] repelled, and made to slip, from generosity:
and hence, applied to living, or sustenance, or means of subsistence, and to a gift, mean, paltry, scanty, or deficient. (A, TA. [See also muzal-ajN.])
mizolaAxN [A kind of latch, or sliding bolt; also called mizolaAjN, q. v., and mizolaAqN;] a thing with which doors are made fast without its being [itself] made fast [or locked]. (A, TA.)
Also i. q. Aizolagab-a, [q. v.,] said of hair. (TA in art. zlgb.)
And AzlEb- Als-aHaAbu The clouds were, or became, dense, or thick. (Ḳ.)

muzolaEib-N A torrent that is copious, and impelled in its several parts, or portions, by the impetus of one part, or portion, acting upon another, (Ṣ in art. zEb, and Ḳ, and TA,) having much rubbish or many small particles or fragments [borne on its surface]. (TA.) [See also zaAEibN.]
Also a dial. var. of muzolagib-N, [q. v.,] applied to a young bird. (TA.)

Q. 4. Aizolagab-a, said of a young bird, Its feathers came forth: (Ṣ in art. zgb, and Ḳ:) or its feathers began to come forth, (Lth, TA,) before their becoming black. (TA.) Also said of plumage, It began to come forth. (Lth, TA.) And said of hair, (Ṣ in art. zgb, and Ḳ,) as also AzlEb-, (TA,) It grew forth after having been shaven: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) it began to grow forth, soft: and said of the hair of an old man, i. q. AizogaAb-a [it was, or became, downy]. (TA.) Accord. to the Ṣ, and AḤei and IḲṭṭ and others, it belongs to art. zgb, like as AizolaEab-a is held by them to belong to art. zEb; but accord. to the Ḳ, the l is radical, and therefore this is its proper place. (TA.)

hom.sense: 1. zalafa: see 2:
and see also 8, in three places.

entry.sense: 2. zl-fhu, (O, TA,) inf. n. tazoliyfN, (O,) He did it previously, or beforehand; namely, a thing; (IAạr, O, TA;) as, for instance, an evil action; (O, TA;) and so zalafahu↓; (IAạr, TA;) syn. Oasolafahu, (O, TA,) and qad-amahu. (IAạr, O, TA.)
zl-f Aln-aAsa, inf. n. as above, He disquieted, or agitated, the people, step by step: (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Z, O, TA:) accord. to Z, said of a guide. (TA.)
zl-f fiI Hadiyvihi, (inf. n. as above, Ḳ,) He added, or exaggerated, in his discourse, or narration; (IDrd, O, Ḳ;) as also cr-f. (IDrd, O.)

4. Azlfhu He made, brought, or drew, him, or it, (namely, a thing, TA,) near. (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, TA.) Hence, in the Ḳur [xxvi. 90 and 1. 30], waOuzolifati Qlojan-apu lilomut-aqiyna And Paradise shall be brought near to the pious: meaning, accord. to Zj, that their entrance thereinto shall become near, and their view thereof. (TA.) [Azdlf↓ bihi also signifies the same as Azlfh (agreeably with analogy); as is shown by what here follows:] it is said in a trad. of Moḥammad El-Bákir, maA laka mino EayoXika Uil-aA lac-apN tazodalifu bika UilaI HimaAmika [i. e. There is not remaining to thee, of thy life, save a pleasure that brings thee near to thy predestined term]. (O, TA.) And Azdlfhu↓ means He, or it, brought him near to destruction. (TA.)
Also He collected it together; (Mṣb, TA;) namely, a thing. (Mṣb.) Hence, in the Ḳur [xxvi. 64], waOazolafonaA vam-a AlMxariyna [And we collected there the others]. (TA.)
5: see the next paragraph {8}.

hom.sense: 8. Aizodalafa, (Mgh, Mṣb,) originally Aizotalafa, (Mṣb,) or AizodalafuwA, and tzl-fwA↓, (Ṣ, O, L, Ḳ,) He, or they, approached, or drew near: (Mgh, O, L, Mṣb, TA: in the Ḳ, tafar-aquwA is erroneously put for taqar-abuwA: TA:) or (O, accord. to the Ḳ “and”) advanced; or went forward, or before: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) Uilayohi [to him, or it], (Mgh, Ḳ,) and minohu [which means the same, as after danaA, &c.]: (TA, and Ḥar p. 452:) [and zalafa↓ and zalafuwA, inf. n. app. zalofN and zalafN, signify the same: for] you say also, zalafa↓ Uilayohi He drew near to him, or it: and zalafonaA↓ lahu We advanced, or went forward, to him, or it: (TA:) and zalofN signifies the act of advancing, or going forward, (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, TA,) from place to place; as also zalafN. (TA.) One says, Azdlf Als-ahomu UilaI kacaA The arrow approached, or drew near, to such a thing. (Mṣb.) And it is said in a trad., faUicaA zaAlati AlX-amosu faQzodalifo UilaI Qll-ehi fiyhi birakoEatayoni, meaning taqar-abo [i. e., When the sun declines from the meridian, then seek thou to draw near unto God therein by means of the prayers of two rek'ahs]. (TA.)
See also 4, in two places.

entry.sense: zalofN: see zulofapN.
zulofN: see its accus. case voce zulofapN, near the end of the paragraph.

zilofN A meadow; syn. rawoDapN; (TṢ, Ḳ;) and so zalafapN↓: (IB, TA:) thus the latter is expl. as occurring in a trad. relating to Ya-jooj and Ma-jooj, in which it is said, vum-a yurosilu Qll-ehu maTarFA fayagosilu AlOaroDa Hat-aI yatorukahaA kaAlz-alafapi [Then God will send rain, and it will wash the earth so that it will leave it like the meadow]: but in this instance, several other meanings are assigned to it: see zalafapN below. (TA.)

hom.sense: zalafN: see zulofapN, in two places:
and see also zalafapN, in five places.

entry.sense: zulufN: see its accus. case voce zulofapN, near the end of the paragraph.

hom.sense: zulofapN i. q. qurobapN [i. e. Nearness, with respect to rank, degree, or station]; (Ṣ, Mgh, O, Mṣb, Ḳ;) as also zulofaI↓, (Ṣ, Mgh, O, Mṣb,) and zalafN↓. (IDrd, O, Ḳ.) [It would seem that it means also Nearness with respect to place or situation: for SM immediately adds,] hence, in the Ḳur [lxvii. 27], falam-aA raOawohu zulofapF, [as though meaning But when they shall see it in a state of nearness: but] Zj says that the meaning is, but when they shall see it (i. e. the punishment) near (qariybFA): and several authors say that zulofapN is sometimes used in the sense of qariybN, as is stated in the 'Ináyeh. (TA.) And Station, rank, grade, or degree; as also zulofaI↓, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA,) and zalofN↓, (TṢ, Ḳ,) and zalafN↓: (Ḳ, TA:) pl. of the first zulafN: (Ṣ,* TA:) or (Ḳ) zulofaI↓ is a quasi-inf. n.; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) and such it is in the saying in the Ḳur [xxxiv. 36], wamaA OamowaAlukumo walaA OawolaAdukumo biQl-atiI tuqar-ibukumo EinodinaA zulofaI, as though meaning QzodilaAfFA [i. e. And neither your riches nor your children are what will bring you near to us in advancement: but here it may be well rendered, in station]: (Ṣ:) accord. to Ibn-ʼArafeh, zulofaI signifies the bringing very near: (TA:) the saying of Ibn-El-Tilimsánee that it is pl. of zulofapN is very strange, and unknown; the correct pl. of this last word being zulafN. (MF, TA.)

Also A portion (Ṣ, Ḳ) of the first part (Ṣ) of the night, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) whether small or large: so accord. to Th: or, accord. to Akh, of the night absolutely: (TA:) pl. zulafN and zulafaAtN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and zulufaAtN and zulofaAtN: or zulafN signifies the hours, or periods, (saAEaAt,) of the night, commencing from the daytime, and the hours, or periods, of the daytime, commencing from the night: (Ḳ:) and its sing. is zulofapN. (TA.) wazulafFA mina All-ayoli, in the Ḳur [xi. 116], means And at sunset and nightfall (the magorib and the EiXaMC): (Zj, TA:) some read zulufFA↓, with two dammehs; which may be a sing., like HulumN; or a pl. of zulofapN, like as busurN is of busurapN, with damm to the s in each: [but this is not a parallel instance; for busurN is a coll. gen. n. of which busurapN is the n. un., and the latter is not of the same measure as zulofapN:] and some read zulofFA↓, which is a pl.
