[or rather coll. gen. n.] of zulofapN, like as dur-N is of dur-apN; (Ḳ, TA;) or pl. of zaliyfN↓, like as qurobN is of qariybN, and gurobN of gariybN: (TA:) and some read zulofaI↓, in which the alif [written I] is a denotative of the fem. gender. (Ḳ, TA.)
See also the next paragraph.

entry.sense: zalafapN A full [reservoir of water such as is called] maSonaEap: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] zalafN↓: (Ṣ:) so, accord. to Sh, in the trad. mentioned voce zilofN: (TA:) or zalafN↓ signifies full watering-troughs, (Ḳ,) as pl. [or coll. gen. n.] of zalafapN: (TA:) or a full watering-trough. (Ḳ.) Also A [bowl such as is called] SaHofap: (Ḳ;) and so zulofapN↓; (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ;) of which the pl. is zulafN: (TA:) or a full SaHofap; and its pl. [or coll. gen. n.] is zalafN↓. (Lth, TA.) Also A green [vessel of the kind called] Uij-aAnap: (Ḳ:) so says AO: pl. [or coll. gen. n.] zalafN↓; and mazaAlifu↓ likewise signifies green OajaAjiyn [app. as an anomalous pl. of zalafapN or of zalafN, like as maXaAbihu is of XabahN]; both, also, mentioned on the authority of AO. (TA.)

Also A mother-of-pearl-'shell, or an oyster-shell; syn. SadafapN: (Ḳ:) Ḳṭ says that Alz-alafap in the trad. mentioned above voce zilofN has been expl. as meaning the maHaArap, i. e. the Sadafap; but he adds, I know not this explanation, unless a pool of water be called mHArp because the water returns (yaHuwru) to it and collects in it. (TA.)

Also A smooth rock: (Ḳ:) so, too, said to mean in the same trad.: and some read Alzlqp. (TA.) And Rugged ground. (Ḳ.) And Swept ground. (Ḳ.) And An even part of a soft mountain. (Ḳ.) Pl. (Ḳ) [or rather coll. gen. n.] in all these senses (TA) zalafN↓. (Ḳ.)
See also zilofN.

Also A mirror: (O, Ḳ: [in the CK, AlmaroOapu is put in the place of AlmiroMpu:]) [like zalaqapN:] mentioned by IB on the authority of Aboo-ʼAmr Ez-Záhid, and by Ṣgh on that of Ks: and so, too, it is said to mean in the trad. mentioned above; the earth being likened thereto because of its evenness and cleanness: (TA:) or the face thereof; (Ḳ;) as is said by IAạr. (TA.)
zulofaI: see zulofapN, in four places.
EuqobapN zaluwfN [A stage of a journey] far-extending: (O, Ḳ:) so says IF. (O.) [In the CK, EaqabapN is erroneously put for EuqobapN.]

zaliyfN Advancing; or going forward, or before. (O, Ḳ. [It is said in the TA that Almutaqad-imu as the explanation of Alz-aliyfu is erroneously put in the copies of the Ḳ for Alt-aqad-umu: but this assertion is app. itself erroneous.]) See zulofapN, near the end of the paragraph.

[Oazolafu expl. by Golius as on the authority of the KL, and by Freytag after him, as meaning Parvo naso præditus ejusque recto ac parvo mucrone, is a mistake for Oacolafu, thus written in my copy of the KL.]
[OazolafapN and OazolafaI expl. by Freytag as meaning Copia parva, cœtus hominum parvus, as on the authority of El-Meydánee, are app. mistakes for OazofalapN and OazofalaI.]

hom.sense: mazolafapN Any town (qaroyapN) that is between the desert and the cultivated land: pl. mazaAlifu: (Ṣ,* Ḳ:) the latter is syn. with baraAgiylu, signifying the towns (bilaAd) that are between the cultivated land and the desert; (Ṣ;) or, between the desert and the baHor [i.e. sea or great river]; such as El-Ambár and El-Kádiseeyeh. (M, TA.)
[The pl.] mazaAlifu also signifies Places of ascent; or steps, or stairs, by which one ascends: (Ḳ:) because they bring one near to the place to which he ascends. (TA.)
For the pl. mazaAlifu, see also zalafapN.

1. zaliqa, aor. _a {yazolaqu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. zalaqN; (TA;) and zalaqa, aor. _u {yazoluqu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. zaloqN; (TA;) He slipped; syn. zal-a; (Ḳ, TA;) for which cal-a is erroneously put in [some of] the copies of the Ḳ. (TA. [See also 5.]) And zaliqato rijoluhu, (Ṣ,) or Alqadamu, (Mṣb,) aor. _a {yazolaqu}, inf. n. zalaqN, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) His foot, (Ṣ,) or the foot, (Mṣb,) slipped, (Ṣ,) or did not remain firm, or fixed, in its place. (Mṣb.) The former is also said of an arrow, [app. as meaning It slid along the ground,] like zahiqa [q. v.]. (JK in art. zhq.)
zaliqa bimakaAnihi and zalaqa, He was, or became, disgusted by, or with, his place, or he loathed it, and removed, withdrew, or retired to a distance, from it. (Ḳ, TA.)
zalaqato, said of a she-camel, She was, or became, quick, or swift. (O, TA.)
zalaqahu: see 4.

zalaqahu Eano makaAnihi, aor. _i {yazoliqu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. zaloqN, (TA,) He removed him from his place. (Ḳ, TA.) Hence the reading of Aboo-Jaạfar and Náfi', [in the Ḳur lxviii. 51,] waUino yakaAdu Ql-aciyna kafaruwA layazoliquwnaka biOaboSaArihimo, meaning [And verily they who have disbelieved almost] smite thee with their evil eyes so as to remove thee from thy station in which God has placed thee, by reason of enmity to thee. (TA. [Or this reading may be rendered agreeably with the common reading: see 4.])

entry.sense: 2. zl-q, [inf. n. tazoliyqN,] He made a place slippery, (Ḳ, TA,) so that it became like the mazolaqap; and thus too though there be no water therein. (TA.)

Accord. to the O and Ḳ, [the inf. n.] tazoliyqN also signifies The anointing the body with oils and the like, so that it becomes like the mazolaqap; to which is added in the O, and though it be without water: but this is a confusion of two meanings; one of which is the first expl. above in this paragraph; and the other is, the anointing the body with oils and the like; as in the L and the Tekmileh. (TA.)
See also 4.
And see 1, last sentence.
zl-q AlHadiydapa He made the iron thing to be always sharp. (Ḳ.)
rl-qhu bibaSarihi, inf. n. as above, He looked sharply, or intently, at him, or it. (Ez-Zejjájee, TA.)
See also 2, last sentence, in art. dlS.

4. Azlqhu He made him to slip; as also zalaqahu↓. (Ḳ.) All the readers except those of El-Medeeneh read, [in the Ḳur lxviii. 51,] waUino yakaAdu Ql-aciyna kafaruwA layuzoliquwnaka biOaboSaArihimo, meaning [And verily those who have disbelieved] almost make thee to fall by their looking hard at thee, with vehement hatred: so accord. to El-'Otbee: or the meaning is, † [almost] smite thee with their [evil] eyes: (TA:) [it is also said that] Azlq fulaAnFA bibaSarihi means ‡ he looked at such a one with the look of a person affected with displeasure, or anger: (Ḳ:) or so naZara UilaI fulaAnK faOazolaqahu bibaSarihi: (Jm, TA:) and in this sense, also, is expl. the saying in the Ḳur mentioned above. (TA.) One says also Azlq rijolahu, (Ṣ,) or Alqadama, (Mṣb,) He made his (another's) foot to slip, (Ṣ,) or he made the foot not to remain firm, or fixed, in its place; and so zal-aqahaA↓. (Mṣb.)

Azlqt, said of a camel, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) and of a mare, (TA,) She cast her young one; syn. OasoqaTato; (Ṣ, TA;) or OajohaDato [q. v.]: (Ḳ:) or she (a mare) cast forth her young one completely formed: or, as some say, [her fœtus] not completely formed: (JK:) and you say also, Azlqt bijaniynihaA, like OamolaSato bh [q. v.]: (Abu-l- ʼAbbás, TA in art. mlS:) or Azlqt waladahaA is said of a female [of any kind], and means she cast forth her young one before it was completely formed. (Mgh.)
See also 1, last sentence.

5. tzl-q He, or it, slipped, or slid, along; (KL;) like tzl-j. (Ṣ and TA in art. zlj. [See also 1.]) One says, tzl-qt Algud-apu bayona Aljilodi waAll-aHomi [The ganglion slipped about between the skin and the flesh]. (M in art. dyS.)
[Also It was, or became, smooth, or slippery: a signification indicated in the M, in art. mls, where it is coupled with AisotawaI.]
He anointed his body with oils and the like. (JK.)

He ornamented, or adorned, himself; (Aboo-Turáb, Ḳ, TA;) as also tzb-q: (Aboo-Turáb, TA:) and led an easy, and a soft, or delicate, life, so that his colour, and the exterior of his skin, had a shining, or glistening. (Ḳ, TA.)
zaloqN: see the next paragraph.

makaAnN zalaqN, (Ṣ,) or zalaqN [alone], (Ḳ,) which is originally an inf. n., (Ṣ,) and zaliqN↓ and zaloqN↓ (Ḳ) and zalaAqapN↓ and mazolaqN↓ and mazolaqapN↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA, [the last two erroneously written in the CK mizolaq and mizolaqap,]) all signify the same; (Ḳ;) A slippery place; a place on which the foot does not remain firm, or fixed. (Ṣ, TA.) Hence, in the Ḳur [xviii. 38], fatuSobiHa SaEiydFA zalaqFA, i. e., [So that it shall become] smooth ground, with nothing in it, or with no plants in it: or, accord. to Akh, such that the feet shall not stand firmly upon it. (TA.) A poet says, (TA,) namely, Moḥammad Ibn-Besheer, (Ḥam p. 551,)
qad-iro lirijolika qabola AlxaTowi mawoqiEahaA
famano EalaA zalaqFA Eano gir-apK zalajaA
[Appoint for thy foot, before the stepping, its place upon which it shall fall, or, as in the Ḥam p. 522, simply its place, (mawoDiEahaA,) for he who goes upon a slippery place, in consequence of inadvertence, slips]. (TA.)
zalaqN also signifies The rump of a horse or similar beast. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)
zaliqN: see the next preceding paragraph.
Applied to a man, Quickly angry (O, Ḳ) at what is said. (O)

And, (T, Ṣ, Ḳ,) as also zumaliqN↓ (T, Ṣ, and Ḳ in art. zmlq) and zum-aliqN↓ and zumaAliqN↓, (Ṣ, and Ḳ in art. zmlq,) applied to a man, (T, Ṣ,) Qui semen emittit quum verba mulieri facit, sine congressu: (T, TA:) or qui semen emittit ante initum. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
zalaqapN A smooth rock; (Ḳ;) as also zalafapN. (Ḳ in art. zlf.)
And, (AZ, Ḳ,) as also the latter word, (AZ, TA,) A mirror. (AZ, Ḳ. [In the CK, AlmaroOapu is erroneously put for AlmiroMpu.])
naAqapN zaluwqN A quick, or swift, she-camel; (AZ, Ḳ;) as also zaluwjN. (AZ, TA.)
And EuqobapN zaluwqN [and zaluwjN and zaluwxN, in the CK, erroneously, EaqabapN,] A far-extending [stage of a journey]. (Ḳ, TA.)

zaliyqN i. q. siqoTN [meaning A young one, or fœtus, that falls from the belly of the mother abortively, or in an immature, or imperfect, state, or dead, but having the form developed, or manifest]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
zalaAqapN: see zalaqN.
zul-ayoqN The smooth peach; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) called in Pers. Xiyfotaho ranoG. (Ṣ.)
zumaliqN and zum-aliqN and zumaAliqN: see zaliqN.
ziyHN zayolaqN A wind swift in its passage. (Kr, TA.)
Alz-aAluwqu the name of a shield belonging to the Prophet; meaning That from which the weapon slips off, so that it does not wound the bearer. (TA.)
Oazolaqu (Ḳ in art. dlS) Hairless and glistening in body. (TḲ in that art.)
mazolaqN: see zalaqN.
mazolaqapN: see zalaqN. [Hence,] one says, huwa EalaI mazolaqapi AlbaATili [He is on the slippery way of false religion or the like]. (MF voce jaAd-apN, q. v.)
mizolaAqN i. q. mizolaAjN, (Ḳ,) a dial. var. of the latter word, [q. v.,] meaning The thing by means of which a door is closed, or made fast, and which is opened without a key. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
Also A mare [or other female (see 4)] that often casts her young; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) i. e., that usually does so; and applied in this sense to a camel. (TA.)

hom.sense: Q. 1. zaloqama He swallowed a gobbet, or morsel, or mouthful. (TA.)
[The inf. n.] zaloqamapN signifies [also], accord. to IB, The being wide, broad, or ample. (TA.)

entry.sense: zuloqumN The sea; from zaloqamapN meaning as expl. above; as also qulozumN. (IKh, TA.)
zuloquwmN i. q. HuloquwmN [The windpipe]. (IDrd, Ṣ in art. zqm, L, and Ḳ.)
Also The xuroTuwm [i. e. nose, or fore part thereof,] of a dog: and of a beast of prey: and, accord. to IAạr, [the proboscis] of an elephant. (TA.)
1. zalama, (aor. _u {yazolumu}, inf. n. zalomN, TḲ,) He cut off one's nose [and app. anything projecting, or prominent: see 2: and see also 8]. (ISh, Ḳ.)
† He made his gift little, or small, in quantity or amount; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) [as though he cut off something from it;] in [some of the copies of] the Ṣ, [but not so in mine,] zl-m↓. (TA.)
He filled (Ṣ, Ḳ) a water-ing-trough, or tank, (Ṣ,) or a vessel; (Ḳ;) as also zl-m↓, inf. n. tazoliymN. (AḤn, Ḳ.)

2. zl-m Als-ahoma, (Ṣ, Ḳ,*) inf. n. tazoliymN, (Ḳ,) He cut [or pared] the arrow, and made its proportion or conformation, and its workmanship, good: (Ṣ:) [he shaped it well:] or he made it even and supple. (Ḳ.) And zul-ima is said of anything as meaning Its edges were pared off. (TA.) [Hence,] zl-m Alr-aHaI He made the mill-stone round, and took from its edges. (Ḳ.) Dhu-r-Rummeh says,
kaOaroHaMCi raqodK zal-amatohaA AlmanaAqiru
[Like the mill-stones of Rakd (a mountain so called) which the picks have rounded by taking from their edges]: he likens the foot of the camel to a mill-stone from the edges of which the maEaAwil have taken, (Ṣ, TA,) and which they have made even. (TA.) And zal-amotu AlHajara signifies I cut the stone, and prepared it properly for a millstone. (TA.)
See also 1, in two places.
zl-m gicaMCahu † He made his food, or nutriment, bad, [i. e. fed him ill,] (Ḳ, TA,) so that his body became small. (TA.)
8. Aizodalama He cut off one's head. (ISh, Ḳ.) And He extirpated one's nose. (Ḳ.)
zalomN or zulomN, whence the phrase huwa AlEabodu zalomFA: see zalomap.

hom.sense: zalamN and zulamN↓ An arrow without a head and without feathers: pl. OazolaAmN: (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ:) which was applied to those [divining-] arrows by means of which the Arabs in the Time of Ignorance sought to know what was allotted to them: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) they were arrows upon which the Arabs in the Time of Ignorance wrote “Command” and “Prohibition;” (Mgh, Mṣb;) or upon some of which was written “My Lord hath commanded me;” and upon some, “My Lord hath forbidden me;” (Ḥar p. 465;) or they were three arrows; upon one of which was written “My Lord hath commanded me;” and upon another, “My Lord hath forbidden me;” and the third was blank; (Bḍ in v. 4;) and they put them in a receptacle, (Mgh, Mṣb,) and when any one of them desired to make a journey, or to accomplish a want, (Mgh,) or when he desired to perform some affair, (Mṣb,) he put his hand into that receptacle, (Mgh, Mṣb,) and took forth an arrow; (Mṣb;) and if the arrow upon which was “Command” [or “My Lord hath commanded me” (Ḥar ubi suprà)] came forth, he went to accomplish his purpose; but if that upon which was “Prohibition” [or “My Lord hath forbidden me” (Ḥar)] came forth, he refrained; (Mgh, Mṣb;) and if the blank came forth, they shuffled them a second time: (Bḍ ubi suprà:) or, as some say, the AzlAm were white pebbles, upon which they thus wrote, and by means of which they sought to know what was allotted to them in the manner expl. above: (Ḥar ubi suprà:) or, accord. to Az, the AzlAm [were arrows that] belonged to Kureysh, in the Time of Ignorance, upon which were written “He hath commanded” and “He hath forbidden,” and “Do thou” and “Do thou not;” they had been well shaped (zul-imato) and made even, and placed in the Kaabeh, the ministers of the House taking care of them; and when a man desired to go on a journey, or to marry, he came to the minister, and said, “Take thou forth for me a zlm;” and thereupon he would take it forth, and look at it; and if the arrow of command came forth, he went to accomplish that which he had purposed to do; but if the arrow of prohibition came forth, he refrained from that which he desired to do: [it is said that] there were seven of the arrows thus called with the minister of the Kaabeh, having marks upon them, and used for this purpose: (Jel in v. 4:) and sometimes there were with the man two such arrows, which he put into his sword-case; and when he desired to seek the knowledge of what was allotted to him, he took forth one of them. (TA.) Some say that the OazolaAm are The arrows of the game called Almayosir: but this is a mistake. (TA.) The seeking to obtain the knowledge of what is allotted to one by means of the AzlAm is forbidden in the Ḳur v. 4. (TA.)

Hence, OazolaAmu Albaqarapi ‡ The legs of the [wild] ox or cow: likened to the arrows called AzlAm because of their slenderness: or, accord. to the A, because of their strength and hardness. (TA.) [Hence, likewise,] the former of the two words (zalamN) signifies also † A strong and light or active boy: pl. as above: (TA:) [app. because] a poet likens [such] a boy to an arrow of the kind thus called. (Ṣ, TA.*)

Also, both words, (Ḳ,) the latter on the authority of Kr, (TA,) A cloven hoof: (Ḳ:) accord. to some, peculiarly of the ox-kind: (TA:) or the [projecting] thing that is behind it: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) pl. as above. (Ḳ,* TA.)
And the latter of the same two words, (AA, Ṣ,) or each of them, (Ḳ,) [The hyrax Syriacus;] one of the [animals called] wibaAr [pl. of waborN]: pl. as above. (AA, Ṣ, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: zulamN: see the next preceding paragraph, throughout.

huwa AlEabodu zalomapF and zulomapF↓ and zalamapF↓ and zulamapF↓, [the last omitted in some copies of the Ḳ,] (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and also with n in the place of the l, (Ṣ and Ḳ in art. znm) † He is one whose proportion, or conformation, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or whose cut, (Ḳ,) is that of the slave: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or he is the slave in truth: (Ks, Ṣ:) or he resembles the slave as though he were he: (Lḥ, Ḳ:) it is as though one said, hw AlEbd mazoluwmFA↓, i. e. he is the slave, being thus created by God, so that every one who looks at him sees the characteristics of the slaves impressed upon him: and it is a prov. applied to him who is low, ignoble, or mean: (Meyd:) [i. e.,] one says thus in disapproval (fI Alnkrp [i. e. fiI Aln-akarapi] or fI Aln-akirapi): (Lḥ: so in different copies of the Ṣ:) and in like manner one says of the female slave [hiIa AlOamapu zalomapF, &c.]: (Lḥ, Ṣ, Ḳ:) Aṣ said, huwa AlEabodu zalomapu, using the nom. case, without tenween; but IAạr said, hw AlEbd zalomapF, using the accus. case, with tenween: so in the handwriting of ʼAbd-Es-Selám El-Basree: (TA:) and accord. to Lḥ, one says, hecaA AlEabodu zalomFA↓ yaA fataI, (so in some copies of the Ṣ,) or zulomFA↓, (so in other copies of the Ṣ, and in the TA,) with damm, (TA,) meaning † This is the slave in proportion, or conformation, and in cut, O young man: (Ṣ, TA:) or, as some say, the meaning is, truly. (TA.)
zulomap: see the next preceding paragraph.

hom.sense: zalamapN [A kind of wattle]: zalamataA AlEanozi means the zanamataAni of the she-goat: (Ḳ:) or, accord. to Kh, zalamapN signifies a certain appertenance of goats; a thing hanging from their Huluwq [here meaning throats, externally,] like the [kind of ear-ring called] quroT; the animal having two of such things: if an appertenance of the ear, it is called zanamapN, [q. v.,] with n. (Ṣ, TA.) See also Oazolamu.
See also zalomap.

entry.sense: zulamap: see zalomap.
zaliymN: see muzal-amN.
naAIN zulaAmiI-N: see zunaAmiI-N, in art. znm.

Oazolamu (Ḳ) and muzal-amN↓, (AʼObeyd, Ḳ,) as also [Oazonamu and zanimN and] muzan-amN [applied to a camel], (TA,) Having the end of the ear cut, (AʼObeyd, Ḳ,) a [portion termed] zalamap↓ or zanamap being left [hanging] to it: (AʼObeyd, TA:) this is done only to camels of generous race, (AʼObeyd, Ḳ,) and to sheep or goats: the fem. of the first is zalomaMCu: (Ḳ:) [see also zanimN: or] Oazolamu, fem. as above, is applied to a goat, as meaning having what are termed zalamataAni [dual of zalamapN expl. above]. (Ṣ.)

AlOazolamu AljadaEu signifies The mountain-goat; (Ḳ;) agreeably with the original meaning; (TA;) and so Almuzal-amu↓: (Ḳ: [in the CK, wa is erroneously omitted between the words AlwaEilu and AlS-agiyru Aljuv-api:]) and Alz-alomaMCu signifies The female mountain-goat. (Kr, Ḳ.)

And also, i. e. AlAzlm AljcE, (Ḳ,) because it is [as though it were] always jacaE, not becoming old, (TA,) ‡ Time, or fortune, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) that is hard, or rigorous, (Ḳ,) in its course, (TA,) abounding with trials (Ḳ) and deaths: accord. to Yaạḳoob, so called because deaths hang upon it, and follow it. (TA.) They said, OawodaI bihi AlOazolamu AljacaEu and AlOazonamu AljacaEu, [q. v.] i. e. † Time, or fortune, [&c.,] destroyed it; relating to a thing that has gone, and passed, and of which one has despaired. (TA.) [See also art. jcE.]
Alz-alomaMCu also signifies The female of the hawk kind. (Kr, Ḳ.)

muzal-amN, applied to an arrow, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) like zaliymN↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) Cut [or pared], (ISk, Ṣ,) and made good in its proportion or conformation, and its workmanship: (ISk, Ṣ, Ḳ:) [well shaped:] or made even and supple: (TA:) and in like manner the former, with p {muzal-amapN}, applied to a staff (EaSFA). (Ṣ.)
See also Oazolamu, in two places.
Also (i. e. muzal-amN) † Short [as though cropped] in the tail. (ISk, TA.)

† Small in body: (Ḳ: [in the CK, wa is erroneously omitted before the words explaining this meaning:]) and so muzan-amN: (IAạr, TA:) and the former, rendered small in the body by being badly fed: (TA:) or [simply] badly fed. (Ṣ.)

Applied to a man, (Ṣ, TA,) † Light, (TA,) or, like muqac-acN, made light, (Ṣ,) in form, figure, or person: so says ISk: (Ṣ, TA:) or † short, light, or active, and Zariyf [app. as meaning either elegant in form, or clever]; (M, Ḳ;) likened to a small arrow: (M:) and, with p {muzal-amapN}, applied to a woman as meaning † not tall; like muqac-acapN. (Ṣ.)
Applied to a horse, † Of middling make; muqotadiru Alxaloqi or muqotadaru Alxlq: (so in different copies of the Ḳ:) thus expl. in the M. (TA.)
And † Small [or scanted]; applied to a gift. (TA.)
mazoluwmN: see zalomap.
zil-iy-apN [expl. in art. zl, q. v.,] sing. of zalaAliI-u. (Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. zam-ahu, (Ḳ,) aor. _u {yazomumu}, inf. n. zam-N, (TA,) He tied, or bound, it: fastened it; or made it fast. (Ḳ.)

zam-a AlbaEiyra, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (Mṣb, TA,) He attached, (ISk,) or put, (Mgh,) or tied, or fastened, (Mṣb,) to the camel, (ISk, Mgh, Mṣb,) the zimaAm [q. v.], (ISk, Mgh,) or his zimaAm; (Mṣb;) he put in the camel's burap, or his xizaAm, [each meaning a nose-ring,] or his xiXaAXap, [or xiXaAX, a wooden thing fixed in the bone of the nose,] the zimaAm, and tied it, or fastened it, in order to restrain him thereby; (Ḥar p. 329;) i. q. xaTamahu: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) and zam-ama↓ AljimaAla [He attached Oazim-ap ( pl. of zimaAm) to the camels], (TA,) or zum-ima↓ AljimaAlu [The camels had Oazim-p attached to them]; (Ṣ) with teshdeed because relating to several objects. (Ṣ, TA.)

Hence, zam-a nafosahu † He restrained, or withheld, himself. (Mgh.) And zum-ati AlOalosinapu † The tongues were restrained, or withheld. (Ḥar p. 329.) And maA Oatakal-ama bikalimapK Hat-aI OaxoTimahaA waOazum-ahaA † [I say not a saying until I qualify it to be used with cogency or efficiency]. (TA.)
Hence also, (Mgh,) zam-a Aln-aEola, (Ṣ, Mgh, TA,) [aor. and] inf. n. as above, (TA,) ‡ He attached a zimaAm [q. v.] to the sandal; (Ṣ, Mgh, TA;) as also Azm-↓ AlnEl. (Mgh, TA.)

[Hence likewise,] zam-a biOanofihi, said of a camel, † He raised [his nose, and consequently] his head, by reason of a pain in it. (Ḳ.) And the same phrase, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) said of a man, (TA,) † He elevated his nose, from pride; (Ḳ;) or he magnified, or exalted, himself; or was proud; (Ṣ, Ḳ;*) as also Aizodam-a↓; (Ḳ;) and zAm-↓, inf. n. muzaAm-apN. (TA.)

And zam-a biraOosihi ‡ He raised his head; (Ḳ, TA;) inf. n. as above: (TA:) [and so zam-a raOosahu: for] you say, Oaxaca Alc-iYobu saxolapF facahaba bihaA zaAm-FA↓ raOosahu, i. e. † [The wolf took a newborn lamb or kid, and went away with it] raising [his head], (Ṣ, TA,) or zam-FA↓ i. e. raising with it his head: (TA:) and you say of the wolf, zam-ahaA and Aizodam-ahaA↓, both meaning the same, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) i. e. He took it, namely, the new-born lamb or kid, raising his head, or its head, (accord. to different copies of the Ḳ,) with it. (TA.)
zam-a Alqirobapa, (Ḳ,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) ‡ He filled the water-skin. (Ḳ, TA.)
zam-ati Alqirobapu, [aor., accord. to rule, _i,] inf. n. zumuwmN, ‡ The water-skin became full: thus the verb is intrans. as well as trans. (Ḳ, TA.)
And zam-a said of a camel's tush, † It rose. (TA.)
And † He went forward, or onward; or before, or ahead; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) as some say, (TA,) in journeying: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) in this sense, the inf. n. is zam-N. (TA.)
Also, (inf. n. zam-N, AʼObeyd, TA,) He spoke, or talked. (AʼObeyd, Ḳ, TA.)
One says also of the sparrow, yzm- biSawotK lahu DaEiyfK [app. yazim-u, as it is intrans., meaning The sparrow chirps with a feeble voice peculiar to it]: and thus do large hornets. (TA.)

entry.sense: 2: see 1, second sentence, in two places.

hom.sense: 3: see 1.
You say also, xarajotu maEahu OuzaAm-uhu, and OuxaAzimuhu, i. e. OuEaAriDuhu [meaning † I went forth with him taking a different way from his until we both met in one place: see xaAzamahu]. (TA.)

entry.sense: 4: see 1, in the former half of the paragraph.
7. Anzm- It was, or became, tied, or bound; fastened; or made fast. (Ḳ.)
8: see 1, in the latter half of the paragraph, in two places.
One says also, Azdm- AlX-aIoCa Uilayohi, meaning † He stretched forth the thing to him. (TA.)

hom.sense: R. Q. 1. zamozamapN [as inf. n. of zamozama, and also as a simple subst.,] A distant sounding or sound, such as is confused and continued. (Ḳ.) You say, of a thing, zamozama, meaning It made a distant sound, confused and continued: and samiEotu zamozamapF I heard a distant sound, confused and continued. (TḲ.)

The sounding, or sound, of thunder: (AZ, Ṣ:) or the consecutive reiteration of the sound of thunder; which is the best kind of sounding thereof, and the surest symptom of rain. (M, Ḳ.) One says, Alr-aEodu yuzamozimu The thunder sounds with consecutive reiteration. (TḲ.) Accord. to AḤn, the zamozamap of thunder is [The sounding thereof] when it is not loud and clear. (TA.)

The speaking, or speech, of the Magians, on the occasion of their eating, (Ṣ, IAth,) with a low voice: (IAth:) or the gibbering, or uttering gibberish or jargon, one to another, of the Persians, or other foreigners, (taraATunu AlEuluwji,) over their eating, while they are [in a manner] speechless, not making use of tongue nor of lip [so as to articulate]; it being a sound which they roll in their noses and their fauces, but such that they understand one another: (Ḳ:) or zamozama, said of a Magian, means He affected, or constrained himself, to speak, on the occasion of eating, while closing his mouth: whence the saying, waQnohawohumo Eani Alz-amozamapi [And forbid ye them from the affecting, &c.]. (Mgh.)
The crying [or roaring], or the cry [or roar], of the lion. (Ḳ.) You say of him, zamozama [He cried, or roared]. (TA.)
It is also [The uttering, or utterance, of a sound, or of the voice,] from the chest, when it is not clear. (TA.)

Also The crying [or whinnying or neighing], or the cry [or neigh], of the horse: [see muzamozimN:] so in the saying, Hawola AlS-il-iyaAni Alz-amozamapu [Around the Sl-yAn (a kind of plant, or herbage,) is whinnying or neighing]: (Meyd:) this is a prov., applied to a man who hovers round about a thing, and does not make apparent his desire: (Meyd, TA:) or to a man who is served for the sake of his wealth: (Meyd:) the Sl-yAn is one of the most excellent kinds of pasture: and the prov. means that the cries and clamour that one hears are for the desire of what is to be eaten and enjoyed: Z says, (TA,) the Sl-yAn is cut for the horses that do not quit the tribe; (Meyd, TA;) and they neigh, or whinny, (tuzamozimu, and tuHamoHimu,) around it: (TA:) some relate it otherwise, saying Hawola AlS-ulobaAni [around the crosses], pl. of SaliybN; and Alz-amozamapu [they say] means the crying, or cry, of the worshipper thereof. (Meyd.)
zamozama also signifies He kept, guarded, or took care of, a thing. (TA.)
And zamozamotu AlmaAla, inf. n. zamozamapN, I collected together the cattle, or property, and drove back, or put back, the outer ones, or outer portions, of what had become scattered thereof. (TA.)

entry.sense: R. Q. 2. tazamozama, said of a camel, He brayed; syn. hadara. (Ḳ. [See also R. Q. 1, which has nearly the same meaning.])
tazamozamato bihi XafataAhu His lips moved with it. (TA.)
zam-N [an inf. n. used in the sense of an act. part. n.]: see zaAm-N:
and see also 1, in the latter half of the paragraph.

zamam is thought by ISd to be used only as an adv. n.: (TA:) [but see what follows.] wajohiI zamama bayotihi means My face is towards his house. (Ḳ.) An Arab of the desert said, laA waQl-aciI wajohiI zamama bayotihi maA kaAna kacaA wakacaA, meaning [No, by Him] towards whose house [is my face, it was not thus and thus, or such and such things did not happen]. (Ṣ.)
One says also, daAriI mino daArihi zamamN, (Ṣ,) or daAriI zamama daArihi, (Ḳ, TA, in the CK zamamu,) ‡ My house is near to his house. (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA.)
And Oamoruhumo zamamN † Their affair, or case, is conformable to the just mean; like OamamN: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or easy, not exceeding the due measure, bound, or limit. (Lḥ, TA.)

zimaAmN A thing with which one ties or binds, fastens, or makes fast: (Ḳ:) meaning [the noserein of a camel; i. e.] the cord that is tied to the burap [or xizaAm, each meaning nose-ring of a camel], or to the xiXaAX [or wooden thing fixed in the bone of the nose], and to which, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, TA,) i. e. to the end of which, (Ṣ, TA,) is tied the miqowad [or leading-rope]: (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, TA:) and (afterwards, Mṣb) also applied to the miqawod (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA) itself: (Mṣb:) pl. Oazim-apN. (Mṣb, Ḳ.) [See also xiTaAmN.] It is said in a trad., laA zimaAma walaA xizaAma fiI AlUisolaAmi [There shall be no nose-rein nor nosering by which to lead a man in El-Islám]: meaning a practice of the devotees of the Children of Israel, who used to attach rings and reins to the noses, like as is done to the she-camel in order that she may be led thereby. (TA.)

[Hence,] zimaAmu AlOamori † That by means of which the thing, or affair, subsists, and is conducted, or managed, and ordered. (TA.) And OaloqaI fiI yadihi zimaAma Oamorihi † [He put in his hand, or power, the means of conducting his affair, or the conduct of his affair]: and yuS-arifu Oazim-apa AlOumuwri † [He disposes as he pleases the various means of conducting the affairs]. (TA.) And huwa EalaI zimaAmK mino Oamorihi † He is on the point of accomplishing his affair. (TA.) And Aln-aAqapu zimaAmu AlUibili † [The she-camel is the leader of the other camels]: said when she goes before them. (TA.) And huwa zimaAmu qawomihi † [He is the leader of his people, or party]: and humo Oazim-apN qawomihimo † [They are the leaders of their people, or party]. (TA.) [See also De Sacy's Chrest. Arabe, sec. ed., i. 261 and 503; and see Quatremère's Hist. des Sultans Mamlouks, vol. i., sec. part, pp. 65 and 66.]

zimaAmu Aln-aEoli † [The zmAm of the sandal] is the thing to which the XisoE is attached, or tied: (Ṣ:) or the thong that is between the middle toe and that next to it, to which the XisoE is attached, or tied: [but for the latter of these explanations, it seems that we should read the thong that is between the middle toe and that next to it: or the thong to which the XisoE is attached, or tied: the XisoE being the thong that passes through the sole, and between two of the toes, and to which the XiraAk is attached: for it appears that the term zimaAm is applied by some to the thong called by others the XiraAk, extending between the leg and the toes: and by some, to what is called by others the XisoE, or qibaAl: to the latter as being likened to the cord that is tied to the camel's nose-ring; and to the former as being likened to the leading-rope which is tied to that cord: it being] a metaphorical term, from the zimaAm of the camel: (Mgh:) it is [said to be] the thong lies upon the back [meaning upper side] of the foot, [extending] from, or [consisting] of, the fore part of the XiraAk, lengthwise: [for the term XiraAk (q. v.) is sometimes used in a larger sense than that above assigned to it:] or it is like the qibaAl, [which is expl. in the same manner as the XisoE, i. e., as] being between the middle toe and that next to it: (Ḥar p. 539:) [and thus it is expl. by J and Mṭr and F in another art.;] the qibaAl of the sandal is its zimaAm, (Ṣ, and Mgh and Ḳ in art. qbl,) i. e. its thong which is (Mgh in that art.) between the middle toe and next to it. (Ṣ and Mgh and Ḳ in that art.)
zam-amN or zam-amu: see zamozamN.
zum-aAmN Tall herbs, (Ḳ,) rising above such as are termed luEaAE. (TA.)

hom.sense: zamozamN Copious, or abundant, water; as also zumaAzimN↓: (Ḳ:) [or] the latter, (Ḳz, TA,) [and app. the former also,] and zumazimN↓, (IKh, TA,) and zamozaAmN↓, (Ḳz, TA,) brackish water; i. e. such as is between salt and sweet. (IKh, Ḳz, TA.)

Also, (accord. to some copies of the Ṣ and Ḳ,) or zamozamu, (accord. to other copies of the same, and accord. to the Mṣb,) imperfectly decl., because of the fem. gender and a proper name, (Mṣb,) the name of The well of Mekkeh, (so in a copy of the Ṣ and in the Mṣb,) or a certain [celebrated] well in Mekkeh, (so in another copy of the Ṣ,) [i. e.] a certain well adjacent to the Kaabeh; (Ḳ;) so called [because its water is somewhat brackish, or] because of the copiousness of its water; (JM;) as also zumazim↓ [i. e. zumazimN or zumazimu], (IAạr, TA,) and zumaAzimN↓ [or zumaAzimu], and zam-amN↓ or zam-amu, (accord. to different copies of the Ḳ,) the last (zam-am) on the authority of IAạr. (TA.) The names of this well, collected from trads. and lexicons, have been found to amount to more than sixty. (TA.)

zamozam [with or without tenween] is also the name of A celebrated well at El-Medeeneh, which is regarded as a means of obtaining a blessing, and the water of which is drunk and transported [like that of the more celebrated well of the same name at Mekkeh]. (TA.)

zamozamN or zamozamu (accord. to different copies of the Ṣ, [used by a poet with tenween, but probably by poetic license, for it is app. a fem. proper name, and therefore imperfectly decl.,]) is also A name of, or for, a she-camel, like EayoTal. (Ṣ.)

entry.sense: zimozimN: see zimozimapN, in two places.
zumazimN or zumazimu: see zamozamN, in two places.

zamozamapN [inf. n. of R. Q. 1 (q. v. passim); and also used as a simple subst., of which the pl. is zamaAzimu]. You say raEodN cuw zamaAzima and hadaAhida [Thunder having confused and continued, or murmuring, sounds, heard from a distance]. (TA.) And zamaAzimu Aln-aAri The sounds of the blazing of fire. (TA.)

zimozimapN A company, or collection, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) of men, (Ṣ, TA,) whatever it be: (TA:) or any collection; as also zmzwm [i. e. zumozuwmN↓]: (Ḥam p. 233:) or fifty, (Ḳ,) and thereabout, (TA,) of camels, and of men; (Aṣ, Ḳ;) as also DimoDimapN; (Aṣ, TA;) neither of which words is formed by substitution from the other: (TA:) pl. zmAzm [i. e. zamaAzimu], (Ḥam ubi suprà,) and [coll. gen. n.] zimozimN↓, (Ṣ,* TA,) occurring in the saying of a rájiz, (Ṣ,) Aboo-Moḥammad El-Fak'asee, (TA,)
UicaA tadaAniI zimozimN mino zimozimi
[When companies draw near to companies]. (Ṣ, TA.) Also A distinct number of jinn, or genii: or of beasts of prey. (Ḳ.) And A herd of camels among which are no young ones, or little ones; and so zimoziymN↓: (Ḳ:) or, accord. to EshSheybánee, zimozimN↓ and zimoziymN↓ signify large, big, or bulky, camels. (Ṣ.)

saHaAbN zamozaAmN Clouds thundering, but not loudly and clearly. (AḤn, TA.) [Accord. to one passage in the TA, zamozaAmN seems to be expl. by IKh as meaning Thundering much: but the passage appears to be incorrectly transcribed.]
See also zamozamN.

zumozuwmN The best, or excellent, or choice, of camels: or a hundred thereof. (Ḳ.) And The best of a people; (Ḳ, TA;) the choice, best, or most excellent, portion thereof: in one copy of the Ḳ, [and so in the CK,] Xar-uhumo is put in the place of sir-uhumo. (TA.)
See also zimozimapN.
zimoziymN: see zimozimapN, last sentence, in two places.
zumaAzimN or zumaAzimu: see zamozamN, in two places.

zaAm-N [act. part. n. of zam-a]. zaOam-ahaA [meaning Attaching a zimaAm to her] occurs used by poetic license for zaAm-ahaA, because of the concurrence of two quiescent letters; like AisowaOad-ato for AisowaAd-ato. (Ṣ.)

† Magnifying, or exalting, himself; or elevating his nose, from pride: (Ṣ, TA:) [and in like manner zam-N↓:] one says, zaOayotuhu zam-FA † I saw him magnifying, or exalting, himself,, &c., not speaking: (TA:) pl. of the former zum-amN. (Ṣ, TA.)
See also 1, in the latter half of the paragraph.
Also, accord. to El-Ḥarbee, applied to a man, † Fearing, or afraid; syn. faziEN. (TA.)
ziyzamN: see what next follows.

ziyziymN a word imitative of The low, or faint, sound of the jinn, or genii, that is heard by night in the deserts; (TA in this art. and in art. zym;) and so ziyzamN↓: (IAạr, Ḳ * and TA in art. zym:) Ru-beh says,
tasomaEu lilojin-i bihi ziyziymaA
[Thou hearest therein a low, or faint, sound of the jinn by night]. (TA.)
AlUizomiymu One of the nights called layaAliI AlmuHaAqi [meaning the last three nights of the lunar month]. (Ḳ.)

And The decrescent moon in the last part of the [lunar] month, (Ḳ,) when it becomes slender and bow-shaped: Dhu-r-Rummeh uses it in this sense without the article Al: and Th says that UizomiymN is one of the names of the [moon when it is termed] hilaAl. (TA.)
UibilN muzam-amapN: see what next follows.
baEiyrN mazomuwmN A camel having a zimaAm attached to him; syn. maxoTuwmN: and UibilN muzam-amapN↓ camels having Oazim-ap attached to them; syn. muxaT-amapN. (TA.)
farasN muzamozimN fiI Sawotihi A horse quavering, or trilling, his voice, [or whinnying or neighing,] and prolonging it. (AʼObeyd, TA.)

zumaAwarodN, (Ṣ and Ḳ in art. wrd,) or zamaAwarodN, as in the Commentaries on the Keshsháf, (MF,) or zum-aAwarodN, (MA,) an arabicized word, vulgarly bazomaAwarodN, (Ṣ,) or buzomaAwarodN, (Ḳ,) and the vulgar appellation is correct, agreeing with the Pers. original, (Shifá el-Ghaleel,) [which is bazomaAwarodN, or] PCmAwrd, (MA,) A certain kind of food, composed of eggs and flesh-meat: (Ḳ:) or thin paste folded together, with flesh-meat within: or the kind of food called luqomapu AlqaADiI, [i. e. small, light, spongy balls, generally about the size of walnuts, made of leavened dough, and eaten with honey poured over,] and also called luqamapu Alxaliyfapi, and narojisu AlmaAYidapi, and muyas-arN, and muhay-aON; and in Khurásán called nawaAlah: (MF:) or nwAlhC bzrGAn: (MA:) [or, as Golius says, on the authority of Meyd, a kind of food made of fine flour, bruised almonds, and honey.]
1. zamuta, aor. _u {yazomutu}, inf. n. zamaAtahu, He was, or became, grave, staid, steady, sedate, or calm. (A, Ḳ.)

5. tzm-t i. q. tawaq-ara [He showed, exhibited, or manifested, gravity, staidness, steadiness, sedateness, or calmness; or he endeavoured, or constrained himself, to be grave, staid,, &c.]. (A.) One says, maA OaXad-a tazam-utahu [How great is his show of gravity,, &c.! or his endeavour, or constraint of himself, to be grave,, &c.!]. (Fr, Ṣ.)

zamiytN Grave, staid, steady, sedate, or calm, (IAạr, Ṣ, A, Ḳ, TA,) in his sitting-place: (IAạr, TA:) pl. rumataMCu, (A,) or zmt [app. zumotN or zumutN, if not a mistranscription for zumataMCu, which I rather think it to be]. (TA.)
zim-iytN Very grave, staid, steady, sedate, or calm: (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) forbearing, or clement; quiet; of few words; like Sim-iytN: or, as some say, silent. (TA.)
fulaAnN Oazomatu Aln-aAsi Such a one is the most grave, staid, steady, sedate, or calm, of men. (Ṣ.)

1. zamaxa, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or zamaxa biOanofihi, (L,) aor. _a {yazomaxu}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. zamoxN, (L,) He exalted, or magnified, himself; was proud; (Ṣ, L, Ḳ;) behaved proudly, haughtily, or vainly; (Ṣ, L;) elevated his nose, from pride; (L;) i. q. Xamaxa, or Xamaxa biOanofihi. (TA.)
zamaxN: see zamuwxN, in two places.
zimoxN or zimaxN The tree called sum-aAq; as also ZimoxN or ZimaxN. (TA in art. Zmx; but there written without any syll. signs.)

EuqobapN zamuwxN [in the CK EaqabapN] (JK, A, Ḳ) and zamaxN↓ (Ḳ) ‡ [A stage of a journey] far-extending, (Ḳ,) hard, or difficult. (AZ, IAạr, JK, Ḳ.) One says, saAra EuqobapF zamuwxFA ‡ [He journeyed a long and hard stage]. (A.)
And niy-apN zamuwxN (A, and L in art. Xmx) and zamaxN↓, like XamuwxN and XamaxN, (L in that art.,) ‡ A distant, far-reaching, or faraiming, intention, purpose, or design. (A, and L ubi suprà.)
zaAmixN i. q. XaAmixN [Proud,, &c.]; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) or XaAmixN biOanofihi [elevating his nose, from pride]: (A, L:) [pl. zum-axN.]
OunuwfN zum-axN i. q. Xum-axN [Noses elevated, from pride]. (Ṣ, A.)
[Hence,] jibaAlN lahaA OunuwfN zum-axN, (A, TA,) i. e. TiwaAlN ‡ [Mountains having tall, or long, prominences]. (TA.)
And kayolN zaAmixN ‡ Full measure. (JK, A, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: 1. zamara, aor. _i {yazomiru} and _u {yazomuru}, inf. n. zamorN (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) and zamiyrN (Mṣb, Ḳ) and zamaraAnN; (ISd, TA;) and zm-r↓, inf. n. tazomiyrN; (Ḳ;) He [piped, or] played upon (lit. sang in) a reed; (Ḳ;) he blew in a mizomaArN. (Ṣ,* A, Mṣb.*)

[Hence,] zamara Aln-aEaAmu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and zamarati Alhayoqapu, (A,) or Aln-aEaAmapu, (TA,) aor. _i {yazomiru}, inf. n. zimaArN (Ṣ, A, Ḳ) and zumaArN, (TA,) ‡ The ostriches, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and the she-ostrich, (A, TA,) cried, or uttered their, or her, cry. (Ṣ, A, Ḳ, TA.) [Said only of the females, or a female:] of the male ostrich one says only EaAr-a. (Ṣ, TA.)
And zamara biAlHadiyvi ‡ He published, or divulged, the story. (A, Ḳ.)
And zamara fulaAnFA bifulaAnK He excited, or incited, such a one against such a one. (A,* Ḳ, TA.)
zamira, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. _a {yazomaru}, (Ḳ,) inf. n. zamarN, (Ṣ,) He had little hair, (Ṣ,* Ḳ,* TA,) and little wool. (Ḳ,* TA.)
Also, [hence,] inf. n. as above, (Ṣ,) or zamaArapN and zumuwrapN, (TA,) ‡ He (a man, Ṣ, TA) had little muruwoCap [i. e. manliness, or manly virtue]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
And zamira maAluhu, inf. n. as above, † His property became little, or scanty. (TA in art. qfr.)

entry.sense: 2: see 1, first sentence.
10. Astzmr ‡ He was, or became, abject, or ignominious, or weak, and small in body, and lean; being abased or brought low. (A, TA.) [See also the part n., below.]
zamorN: see zumorapN.

hom.sense: zamirN Having little hair; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) and having little wool: fem. with p {zamirapN}. (A, Ḳ.) You say SabiI-N zamirN A child having little hair: and XaApN zamirapN [A sheep, or goat, having little wool or hair]: and ganamN zawaAmiru [Sheep, or goats, having little wool or hair]: (A, TA:) and naAqapN zamirapN A she-camel having little fur: and nabotN zamierN [app. meaning A plant having few leaves]. (Ḥam p. 683.) And XaEarN zamirN [Scanty, or thin, hair]. (A, TA.)
Also, [hence,] (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or zamiru AlmuruwoCapi, (A,) ‡ A man (A) having little muruwoCap [i. e. manliness, or manly virtue]. (Ṣ, A,* Ḳ.)
And zamiru AlmaAli † A man having little, or scanty, property. (AZ, TA in art. qfr.)
And EaTiy-apN zamirapN ‡ A scanty, or small, gift. (A,* TA.)
Also Good singing: (Th, TA:) [and] so zamiyrN↓. (Az, O, TA.)
And Goodly in countenance. (Ḳ.)

entry.sense: zamorapN A company, or congregated body, of men; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) as also zawomarN↓: (TA:) or (so in the TA, but in the Ḳ “and”) a party in a state of dispersion: (Ḳ:) pl. zumarN: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) you say, jaAWuwA zumarFA They came in parties in a state of dispersion, one after another: (A:) some say that zumorapN is from zamorN↓ [originally an inf. n., (see 1, first sentence,) and hence] signifying “sound,” because a company of men is not without sound: others, that it signifies a company of few persons; from XaApN zamirapN: (MF:) but the former is the proper derivation, and is confirmed by what is said in the B. (TA.)
zamuwrN: see the next paragraph.
zamiyrN Short; (Kr, Ḳ;) applied to a man: (TA:) pl. zimaArN. (Kr, Ḳ.)
And Beautiful; applied to a boy, or young man; (AA, Th, O, Ḳ;) as also zawomarN↓ (AA, O, Ḳ) and zamuwrN↓. (Ḳ.)
See also zamirN.
zimaArapN The act [or art] of [piping, or] playing upon the reed [or mizomaAr]. (Ḳ.)

Also zam-aArapN, † A fornicatress, or an adulteress: (Th, AʼObeyd, Az, Ṣ, Ḳ:) so in a trad., in which it is said nahaI Eano kasobi Alz-am-aArapi He prohibited the gain of the fornicatress: (Th, AʼObeyd, Az, Ṣ:) so called because she publishes her business: (Th:) some say that the correct word is here ram-aAzap, because such a woman makes signs with her lips and her eyes and her eyebrows: Az says that he holds the former to be the right; and Abu-l- ʼAbbás Aḥmad says that the latter is wrong, and that the former signifies a beautiful prostitute: but Az adds that the trad. may mean as above, or he prohibited the gain of the female singer, as AḤát relates on the authority of Aṣ. (TA.)
zam-aArapN [fem. of zam-aArN, q. v.]
[Also] i. q. mizomaArN, q. v. (Ḳ.)
And ‡ A saAjuwr [i. e. collar, or collar of iron,] (O, A, Ḳ, TA) that is put upon the neck of a dog. (TA.)

And metaphorically used as meaning ‡ A jaAmiEap; (A, TA;) [i. e.] A [shackle for the neck and hands, such as is called] gul-. (TA.)
And † A bar of iron (EamuwdN) between the two rings of the [shackle called] gul-: (M, O, Ḳ:) so termed because of its sound. (O.)
Also A she-ostrich. (Ḥar p. 408.)

hom.sense: zawomarN: see zumorapN:
and see also zamiyrN.
Also Playing; or a player. (O.)

entry.sense: muzam-arN † Shackled [with a zam-aArp]. (O, TA.)

mizomaArN A musical reed, or pipe; (Ṣ,* A, Mṣb,* Ḳ,* TA;) what is called in Persian naAIo [now generally meaning a flute]; (marginal note in a copy of the KT;) as also zam-aArapN↓, (Ḳ,) [which latter, by many pronounced zum-aArap, and generally so pronounced in Egypt, is applied to a double reed-pipe, figured and described in my work on the Modern Egyptians,] and mazomuwrN↓ and mazomuwrN↓, (IAth,) the latter like magoluwqN and magoruwdN: (TA:) pl. of the first, (Ṣ, A,) and of the last two, mazaAmiyru. (Ṣ,* A.) It is related in a trad., that Moḥammad, on hearing Aboo-Moosà El-Ash'aree reciting, said to him, laqado OuEoTiyta mizomaArFA mino mazaAmiyri Mli daAwuwda ‡ [Verily thou hast been gifted with a pipe like that of David himself]; likening the sweetness of his voice and melody to the sound of the mizomaAr; (TA;) as though he had musical pipes in his throat: or mzAmyrMl dAwwd is here the same as mazomuwraAt daAwuwd: (A:) for,

mazaAmiyru daAwuwda also signifies [The Psalms of David;] what David used to sing, or chant, (yatagan-aI bihi, in the CK yutagan-aI bh,) of the Psalms: (Ḳ:) and to such is likened the utmost sweetness of voice in reciting: and Ml is said to be here redundant or pleonastic; meaning the person: (TA:) or (so in the TA, but in the Ḳ “and”) mzAmyr dAwwd signifies kinds of prayer, or supplication: it is pl. of mizomaArN and of mazomuwrN↓ or muzomuwrN. (So in different copies of the Ḳ.)
mazomuwrN and muzomuwrN: see mizomaArN, in two places.
musotazomirN ‡ Shrinking, and abject, or ignominious, in his own estimation. (Ḳ, TA.) [See also its verb.]
zumur-udN: see the next article.

zumur-ucN (T, Ṣ, Mgh, L, Mṣb, Ḳ) and zumur-acN, (Az, TA,) and accord. to some zumur-udN, with the unpointed d (TA,) or, accord. to IḲt, this is a mistranscription, and Aṣ says that it is correctly written with the pointed c (Mṣb,) [The emerald: accord. to some] i. q. zabarojadN; (Sudot;, L, Mṣb, Ḳ;) but Et-Teyfáshee [rightly] says that the zbrjd is a different kind of stone: [see this word:] and Ibn-Sá'id El-Anṣáree says that the mine of the zbrjd is said to be near to that of the zm-rc: (TA:) several authors say that the zm-rc differs from the zbrjd in being more green: (MF, TA:) it is an arabicized word [from the Pers. zumorudo]: (Ṣ, L, Mṣb, Ḳ:) [a coll. gen. n.:] n. un. with p {zumur-ucapN}. (Mṣb.)

hom.sense: 1. zamiEa, aor. _a {yazomaEu}, inf. n. zamaEN, He became confounded, or perplexed, and unable to see his right course; or he became bereft of his reason or intellect; in consequence of fear: (Ṣ, Mṣb,* Ḳ:*) he feared, or was afraid: (Ḳ:) he was impatient; or had not sufficient strength to bear what befell him, and found not patience: (L:) he became disquieted, disturbed, agitated, flurried, or in a state of commotion. (Lḥ.)

zamaEati AlOaronabu, aor. _a {yazomaEu}, (TA,) inf. n. zamaEaAnN, (Lth, Ḳ, TA,) The hare was light, or active, and quick, or swift: (Lth, Ḳ, TA:) and AzmEt↓ it ran, (Ṣ, TA,) and was light, or active. (TA.) And zamaEa, aor. _a {yazomaEu}, inf. n. zamaEaAnN, He went slowly. (ISk, Ṣ, Ḳ.) Thus the verb has two contr. significations. (Ḳ.) And He went with short steps; as also tzm-E↓. (TA.)

entry.sense: 2: see the next paragraph {4}.

hom.sense: 4. OazomaEotu AlOamora, and OazomaEotu EalaI AlOamori; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) the former accord. to Ks.; the latter accord. to Kh, but disallowed by Ks; both, however, are authorized by Fr, as meaning the same, like OajomaEotuhu and OajomaEotu Ealayohi; (Ṣ;) and OazomaEotu bihi; (TA;) I determined, resolved, or decided, upon the affair: (Fr, Ṣ, Ḳ:) my determination, resolution, or decision, became fixed upon the affair, (Lth or Kh, Ṣ, TA,) to execute it, or perform it, of necessity: (Lth, TA:) or I kept constantly, firmly, steadily, steadfastly, or fixedly, to the affair: syn. vabat-u Ealayohi: (Ḳ:) and zam-aEotu↓, (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ, [in the CK written without teshdeed,]) followed by EalaI before the object, inf. n. tazomiyEN, (TA,) signifies the same: (Ibn-ʼAbbád, Ḳ:) AzmE may be formed by transposition from Ezm, or the z may be a substitute for j (IF.) You say, AzmE Almasiyra [and EalaI Almasiyri] He determined, resolved, or decided, upon going, journeying, or departing. (Mgh.)
See also 1.
AzmEt AlHubolapu † [The grape-vine, or its branch,] became large in its zamaEap, i. e. knot, or gem, [see zamaEN,] (ISh, Ḳ, TA,) and its fruit-stalk was near to coming forth. (ISh, TA.)

And AzmE Aln-abotu The herbage made its first appearance in a scattered state: (Ṣ:) or was not all of it equal, or uniform, but consisted of scattered portions, (Ḳ, TA,) at its first appearance, (TA,) one part surpassing another. (Ḳ, TA.)

entry.sense: 5: see 1, last sentence.

hom.sense: zamaEN; see zamaAEN.

Also pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] of zamaEapN↓, which [is the n. un. of the former, and] signifies A certain excrescence bekind the cloven hoof: (AZ, Ṣ, Mṣb,* Ḳ:) or a thing like the nails of sheep or goats, in the part between the shank and foot; every leg having upon it two of the things thus termed (zamaEataAni), as though they were formed of pieces of horn: (Lth, Ḳ:) or a certain excrescence projecting above the hoof of the sheep or goat: (TA:) or the pendent hairs in the kinder part of the kind leg, or kind foot, of the sheep or goat, and of the gazelle, and of the hare: (Ḳ:) [the pl. of zamaEapN↓ is zamaEaAtN (occurring in the Ṣ and Ḳ in the present art., and in the Ḳ in art. zwd, &c.), and] the pl. of zamaEN is zimaAgN: (AZ, Ṣ, Ḳ:) see zamuwEN.

Hence, as being compared to the zamaE of the cloven hoof, (L,) zamaEN also signifies † The lower, or baser, or the lowest, or basest, or the refuse, of mankind: (Ṣ, L, Ḳ:) pl. OazomaAEN. (L.) One says, huwa mino zamaEihimo, meaning † He is of the last of them; (Ṣ, L;) and of their followers. (L.)
Also, i. e. zamaEN The hairs behind the fetlock [-joint]; (Ḳ;) and so zamaEaAtN [pl. of the n. un. zamaEapN↓]. (TA.)

Also ‡ Knots, gems, or buds, in the places whence the racemes of the grape-vine come forth: (ISh, Ḳ, TA:) accord. to Et-Táïfee, (L in art. kmH,) [the n. un.] zamaEapN↓ signifies the knot, or gem, in the place whence the raceme of grapes grows forth: (L ubi suprà, and TA:) or, as some say, the berry when it is like the head of a young ant; and the pl. is zamaEaAtN and [coll. gen. n.] zamaEN: (TA:) and † the gem of a leaf: (L in art. kmx:) and zamaEu Alkaromi † The leaves that cover what is within them of the raceme of the grape-vine. (TA voce kaAfuwrN.)
Also † An excrescence, or a redundance, (ziyaAdapN,) in the fingers or toes: and the epithet [applied to him who has such] is OazomaEu↓. (Ḳ.)
And Scattered portions of herbage, here and there; like portions of clouds in the sky. (TA.)

entry.sense: zamaEapN: see the next preceding paragraph, in four places.

zamaAEN Penetrating energy, or sharpness, vigorousness, and effectiveness, in the performance of an affair, and determination, resolution, or decision, to do it; (L, Ḳ;) as also zimaAEN↓ and zamaEN↓: (Ḳ:) and courage, such that when one has determined, resolved, or decided, upon an affair, he does not turn from it: (Ḳ:) and good judgment, with boldness to undertake affairs, (Ḳ, TA,) such that when one purposes an affair, he acts with a penetrating energy, or sharpness, vigorousness, and effectiveness, in performing it: (TA:) or courage, and great boldness: (Ṣ:) and quickness, and hastiness. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
zimaAEN: see the next preceding paragraph.
zamuwEN: see zamiyEN.

Also A hare that runs with short steps, as though it ran upon its zamaEaAt↓, (Aṣ, T, Ṣ, Ḳ,) i. e. the pendent hairs on the kinder parts of its kind legs: (T, TA:) or such as, when it approaches its habitation, goes upon its zamaEap, (Ḳ, TA,) and with short steps, (TA,) in order that its foot-marks may not be traced: (Ḳ, TA:) and (Ḳ, TA, but in the CK “or”) such as is quick, or swift, and brisk, or sprightly. (Ḳ, TA.)

zamiyEN A man sharp, vigorous, or effective, in determination, resolution, or decision: (Mgh:) a courageous man, who, when he has determined, resolved, or decided, upon an affair, does not turn from it: (Lth, Ḳ: [in the CK, yazomaEu is a mistake for yuzomiEu:])
and having good judgment, with boldness to undertake affairs, (Ḳ, TA,) so that when he has purposed an affair, he acts with a penetrating energy, or sharpness, vigorousness, and effectiveness, in performing it: (TA:) or zamiyEu Alr-aOoIi signifies a man having good judgment: (Ṣ:) and zamiyEN signifies also quick; (Ḳ;) quick, and hasty; (Ṣ;) and so zamuwEN↓: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) pl. of the former zumaEaMCu. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

hom.sense: huwa OazomaEu minohu He is more sharp, vigorous, or effective, in determination, resolution, or decision, than he. (Mgh.)
See also zamaEN, last sentence but one.

entry.sense: OanaA muzomiEN EalaI OamorK, [or muzomiEN OamorFA, or both, and muzomiEN biOamorK, I am determining, resolving, or deciding, upon an affair: or] my determination, resolution, or decision, is fixed upon an affair. (Kh, Ṣ.) [See 4.]
zimik-N: see the following paragraph.

zimik-aI, (Fr, Ṣ, Ḳ,) with kesr to the z and m, (Ḳ,) like zimij-aI [in measure and in meaning, app. from the Pers. zimojiI], (Ṣ,) [in the O erroneously written zimak-aI,] and zimik-N↓, (Fr, Ḳ, TA,) like filiz-N, (TA,) [in the O erroneously written zimak-, and in the CK zamak,] and zimik-MCu↓, (TA,) The place of the growth of the tail of a bird: (Fr, Ṣ, Ḳ:) or the root of the tail of a bird: (M, Ḳ:) or the whole tail of a bird: (Ḳ:) or sometimes, accord. to Lth, the tail itself is called zmk-I when it is short (UicaA qaSura), (O, TA,*) or, as in some copies [of his book, meaning the ʼEyn], when it is clipped (AcA quS-a). (TA.)
zimik-aMCu: see the preceding paragraph.

hom.sense: 1. zamala, aor. _u {yazomulu} and _i {yazomilu}, inf. n. zamaAlN, He ran, (Ḳ, TA,) and went along quickly, (TA,) leaning, or bearing, on one side, raising his other side; (Ḳ, TA;) as though he were bearing upon one leg; not with the firmness of him who bears upon both of his legs. (TA.)

And zamala (Ḳ, TA) fiI maXoyihi and Eadowihi, aor. _u {yazomulu}, (TA,) inf. n. zamolN and zamaAlN [the latter accord. to the CK zimaAlN but said in the TA to be with fet-ḥ like the former,] and zamalaAnN (Ḳ, TA) and zamalN, (TA as from the Ḳ, [but not in the CK nor in my MṢ. copy of the Ḳ,]) said of a horse or similar beast, (Ḳ, TA,) or of a wild ass, (TA,) He was as though he limped, by reason of his briskness, or sprightliness, (Ḳ,) or as though bearing upon his fore legs, by reason of pride, or self-conceit, and briskness, in his going and his running. (TA.)

zamalahu, (Mgh, Mṣb,) inf. n. zamolN, (TA,) He bore it, or carried it; namely, a thing: (Mgh, Mṣb:) and Aizodamalahu↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ,) originally Aztmlh, (TA,) signifies the same; or he took it up and carried it, or he raised it upon his back; syn. AiHotamalahu; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) at once; (Ḳ;) namely, a load: (TA:) like zabalahu and Azdblhu. (TA in art. zbl.)

And zamalahu, (IDrd, Ḳ,) aor. _u {yazomulu}, inf. n. zamolN, (TA,) He made him to ride behind him, (IDrd, Ḳ,) EalaI AlbaEiyri on the camel: (IDrd:) or he rode with him [on a camel, in a maHomil,] so as to counterbalance him; (Ḳ, TḲ:) and so zAmlhu↓, (Mgh,) inf. n. muzaAmalapN, (Ṣ,) he rode with him so as to counterbalance him (Ṣ * Mgh) on a camel, (Ṣ,) in the maHomil. (Mgh.)
[And zamala gayorahu, aor. _u {yazomulu}, He followed another:] see zaAmilN.

entry.sense: 2. zm-lhu, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) inf. n. tazomiylN, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) He wrapped him (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ *) fiI vawobihi [in his garment], (Ṣ, Ḳ,*) or fI viyaAbihi [in his garments], (Mgh,) or bivawobihi [with his garment]. (Mṣb.)
[Hence, app.,] tazomiylN signifies also The act of concealing. (IAạr, Ḳ.)
3: see 1, last sentence but one.
muzaAmalapN also signifies The requiting with beneficence. (AA, TA in art. Hml.)

5. tzm-l (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and Aiz-am-ala, (Mgh, Ḳ,) the latter of the measure Aif-aE-ala, (Ḳ,) [a variation of the former,] and Aizodamala↓, (TA,) He wrapped himself (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ, TA) biviyaAbihi [with his garments], (Ṣ,) and so tzm-l alone, (TA,) or fiI viyaAbihi [in his garments], (Mgh, TA,) or bivawobihi [with his garment]. (Mṣb.)
6. tzAmlwA i. q. trAjzwA [i. e. They recited verses, or poetry, of the metre termed rajaz, which is also termed zamal, one with another; or vied in doing so]. (TA.)

hom.sense: 8. Aizodamala: see 5.
Aizodamalahu: see 1.

entry.sense: Q. Q. 1. zawomala, (TḲ,) inf. n. zawomalapN, (Ḳ,) He drove camels. (Ḳ, TḲ.)

hom.sense: zimolN A load, or burden. (Ḳ.) It occurs in a trad. as meaning † A load of knowledge. (TA.)
[Household-goods; or furniture and utensils. (Freytag, on the authority of the Deewán of the Hudhalees.) See also OazomalN.]
maA fiI juwaAliqika Uil-aA zimolN means There is not in thy sack save a half. (AA, Ḳ.)
See also zamiylN.
And see zum-alN.

entry.sense:
zamalN The kind of verse, or poetry, [more commonly] termed rajaz: [hence,] a poet says,
laA yugolabu Aln-aAziEu maA daAma Alz-amalo
[The drawer of water will not be overcome as long as the zml continues]; meaning, as long as he recites [or chants] the verse termed rajaz [or zamal], he is strong enough to work: thus it is related on the authority of AA: another reading is Alr-amalo: both are correct as to meaning. (IJ, TA.)
zamilN and zumalN: see zum-alN.

zumolapN A company of persons travelling together, or with whom one is travelling; (AZ, Ḳ;) as also zawomalapN↓: (En-Naḍr, TA:) or, as some say, (TA,) a company or a collection [in an absolute sense]. (Ḳ, TA.)

zimolapN Luxuriant, or abundant, and dense [palmtrees such as are termed] jab-aAr: [Aljum-Ar in the CK is a mistranscription:] and a collection of wadiI- [i. e. small young palm-trees, or shoots cut off from palm-trees and planted]: and young palm-trees exceeding the reach of the hand: (Ḳ, TA:) all on the authority of El-Hejeree. (TA.)
zamalapN: see OazomalN, in two places.

hom.sense: zimaAlN A limping in a camel. (Ḳ.)
And A wrapper that is put over a raAwiyap [or leathern water-bag]: pl. zumulN and OazomilapN: (Az, Ḳ:) you say valaAvapu OazomilapK. (Az, TA.)

entry.sense: zamiylN One who rides behind another (IDrd, Ṣ, Ḳ) on a camel (IDrd, TA) that carries the food and the household-goods or furniture and utensils; (TA;) and zimolN↓ signifies the same, (Ḳ,) and so does mazomuwlN↓: (IDrd, TA:) or one who rides behind another on a horse or similar beast: (TA:) or one who rides with another in a maHomil so as to counterbalance him. (Mgh.) It is metaphorically used in the saying, Oanota faArisu AlEilomi waOanaA zamiyluka ‡ [Thou art the horseman of science, or knowledge, and I am he who rides behind thee]. (TA.)

Hence, A travelling-companion (Mgh, TA) who assists one in the performance of his affairs. (TA.) It is said in a trad., laA yufaAriqu rajulN zamiylahu, i. e. [A man shall not separate himself from] his travelling-companion. (Mgh.)
zamiylaAni means Two men engaged in work upon their two camels: when they are without work, they are called rafiyqaAni. (Ḳ.)
zumayolN and zumayolapN: see zum-alN.
zimoyal-N: see what next follows.

zum-alN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and zumalN↓ and zimolN↓ [said in the CK to be like EidapN, but correctly like EidolN,] and zamilN↓ and zumayolN↓ (Ḳ) and zum-ayolN↓ and zum-aAlN↓ (Ṣ, Ḳ) and zimoyal-N↓ and zumayolapN↓ and zum-ayolapN↓ (Ḳ, or this is fem., Ṣ) and zum-aAlapN↓ (Ḳ) Cowardly, weak, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) low, mean, or contemptible; who wraps himself up in his house, or tent; not rising and hastening to engage in warfare; indolently refraining from aspiring to great things. (TA.) [See also UizomiylN. Accord. to J,] zum-ayolapN↓ signifies Weak as a fem. epithet. (Ṣ.)
zum-aAlN: see the next preceding paragraph.
zum-ayolN: see the next preceding paragraph.
zum-aAlapN: see the next preceding paragraph.
zum-ayolapN: see zum-alN, in two places.

zaAmilN, applied to a horse or similar beast, (Ḳ, TA,) or to a wild ass, (A' Obeyd, TA,) That is as though he limped, by reason of his briskness, or sprightliness. (A' Obeyd, Ḳ, TA.) [Hence, app., the name of] The horse of Mo'áwiyeh Ibn-Mirdás Es-Sulamee. (Ḳ.)
Also One who follows (yazomulu↓, [in the CK yuzam-ilu,] i. e. yatobaEu,) another. (Ḳ.)

zaAmilapN A camel (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) or other beast (Ḳ) used for carrying (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) the goods, or furniture and utensils, of a man (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb) travelling, (Mgh, Mṣb,) and his food; (Ṣ, Mgh;) the p denoting intensiveness: (Mṣb:) or a she-camel upon which are carried the goods, or furniture and utensils, of the traveller: (Ḥar p. 130:) from zamala “he bore, or carried,” a thing: (Mgh, Mṣb:) pl. zawaAmilu. (TA.) [See also zawomalapN.]

Afterwards used to signify The Eidol [properly half-load] in which is the pilgrim's travelling-provision, consisting of biscuit, or dry bread, and fruit (vmr [app. a mistranscription for tamor i. e. dates]), and the like. (Mgh.)

hom.sense: zawomalapN Camels having their loads upon them: (IAạr, M, Ḳ:* [in the Ḳ, waAlEiyri should be waAlEiyru, or rather waAlUibilu:]) and so laTiymapN: EiyrN signifies “camels laden or not laden:” (IAạr, M:) zawaAmilu may be either its pl. or pl. of zaAmilapN [q. v.]. (TA.)
See also zumolapN.
huwa Qbonu zawomalatihaA means He is a knower of it; (IAạr, Ḳ;) i. e., of the affair. (IAạr.)
And Aibonu zawomalapa, also, means The son of the female slave. (IAạr, Ḳ.)

OazomalN A sound: (Aṣ, Ṣ:) or any mixed, or confused, sound: or a sound proceeding from the prepuce of a horse or similar beast: (Ḳ:) it has no verb. (TA.) A poet says,
taDib-u livaAtu Alxayoli fiI HajaraAtihaA
watasomaEu mino taHoti AlEajaAji lahaA QzomalaA
[The gums of the horses water in the adjacent tracts thereof, and thou hearest, beneath the dust, a sound attributable to them]: he means OazomalaA, but suppresses the C, as is done in wayolum-ihi [for wayolN liOum-ihi]. (Ṣ.) OazaAmiylu AlqisiI- means The sounds of the bows: AazAmyl being pl. of OazomalN, with I to give fulness to the sound of the vowel preceding it. (TA.) And OazomalapN↓ signifies The twanging sound of a bow. (Ḳ, TA.)

taraka OazomalFA and OazomalapF↓ and zamalapF↓ He left a family, or household. (Ḳ.) And xaraja fulaAnN waxal-afa Oazomalahu [Such a one went forth, and left behind him his family, or his family and his cattle]: and xaraja biOazomalihi He went forth with his family and his camels and his sheep or goats, not leaving behind him aught of his property. (AZ, TA.)

[Hence, app.,] Oaxacahu biOazomalihi [in one of my copies of the Ṣ, Oazomalahu,] He took it altogether; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) namely, a thing. (Ṣ.) And He took it with its OavaAv [or utensils and furniture]; as also biOazomulihi↓ and Oazomalatihi↓ (Ḳ) and zamalatihi↓. (L, TA.)
And EiyaAlaAtN OazomalapN↓ i. e. Numerous [families or households]. (Ṣ, Ḳ.*)

entry.sense: OazomulN, whence Oaxacahu biOazomulihi: see the next preceding paragraph, last sentence but one.
OazomalapN: see OazomalN, in four places.
UizomawolN: see OuzomuwlapN.

UizomiylN A shoemaker's knife (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA) with which he cuts the leather. (TA.) [In the TA, in art. crb, it is expl. as meaning A shoemaker's UiXofaI with which he sews: but this I have not found elsewhere.]
Also An iron (Ḳ, TA) like the new moon [in shape], (TA,) that is put at the end of a spear, for the purpose of catching wild oxen. (Ḳ,* TA.)
And The [implement called] miToraqap [q. v.]. (Ḳ.)

Applied to a man, (Ḳ, TA,) † A great, or vehement, eater; likened to the [shoemaker's] knife: (TA:) or strong: and also weak; (Ḳ, TA;) low, mean, or contemptible: (TA: [like zum-alN:]) thus having two contr. significations. (Ḳ.)

OuzomuwlapN (AA, Ṣ, Ḳ) and (Ṣ, Ḳ) some say (Ṣ) UizomawolapN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) the latter accord. to Aṣ and Sb and Ez-Zubeydee, (TA,) and UizomawolN↓, (Ṣ, TA,) which is said by IJ to be quasi-coordinate to jirodaHolN, because the w in it is not a letter of prolongation, for the letter before it is with fet-ḥ, (TA,) applied to a mountain-goat and to one of other animals, Vociferous: (AA, Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) or the first, [or, app, any of the three,] applied to a mountain-goat, such as, when he runs, leans, or bears, on one side: so accord. to AHeyth: Fr explains the first or second as applied to a horse, meaning that runs swiftly: and in like manner to a mountain-goat. (TA.)

muzam-alapN A certain thing in which water is cooled: of the dial. of El-'Irák: (Ḳ:) applied by the people of Baghdád to a green [jar such as is called] jar-ap or xaAbiyap, in the middle whereof is a perforation, in which is fixed a tube of silver or lead, whence one drinks; so called because it is wrapped (tuzam-alu i. e. tulaf-u) with a piece of cloth of coarse flax, or some other thing, between which and the jar is straw: it is in their houses in the days of summer: the water is cooled in the night by means of the [porous earthen bottles called] bar-aAdaAt; then it is poured into this mzm-lp, and remains in it cool. (Ḥar p. 548.)
mazomuwlN: see zamiylN.
muz-am-ilN, originally mutazam-ilN, A man wrapped with [or in] his garments: occurring in the Ḳur lxxiii. 1. (TA.)
Q. 1. zamolaqa, inf. n. zamolaqapN, He did the act denoted by the epithet zumaliqN expl. in art. zlq voce zaliqN. (TA.)
zamolaqapN in asses is like hamolajapN [i. e. The going an easy and a quick pace] in a horse. (TA.)

zumaliqN and zum-aliqN↓ and zumaAliqN↓ are expl. in the Ṣ in art. zlq [q. v., voce zaliqN]: in the Ḳ, in the present art., agreeably with the opinion of Aboo-ʼObeyd. (TA.) [The first is said in the TA, voce vat-N, to be syn. with EicoyawoTN, q. v.]
The first is also applied to an ass, as meaning Fat; whose back is even by reason of the fat. (Lḥ, TA.)
zumaAliqN: see zumaliqN:
and see also zumoluwqN, in two places.
zum-aliqN: see zumaliqN:
and see also zumoluwqN.

1. zamina. aor. _a {yazomanu}, inf. n. zamanN (Mṣb, Ḳ) and zamaAnapN (Ṣ,* Mṣb, Ḳ) and zumonapN, (Ḳ,) He (a man, Ṣ, Mṣb) had, or was affected with, a malady of long continuance, (Mṣb,) or what is termed zamaAnapN, expl. below: (Ḳ:) he was, or became, afflicted [with what is so termed]: (Ṣ:) or he was, or became, crippled. (TḲ.)

3. EaAmalahu muzaAmanapF (Ṣ, Ḳ) and zimaAnFA (Lḥ, TA) [He bargained, or made an engagement, with him, to work, for a time], (Ṣ, Ḳ,) from Alz-amanu. (Ṣ,) is like muXaAharapF [and XihaArFA] (Ṣ, Ḳ) from AlX-ahoru. (Ṣ.)

hom.sense: 4. Azmn [He, or it, continued a long time;] a long time passed over him, or it, (Ḳ,* TA,) i. e. a thing. (TA.) You say, Azmn biAlmakaAni He remained, staid, dwelt, or abode, a long time (zamaAnFA) in the place. (TA.)
And [hence,] Azmn Ean-iI EaTaAWuhu ‡ His gift [was a long time kept back from me, or] was slow, or tardy, in coming to me. (TA.)

Azmn fulaAnFA He (God) made such a one to be such as is termed zamin, i. e. affected with a protracted disease; (Mṣb, TA;) or crippled, or deprived of the power to move or to stand or to walk, by disease, or by a protracted disease: or made him to be affected with what is termed [zamaAnapN, expl. below, as meaning] EaAhapN [&c.]. (TA.) It is said also of a disease [as meaning It deprived him of the power to move, &c.]. (TA in art. EDb.)

entry.sense: zamanN an inf. n. of zamina [q. v.]. (Mṣb, Ḳ.)
And a simple subst. [meaning Continuance for a long time,] from Oazomana in the first of the senses assigned to it above; and so zumonapN↓, with damm. (IAạr, TA.)

Also, and zamaAnN↓, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, &c.,) the former a contraction of the latter, (Mṣb,) A time, whether little or much; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) thus accord. to Er-Rághib; (TA in art. dhr;) as being a space capable of division: (Mṣb:) and so says El-Munáwee: (TA:) a time considered with respect to its beginning and its end: (Er-Rághib, MF voce OamadN:) or i. q. EaSorN [as meaning a space, or period, of time]: (M, Ḳ:) [often meaning, without any addition to qualify it, a long time; as in an instance of the usage of the latter word above: (see 4:) what follows here applies to each of these words:] zamaAnN differs in some respects from MnN and from OamadN: Sh asserts it to be syn. with dahorN; but AHeyth says that this is a mistake: (TA:) [it is so, however, sometimes, accord. to several authorities, as has been shown in art. dhr; and particularly as meaning fortune, or fate:] IAth says that it is applied to the whole of what is termed Ald-ahoru [as meaning time], and to a portion thereof:
AHeyth says that it is the zmAn [i. e. season] of fruit, of ripe dates, and of heat and cold: and that it may be [a period of] two months [as meaning any one of the six seasons of the solar year] to six months [as meaning the half-year often termed summer and the half-year often termed winter]: (TA:) [thus] it is applied to any one of the four quarters of the year; (Mṣb, TA;) the first of which [in the order in which they are commonly mentioned by the Arabs, i. e. autumn,] is called by the Arabs [of the classical age] Alr-abiyEu, but vulgarly Alxariyfu; called by the former name because the first rain is therein, giving growth to [the herbage called] the rabiyE; and called by the latter name because the fruits are gathered therein; and it commences when the sun enters Libra: the second [i. e. winter] is called AlX-itaMCu; and commences when the sun enters Capricornus: the third [i. e. spring] is AlS-ayofu, vulgarly called Alr-abiyEu; and commences when the sun enters Aries: the fourth [i. e. summer] is AlqayoZu, vulgarly called AlS-ayofu; and commences when the sun enters Cancer: (Mṣb:)* * The two following tables exhibit the principal divisions of the Arabian Calendar. The latter of them shows the places of the months in relation to the solar year at the period when they received the names by which they are here designated.
THE QUARTERS. THE SIX SEASONS. OLDER NAMES. LATER NAMES.
Together called by some AlX-itaMCu and Alr-abiyEu. Alr-abiyEu: Alxariyfu Autumn. Sept. Alxariyfu
Together called by some AlX-itaMCu and Alr-abiyEu. Alr-abiyEu: Alxariyfu Autumn. Oct. Alxariyfu
Together called by some AlX-itaMCu and Alr-abiyEu. Alr-abiyEu: Alxariyfu Autumn. Nov. Alxariyfu
Together called by some AlX-itaMCu and Alr-abiyEu. Alr-abiyEu: Alxariyfu Autumn. Nov. AlX-itaMCu
Together called by some AlX-itaMCu and Alr-abiyEu. Alr-abiyEu: Alxariyfu Autumn. Dec. AlX-itaMCu
Together called by some AlX-itaMCu and Alr-abiyEu. AlX-itaMCu Winter. Dec. AlX-itaMCu
Together called by some AlX-itaMCu and Alr-abiyEu. AlX-itaMCu Winter. Jan. AlX-itaMCu
Together called by some AlX-itaMCu and Alr-abiyEu. AlX-itaMCu Winter. Jan. Alr-abiyEu AlOaw-alu or rabiyEu AlkalaOi
Together called by some AlX-itaMCu and Alr-abiyEu. AlX-itaMCu Winter. Feb. Alr-abiyEu AlOaw-alu or rabiyEu AlkalaOi
Together called by some AlX-itaMCu and Alr-abiyEu. AlX-itaMCu Winter. Mar. Alr-abiyEu AlOaw-alu or rabiyEu AlkalaOi
Together called by some AlS-ayofu. AlS-ayofu: Alr-abiyEu Spring. Mar. AlS-ayofu
Together called by some AlS-ayofu. AlS-ayofu: Alr-abiyEu Spring. Apr. AlS-ayofu
Together called by some AlS-ayofu. AlS-ayofu: Alr-abiyEu Spring. May AlS-ayofu
Together called by some AlS-ayofu. AlS-ayofu: Alr-abiyEu Spring. May AlqayoZu
Together called by some AlS-ayofu. AlS-ayofu: Alr-abiyEu Spring. June AlqayoZu
Together called by some AlS-ayofu. AlqayoZu: AlS-ayofu Summer. June AlqayoZu
Together called by some AlS-ayofu. AlqayoZu: AlS-ayofu Summer. July AlqayoZu
Together called by some AlS-ayofu. AlqayoZu: AlS-ayofu Summer. July Alr-abiyEu Alv-aAniI or rabiyEu Alv-imaAri
Together called by some AlS-ayofu. AlqayoZu: AlS-ayofu Summer. Aug. Alr-abiyEu Alv-aAniI or rabiyEu Alv-imaAri
Together called by some AlS-ayofu. AlqayoZu: AlS-ayofu Summer. Sept. Alr-abiyEu Alv-aAniI or rabiyEu Alv-imaAri
THE MONTHS. THE PERIODS OF RAIN.
11. cuw AlqaEodapi Sept. 1. AlwasomiI Alr-abiyE
12. cuw AlHaj-api Oct. 1. AlwasomiI Alr-abiyE
1. AlmuHar-amu Nov. 1. AlwasomiI Alr-abiyE
2. SafarN Dec. 1. AlwasomiI Alr-abiyE
2. SafarN Dec. 2. AlX-atawiI-u Alr-abiyE
3. Xahoru rabiyEK AlOaw-alu Jan. 2. AlX-atawiI Alr-abiyE
4. Xahoru rabiyEK AlMxiru Feb. 2. AlX-atawiI Alr-abiyE
4. Xahoru rabiyEK AlMxiru Feb. 3. Ald-afaYiI-u Alr-abiyE
5. jumaAdaI AlOuwlaI Mar. 3. Ald-afaYiI-u Alr-abiyE
5. jumaAdaI AlOuwlaI Mar. 4. AlS-ayofu
6. jumaAdaI AlMxirapu Apr. 4. AlS-ayofu
7. rajabN May 4. AlS-ayofu
7. rajabN May AlHamiymu Mostly Dry.
8. XaEobaAnu June AlHamiymu Mostly Dry.
9. ramaDaAnu July AlHamiymu Mostly Dry.
9. ramaDaAnu July Alxariyfu Mostly Dry.
10. Xaw-aAlN Aug. Alxariyfu Mostly Dry.
10. Sept. Alxariyfu Mostly Dry.
it is also applied to the time, or period, of the reign, rule, prefecture, or the like, of a man: [and to the life-time of a man:] with the philosophers, it signifies the measure of the motion of the ninth (or greatest) sphere (Alfalak AlOaTolas): (TA:) [and there are various other explanations belonging to the conventional language of the schools, not to the proper language of the Arabs: (see the “Dict. of the Technical Terms used in the Sciences of the Musalmans:”)] the pl. (of zamanN, Mṣb) is OazomaAnN and OazomunN and ( that of zamaAnN, Mṣb) OazominapN. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.) [The dim. of zamanN, i. e. zumayonN, see below.] In the following trad., UicaA taqaAraba Alz-amaAnu↓ lamo takado ruWyaA AlmuWomini takocibu [When the time becomes contracted, the dream of the believer will scarcely ever, or never, be false], what is meant is the end of time; and the approach of the resurrection; because when a thing becomes little, its extremities contract: or what is meant is the day's and the night's becoming equal; for the interpreters of dreams assert that the times [of dreams] most true of interpretation are the season of the breaking forth of the blossoms and that of the ripening of the fruit, which is when the day and the night become equal: or what is meant is the coming forth of El-Mahdee, when the year will be like the month, and the month like the week, and the week like the day, and the day like the hour, deemed short because deemed delightful: (Ḳ in art. qrb:) or it alludes to the shortness of lives and the scantiness of blessings. (TA in that art.) In another trad. it is said, kaAnato taOotiynaA OazomaAna xadiyjapa, meaning [She used to come to us] in the life-time [lit. times] of Khadeejeh. (TA.) And one says also, maA laqiytuhu muco zamanapK↓, meaning mc zamaAnK↓ [i. e. I have not met him for a long time past: but in this case, accord. to the more approved usage, one should say muco zamanapN and muco zamaAnN, or munocu zamanapK and munocu zamaAnK]. (Lḥ, Ḳ,* TA.) (For authorities, and further information, see the words here mentioned, and more particularly nawoCN and rabiyEN; under the latter of which it is said that the third and last of the Six Seasons are called by some, respectively, Alr-abiyEu Alv-aAniI and Alr-abiyEu AlOaw-alu; and also that the appellations of the 3rd and 4th months are differently pronounced by different persons; and that some exclude the wasomiI- from the rains called Alr-abiyEu: and for the Calendar of the Mansions of the Moon, see manaAzilu Alqamari, in art. nzl.) The months are said to have received the names here given to them from Kiláb Ibn-Murrah, an ancestor of Moḥammad, about two centuries before El-Islám. These months were lunar; and from this period, with the view of adapting their year to the solar, the Arabs added a month, which they called Aln-asiIoCu, at the end of every three years, until they were forbidden to do so by the Ḳur-án (ch. ix.): but the months still retrograded through the seasons, though much more slowly. The abolition of the intercalation was proclaimed by Moḥammad at the pilgrimage in the tenth year of the Flight.

zaminN (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ) and zamiynN↓, (Ḳ, TA,) applied to a man, (Ṣ, Mṣb, TA,) Having, or affected with, a malady of long continuance; (Mgh, Mṣb, TA;*) as also muzomanN↓; (Ḥar p. 182;) or crippled, or deprived of the power to move or to stand or to walk, by disease, or by a protracted disease: (TA:) or having what is termed zamaAnapN [expl. below], i. e. EaAhapN: (Ḳ, TA:) or afflicted [with what is so termed]: (Ṣ:) pl. zaminuwna, (Ḳ, TA,) of the former, (TA,) and zamonaI, (Mṣb, Ḳ, TA,) [likewise] of the former, (Mṣb,) or of the latter, as also zamanapN. (TA.)
[Hence,] huwa faAtiru Aln-aXaATi zaminu Alr-agobapi ‡ [He is remiss in respect of briskness or promptness, powerless in respect of desire]. (TA.)
zumonapN: see zamanN, second sentence.
zamanapN A space, or period, or a long space or period, of time. (TA.) See also zamanN, last sentence.
zamaAnN: see zamanN, third sentence, and again in two places in the latter part of the paragraph.
zamiynN: see zaminN.

zumayonN [dim. of zamanN]. You say, laqiytuhu caAta Alz-umayoni, meaning thereby taraAxiI Alwaqoti; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) [i. e. I met him some time ago;] like as one says caAta AlEuwayomi, meaning bayona AlOaEowaAmi: (Ṣ:) or meaning fiI saAEapK lahaA OaEodaAdN [in a time consisting of some, or several, subdivisions]: (TA:) or caAta Alz-umayoni means muco valaAvapN OazomaAnK [three seasons ago; or, app., three or more, to ten; (agreeably with an explanation of caAta AlEuwayomi voce cuw;) by AzmAn being app. meant periods of two, or three, or six, months]; (T in art. cuw;) and the like is said by IAạr. (TA in art. SbH.)
zamaAnapN an inf. n. of zamina [q. v.]. (Ṣ,* Mṣb, Ḳ.)

[Used as a simple subst.] it signifies also A disease, or an evil affection, syn. MfapN, (Ṣ,) or EaAhapN, (Ḳ,) in animals: (Ṣ:) [and particularly, in a man, a disease of long continuance: or such as cripples, or deprives of the power to move or to stand or to walk: (see zamina and zaminN:)] or want of some one or more of the limbs, or members; and privation of the powers, or faculties. (Ḥar p. 315.) And i. q. dahorN [app. as meaning An evil event or accident, a misfortune, or a calamity]. (KL.)
Also Love. (Ḳ.)
saAEapN zamaAniy-apN [A while; an indefinite short time; as distinguished from saAEapN falakiy-apN, which is an astronomical hour: and so, often, saAEapN alone.]
muzomanN: see zaminN.
muzominN Of long continuance; of long standing; over which a long time has past. (TA.) [You say maMCN muzominN Stale water.] And suEaAlN muzominN [Chronic cough]. (Ḳ voce maSoTakaA.)
Q. 1: see the next paragraph.
Q. 4. Aizomahar-ato They (the stars) shone, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and were intensely bright. (TA.)
It (the eye) became red by reason of anger, (Ḳ,) on the occasion of some distressing event; (TA;) as also zamoharato↓. (AZ, Ṣ, Ḳ.)
Azmhr- It (the face) grinned, so as to display the teeth; or became contracted, with a stern, an austere, or a morose, look. (Ḳ.)
It (a day) became intensely cold. (Ḳ.)

zamohariyrN Intense cold. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) Such is prepared by God as a punishment for the unbelievers in the latter state. (TA.) In the Ḳur lxxvi. 13, zamohariyrFA means Hurting cold: (Bḍ:) or [simply] cold: (Jel:) or, accord. to some, it there has the meaning next following. (Bḍ, Jel.)
The moon; (Ḳ;) in the dial of Teiyi. (TA.)
muzomahir-N Laughing so as to show the teeth: (Ḳ:) from the likeness to the shining of stars. (TA.)
Angry: (Ḳ:) or violently angry. (Ṣ.)

hom.sense: 1: see 4, in five places.

zan-a EaSabuhu, [aor., accord. to rule, _i, or the sec. pers. may be zaninota, and the aor. _a {yazonanu}, and the inf. n., in this case, rananN, which see below, but the TḲ makes its aor. to be _u, and the inf. n. zan-N,] His sinews dried up. (Ḳ.)
zan-a facan-a means Hqn fqTr [which may be rendered He kept in, or retained, his urine, and then dribbled it, or his urine was kept in, or retained, and then dribbled]. (TA. [See zin-iynN.])

entry.sense:
4. Oazonanotuhu I thought him to possess good or evil; as also zananotuhu↓,, aor. _u {yazonunu}, inf. n. zan-N: or both mean I imputed, or attributed, to him good or evil: (Mṣb:) or zan-a↓ fulaAnFA bixayorK or biXar-K he thought such a one to possess good or evil; like Oazan-ahu; syn.
