[And hence, zaAwiyapu AlEaw-aMCi The star γ of Virgo; AlEaw-aMCu being composed of four stars, γ, δ, ε and η, of Virgo, disposed nearly in the form of a capital L, with ε, δ, γ from top to bottom and η to the right.]
In a saying cited voce raAwiyapN, the pl. zawaAyaA is used as meaning Houses, or tents. (T in art. rwI.)

[And in the present day, the term zaAwiyapN is also applied to A small mosque, or chapel: and in some instances, a building of this kind, thus called, serves as a hospice, or an asylum for poor Muslims, students and others; like ribaATN.]
1. zuI-a, or ziI-a: see art. zw.
2. zay-ayotu: see 2 in art. zwI, in two places.
5. tazay-aA: see 5 in art. zwI.
zaIo: see zaAIN, in art. zwI.
ziI ziI an onomatopoeia significant of The sound of the jinn, or genii. (TA.) [See also ziyzamN and ziyziymN, in art. zm.]
zaI-N: see zaAIN, in art. zwI.
ziI-N: see art. zwI.
zuyay-apN: see art. zwI.

Oazoyabu is of the measure OafoEalu, (Ṣ,) like OaHomaru: (Ḳ:) or, as some say, of the measure faEoyal; but this is a weak assertion, for it is said that there is no Arabic word of this measure; maroyamu being a foreign proper name, and DahoyaO being disputed. (MF, TA.) [In some of its senses it is an epithet, and used as such: in some, app. an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant: and in some, a simple subst.: but in all its senses it is imperfectly decl.; and therefore seems to be originally an epithet.]
Brisk, lively, sprightly, agile, or quick. (Ḳ.)
A man who walks with short steps: (TA:) and short in stature and in step; (Ḳ, TA;) likewise applied to a man. (TA.)

Ignoble, base, or base-born. (Ḳ.) The offspring of fornication or adultery; or the offspring of fornication, begotten on a slave. (Abu-l-Mekárim, TA.) One whose origin, or lineage, is suspected; or an adopted son; or one who claims as his father a person who is not his father; or who is claimed as a son by a person who is not his father; syn. daEiI-N. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)
A devil: (Ḳ:) accord. to some, a dial. var. of Oazab-u. (TA.)
The hedge-hog. (IAạr, Ḳ.)
A disagreeable, a disapproved, or an abominable, thing or affair. (Ḳ.)
A calamity, or misfortune. (Ḳ.)
Much water: (AA, Ṣ:) and so Oacoyabu. (Ḳ in art. cyb.)

[A south-easterly wind; i. e.] the [wind termed] nakobaMC [q. v.] that blows between the SabaA and the januwb: (Ṣ, M, Ḳ:) or the south wind, or a southerly wind; syn. januwbN; (M, Ḳ;) of the dial. of Hudheyl; so affirm Mbr in his “Kámil” and IF and Et-Tarábulusee: IAth says that the people of Mekkeh use this appellation much; and it is related to be God's name for what men call the jnwb: Sh says that the people of El-Yemen, and those who voyage upon the sea between Juddah and 'Adan, cali the jnwb by the name of AlOazoyabu, and know not any other name for it; and that is because it is boisterous, and stirs up the sea, turning it upsidedown: [whence it seems to mean the boisterous, or violent:] ISh says that caAtu Oazoyaba signifies any violent wind. (L,TA.)
[Hence it appears that it signifies also Violence.]
Also Enmity. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

And Briskness, liveliness, sprightliness, agility, or quickness: (ISk, Ṣ, Ḳ, TA:) [see also Oacoyabu:] it is fem.: one says, mar-a fulaAnN walahu Oazoyabu munokarapN [Such a one passed having a disapproved briskness,, &c.]: this is said when one passes quickly by reason of briskness, &c. (ISk, Ṣ.)
And Fear, or fright: (AZ, Ṣ, Ḳ:) and so Oacoyabu. (Ḳ in art. cyb.) One says, OaxacaniI mino fulaAnK AlOazoyabu [Fear, or fright, arising from such a one, seized me]. (AZ, Ṣ.)

1. zaAtahu, aor. yaziytuhu, [inf. n. zayotN,] He anointed him, or it, with zayot, i. e. oil of the zayotuwn [or olive]. (Mṣb.) You say, zit-N, meaning I anointed my head, and the head of another, with oil of the zytwn. (L.)

And zit-uhu, (Lḥ, Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. Oaziytuhu, (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA, in the CK Aazit-uh, and so in my MṢ. copy of the Ḳ,) inf. n. zayotN, (Ḳ,) I put zayot [i. e. olive-oil] into it; namely, the food; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) or the crumbled bread: or I prepared it therewith: (TA:) or I moistened it, or stirred it about, or moistened and mixed it, with zyt; namely, bread, and crumbled bread. (Lḥ, TA.)
And zaAtahumo (Lḥ, Ṣ, Ḳ, TA, in the CK [erroneously] zaOatahumo) He fed them with zayot: (Lḥ, Ḳ:) or he made zyt to be the seasoning of their food. (Ṣ.)
2. zay-atahumo He furnished them with zayot [i. e. olive-oil] for travelling-provision; (Lḥ, Ṣ, A;) agreeably with a general rule relating to verbs similar to this in meaning. (Lḥ, TA.)

4. OazaAtuwA (in the CK [erroneously] AazoAatuwA) They had much zayot [i. e. olive-oil]; their zayot became much; (Lḥ, Ḳ;) agreeably with a general rule relating to verbs similar to this in meaning. (Lḥ, TA.)
8. AizodaAta [so in the TA and in my MṢ copy of the Ḳ; in the CK, erroneously, AizodaOata;] He anointed himself with zayot [i. e. olive-oil]. (Ḳ.)
10. AstzAt He sought, or demanded, zayot [i. e. olive-oil]. (Ḳ.) You say, jaAWuwA yasotaziytuwna They came asking for zayot as a gift; (Ṣ, L;) or seeking, or demanding, zyt. (A.)

zayotN The oil, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) or expressed juice, (M, TA,) or mux- [i. e. best, or choicest, of the constituents], (A, TA,) of the zayotuwn [or olive]. (Ṣ, M, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ.) [In the present day it is applied to Any oil.]

zayotuwnN [The olive-tree;] a certain kind of tree, (Mṣb, Ḳ,*) well known, (Ṣ, Mṣb,) whence zayot is obtained; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) [a tree] of the kind called EiDaAh; (AḤn, Mgh, TA;) Aṣ says, on the authority of ʼAbd-El-Melik Ibn-Sálih Ibn-ʼAlee, that a single tree of this kind lasts thirty thousand years; and that every tree of this kind in Palestine was planted by the ancient Greeks who are called the Yoonánees: (TA:) and the fruit of that tree: (Mgh:) or it has the latter signification, and is tropically applied to the tree: or it properly has both of these significations: (TA:) [it is a coll. gen. n.:] n. un. with p {zayotuwnapN}: (Ṣ, TA:) accord. to some, the n is a radical letter, and the I is augmentative, because they said ArD ztnp [i. e. OaroDN zatinapN, like OaroDN EaDihapN from AlEiDaAhu], meaning “a land in which are zayotuwn;” so that the measure is fayoEuwlN; and if so, its proper place is art. ztn. (TA.) Respecting the phrase in the Ḳur xcv. l, waAlt-iyni waAlz-ayotuwni, see tiynN.
[zayotuwnu baniI UisoraAYiyla Lapis Judaicus: so called because resembling an olive in shape, and found in Judæa.]
[zayotuwniI-N Of, or relating to, the olive: olivecoloured.]
zay-aAtN One who sells, or expresses, zayot [i. e. olive-oil, and, vulgarly, any oil]. (TA.)
[Hence,] jaMCa fulaAnN fiI viyaAbi zay-aAtK † Such a one came in dirty clothes. (A.)
maziytN and mazoyuwtN↓ Food into which zayot [i. e. olive-oil] has been put: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) or prepared therewith. (TA.)
mazoyuwtN: see what next precedes.
muzodaAtN A man anointing himself, or who anoints himself, with zayot [i. e. olive-oil]. (TA.)
muzayotiytN dim. of muzodaAtN. (TA.)

ziyj The builder's string, or line, (Ḳ in art. zwj, improperly there mentioned, TA,) which he extends to make even, thereby, the row of stones, or bricks, of the building; syn. miTomarN [q. v.]: (TA:) [also called ziyqN:] an arabicized word, (Ḳ,) from [the Pers.] ziho, signifying “a bowstring:” so in the “Shifá el-Ghaleel.” (TA.)

Also, as is said in the “Mefáteeh el-'Uloom,” [An astronomical almanac; or a set of astronomical tables;] a book, or writing, containing stellar calculations, year by year: in which sense, likewise, it is an arabicized word, from the Pers. ziho: pl. ziyajapN. (TA.)
And The science of astronomy, or of the celestial sphere. (TA.)

zaAYijapN A four-sided, or round, scheme, made to exhibit the horoscope, or places [or configurations] of the stars at the time of a birth:
an astrological term [arabicized from the Pers. zaAyoJaho]: so in the “Shifá el-Ghaleel,” from the “Mefáteeh el- 'Uloom,” by Er-Rázee. (TA.)

1. zaAHa, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) aor. yaziyHu, inf. n. zayoHN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and zuyuwHN (MA, Ḳ) and ziyuwHN (Ḳ) and zayaHaAnN; (MA, Ḳ; [in the CK, erroneously, zayoHAn;]) and AnzAH↓; (A, Ḳ;) It (a thing, Ṣ) became distant, or remote: (Ṣ, A, Ḳ:) it went, went away, passed away, or departed. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) You say, zaAHato Eil-atuhu (Ṣ, A, MA) and AnzAHt↓ (A) His pretext, pretence, or excuse, [or his malady,] became remote [or removed], or went away. (MA.) And zaAHa Ean-iI AlbaATilu What was false, or vain, ceased, passed away, or went away, from me. (TA, from a trad.)
And zaAHa, aor. as above, i. q. taOax-ara [He, or it, went back or backwards,, &c.]. (TA in art. zH.)

4. AzAHhu He made it (a thing, Ṣ) to be distant, or remote: [he removed it, did away with it, or caused it to cease:] he made it to go, go away, pass away, or depart. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) Hence the saying of El-Aạshà, qado OazaHonaA huzaAlahaA [We had caused her leanness to cease]. (Ṣ.) And OazaHotu Eil-atahu: (Ṣ, A:) AzAH Eil-atahu signifies He removed his pretext, pretence, or excuse; [or his malady;] or did away with it. (MA.)
7: see 1, in two places.
mazaAHN A place to which one [goes away, or may go away; or] removes, or may remove, far away. (Ḥam p. 329.)

hom.sense: 1. zaAda, (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. yaziydu, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb,) inf. n. ziyaAdapN (Ṣ, A,* Mṣb, Ḳ *) and zayodN, (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,*) with which are syn. ziydN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and zayadN (Ḳ) and maziydN (Ṣ, Ḳ) and zayodaAnN, which last is anomalous, like XanoMnN (Ḳ) and lay-aAnN, said to be the only instances of the kind, (TA,) all as inf. ns., (TḲ,) and so is mazaAdN, (TA,) and J adds that zuwaAdapN is mentioned by Yaạḳoob, from Ks, from El-Bekree, as syn. with ziyaAdapN, but this is a mistake, which is unfairly imputed to J by the author of the Ḳ, (MF,) [who says,] as to Alz-uwaAdapu, it is a mistranscription by J, for the words are Alz-uwaArapu and Alz-iyaArapu, [in the CK Alr-uwAdpu and Alr-iyAdpu,] with r, and without the mention of [the signification of] Aln-umuw-u, (Ḳ, TA,) It (a thing, Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb, [as, for ex.,] water, and property, A) increased, or augmented, or grew; (Ṣ, A, TA;) [and in like manner said of a man, and of any animal;] as also AizodaAda↓: (Ṣ, A, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ:) or this latter has a more intensive signification than the former, like Aikotasaba in relation to kasaba. (MF. [See also 5.]) In this sense it has a single objective complement; as in zaAda kacaA It, or he, increased, or augmented, or grew, in such a thing; as also AizodaAda↓. (TA.) [The latter is more commonly used in this manner.] You say, Aizodadotu↓ maAlFA (A, Mgh, Mṣb) [I increased in property: also] meaning I increased to myself, or for myself, property. (Mgh,* Mṣb.) And AzdAd↓ AlOamoru SuEuwbapF [The affair increased in difficulty]. (A.)

[Also It exceeded; it was, or became, redundant, or superfluous; it remained over and above. And zaAda Ealayohi It exceeded it; as also tzAyd↓.] You say, zaAda EalaI AlX-aIoCi DiEofahu [It exceeded the thing by the like thereof, or more]. (A.) And zaAda EalaI maA OaraAda [It exceeded what he desired]. (A.)
Also He gave an addition: so in the saying, mano zaAda waQzodaAda↓ faqado OarobaI He who gives an addition, and who takes it, [each of these] practises usury. (Mṣb.)
[And He added, or exaggerated.] yaziydu fiI Hadiyvihi [He adds, or exaggerates, in his narration, or talk, or discourse,] is said of a liar. (A and TA voce sar-aAjN. [See also 5.])

It is also trans.: (Mṣb:) you say, zaAdahu, aor. yaziyduhu, inf. n. ziyaAdapN, He increased it, or augmented it. (L.) And in this sense it is doubly trans.: (MF:) you say, zaAdahu Qll-ehu xayorFA, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) or maAlFA, (A,) [God increased to him, or added to him, good fortune or prosperity or the like, or property; increased, or added to, his good fortune,, &c.; or may God increase, &c.;] as also zay-adahu↓: (Ḳ:) and zaAda fiymaA Einodahu, (Ṣ,) or fiI maAlihi, (A,) [He increased, or added to, what he possessed or his possessions, or his property; or may He (i. e. God) increase, &c.]
zaAdahu also signifies He gave him an increase, or an addition, or more. (Mṣb.) See 10.

You say also, maA yaziyduka OaHadN Ealayohi [No one is more sufficient for thee than he]. (Ḳ in art. znd. [See 4 in that art.]) And laA yaziyduka Ealayohi jamalN No camel will be more sufficient for thee than he; i. q. laA yaDur-uka. (ISk, Ṣ in art. Dr [in which see other exs.].)
2. zy-d, [inf. n. tazoyiydN,] said of property, It increased, or augmented, much. (A.)
See also 1, latter part.

entry.sense: 3. zAyd OaHadu AlmutabaAyiEayoni AlMxara, inf. n. muzaAyadapN, [One of the two persons buying together outbade the other: see also 6.] (A.)
5. tzy-d It (a price, Ṣ, A) was, or became, excessive, or dear; (Ṣ, A, Ḳ;) as also tzAyd↓. (A, TA.)

He added, or exaggerated, (MA,) or lied, (Ṣ, MA, Ḳ,) in narration, or discourse. (Ṣ, MA. [See also 1, latter half.]) And He affected to exceed the due bounds in his narration, or discourse, and his speech; (TA;) he affected excess in speech, &c.; (Ḳ, TA;) i. e. in speech and in action; (TA;) as also tzAyd↓: (Ḳ:) or Alt-azay-udu fiI AlHadiyvi means the embellishing narration, or discourse, with lies, and adding in it what does not belong to it. (Ḥar p. 195.) In the verse of 'Adee cited in art. znd, the last word is tazay-adi as some relate it, or tazan-adi as others relate it. (TA.)

He went a pace exceeding that termed AlEanaq. (Ṣ, Ḳ. [See also camala, and naSaba Als-ayora, and wasaja.]) And tzy-dt She (A camel) stretched forth her neck, and went a pace exceeding that termed AlEanaq, as though she were swimming with her rider: (A, TA:) and in like manner one says of a mare, or horse. (TA.) And tzy-dt AlUibilu fiI sayorihaA The camels tasked themselves in their pace beyond their ability. (TA.)

6. tzAyd [It increased, augmented, or grew, gradually; contr. of tanaAqaSa]. See also 1. And see 5, in two places. tzAydwA EalaI Als-iloEapi [They bade, one against another, for the commodity, or article of merchandise, successively raising the price]: said of the people of a market when a commodity is sold to him who bids more than others. (L.) And tzAydwA fiI Alv-amani Hat-aI balaga munotahaAhu [They augmented the price, one outbidding another, until it attained its utmost]. (A, TA.)
8. AizodaAda [originally AizotaAda]: see 1, in four places.
Also He took an addition. (Mṣb.) See, again, 1.

Also He took in addition: so in the saying, UicaA QzodaAda Alr-aAhinu daraAhima mina Almurotahini [When the pledger takes money in addition from the receiver of the pledge]. (Mgh.) One says also, Aizodado mina Alxayori [Obtain thou, or gain thou, somewhat in addition of what is good: or it may mean seek thou, or desire thou, an increase, or addition, of what is good]. (A.) See what next follows, in two places.

10. AstzAd He sought, or desired, or demanded, an increase, an addition, or more; (A, Mgh, Mṣb;) as also AizodaAda↓; whence the saying, to a man to whom a thing has been given, halo tazodaAdu↓ Dost thou seek, or desire, or demand, more than what I have given thee? (L.)

[Hence,] huwa yasotaziydu fiI Hadiyvihi [He seeks, or desires, to add, or exaggerate, or to exceed the due bounds, or to embellish with lies and additions, in his narration, or discourse]. (A, TA. [See also 5.])

AstzAdhu He sought, or desired, or demanded, of him an increase, an addition, or more. (Mṣb, Ḳ.) You say, lawi Qsotazadotuhu lazaAdaniI↓ If I had sought, or desired, or demanded, an increase,, &c., he had given me an increase,, &c. (Mṣb.)

[And hence,] ‡ He reckoned him, or held him, to have fallen short of doing what he ought to have done, (Ṣ, A, Ḳ, TA,) and complained of him, (A, TA,) or reproved him, for a thing that he did not approve. (TA.) And kataba Uilayohi kitaAba QsotizaAdapK ‡ [He wrote to him a letter of complaint, or reproof, for his having fallen short,, &c.; requiring him to do more]. (A.)
zayodN an inf. n. of zaAda. (Ṣ, Mgh, Mṣb.)
[Hence,] humo zayodN EalaI miAYapK (Ṣ, A, L) and ziydN↓ (Ṣ, L) and ziyAadapN↓ (A) ‡ [They are more than a hundred].
ziydN an inf. n. of zaAda. (Ṣ,* Ḳ,* TḲ.)
See the next preceding paragraph.

ziyaAdapN an inf. n. of zaAda. (Ṣ, Mṣb.) Using it as an inf. n., (Mṣb,) you say, AifoEalo celika ziyaAdapF [meaning Do thou that in addition]: (Ṣ, Mṣb:) the vulgar say zaAYidapF↓, (Ṣ,) which one should not say. (Mṣb.) [Hence also,] Huruwfu Alz-iyaAdapi [The letters of augmentation; or the augmentative letters; i. e. the letters that are added to the radical letters in Arabic words]:
they are ten, and are comprised in the saying, saOalotumuwniyhaA [“Ye asked me for them”], (TA,) and in Oaloyawoma tanosaAhu [“Today thou wilt forget it”]; (Ḳ, TA;) and more than a hundred and thirty other combinations comprising them have been mentioned: (MF:) [these letters are also called zawaAYidu, of which the sing. is zaAYidapN↓.] See also zayodN.

[As a simple subst., or a subst. properly so termed, it signifies An increase, or increment; and augmentation, or augment; an addition, additament, adjunct, or accessory: an accession: excess, redundance, or superfluity: and a redundant part or portion or appertenance; a surplus; a residue: an excrescence: pl. ziyaAdaAtN and zayAYidu.]

[Hence,] UibilN kaviyrapu Alz-ayaAYidi i.e. Alz-iyaAdaAt [Camels having much increase; lit., much, or many, increases]. (Ḳ.) A poet says,
bihajomapK tamolaOu Eayona AlHaAsidi
caAti suruwHK jam-api Alz-ayaAYidi
[With a herd of forty or more camels, that fill, or glut, the eye of the envier, enjoying pasturing by themselves, having much increase]: some say, [in citing this verse,] Alz-awaAYidi, which is pl. of zaAYidapN↓; but AlzwAYd is said only in relation to the legs of a beast. (L.)

[Hence also,] ziyaAdapu Alkabidi, (so in a copy of the Ṣ, and in the A and L, and in several places in the Ḳ,) or zaAYidapu↓ Alkabidi, (so termed by Zj, and so in the T, and in two copies of the Ṣ, and in the L,) both of which are correct, (TA,) [The redundant appertenance of the liver;] a certain small piece to which the liver is attached, or suspended: (Zj, in his “Khalk el-Insán:”) or a certain small appertenance of the liver (hunay-apN minohaA SagiyrapN), at its side, going away from it (mutanaH-iyapN EanohaA): (Ṣ, L:) or a certain piece appended, or attached, to the liver (muEal-aqapN bihaA): (A:) or a certain appendage of the liver; [so I render hanapN mutaEal-iqapN minohaA, agreeably with the next preceding explanation; though it may be rendered a thing suspended from it, i.e. from the liver; or the right reading may be hnp mtEl-qp bihaA, which is virtually the same as the explanation in the A, and agreeable with what here follows: so called] because it is a redundance (taziydu) upon its upper surface: (L:) [all of these explanations seem to denote the round ligament of the liver: the Hebrew אׄתֶרֶת הַכָבֵד, in Ex. xxix. 22, literally signifies the same; like the slightly-varying appellations in Ex. xxix. 13 and Lev. iii. 4, and Lev. ix. 10: but the real meaning thereof is much disputed: the rendering of the LXX. is λοβὸς τοῦ ἤπατος; which is said to mean extrema pars hepatis: that of the Vulg., reticulum hepatis: that of our authorized Engl. Vers., the caul above the liver; (with this marginal note: “it seemeth by anatomy, and the Hebrew Doctors, to be the midriff:”) and it is remarkable that this is one of the meanings assigned to Alxilobu, which some hold to be syn. with zayaAdapu Alkabidi: (see xilobN:) Bochart (in his Hieroz. t. i., p. 498, seq.,) and Gesenius (in his Lex.) explain the Hebrew term as meaning the greater lobe of the liver: but this is hard to reconcile with the Hebrew or the Arabic; and utterly irreconcileable with the explanations given by the Arabs; among whom, it should be observed, were many of the Jewish religion, who cannot reasonably be supposed to have not known the correct meaning of a term relating to their sacrifices:] the pl. of zyAdp is zayaAYidu, (L,) and that of zAYdp↓ is zawaAYidu. (Ṣ, L.) Hence the saying, Alwaladu kabidu ciI Alwaladi wawaladu Alwaladi ziyaAdapu Alkabidi [The child is as the liver of the parent, and the grandchild is as the redundant appertenance of the liver]. (A, TA.)
zaAYidN act. part. n. of zaAda, (Mṣb,) [Increasing, augmenting, or growing.]

[Exceeding; in excess; redundant; superfluous; remaining over and above: excrescent: additional; in addition; adscititious.] You say, Oaxacotuhu bidirohamK fazaAYidFA [I took it, i. e. bought it, for a dirhem and more]. (A.) [See also the next paragraph.]
zaAYidapN [fem. of zaAYidN: and also a subst.; being transferred from the category of epithets to that of substs. by the affix p: pl. zawaAYidu]: see ziyaAdapN, in five places.

[Hence,] Alz-awaAYidu [Certain excrescences, or pendent hairs, termed] zamaEaAt, in the hinder part of the kind leg or foot. (Ḳ. [In the explanations there given, I read Alr-ijol, as in one copy, instead of Alr-aHol. It has been stated above, voce ziyaAdapN, on the authority of the L, that Alz-awaAYid is said only in relation to the legs of a beast.])
[But] cuw Alz-awaAYidi means The lion: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) by the zwAYd being mean this claws and his canine teeth and his roaring and his impetuosity. (Ṣ.)
zaAYidapu Als-aAqi The shin-bone. (L.)

[zawaAYidiI-N a rel. n. from zawaAYidu pl. of zaAYidapN; and used, app., as meaning Having something redundant; for] Saʼeed Ibn-ʼOthmán was surnamed Alz-awaAYidiI-u because he had three bayoDaAt: so they assert. (Ṣ.)

buruwdN taziydiy-apN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) and taziydiy-aAtN [alone], (Ṣ,) [Garments of the kind termed] buruwd having in them red stripes, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) to which streaks of blood are likened: (Ṣ:) so called in relation to taziyd the son of HulowaAn, the father of a tribe: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) or, as some say, taziyd the son of HayodaAn: (MF:) or from taziyd, a city, or town, of El-Yemen, in which such brwd were woven: (TA:) or, accord. to some, J and F are in error; and the truth is, that there were some merchants in Mekkeh, called banuw yaziydK, thus with I and in relation to them certain [camel-vehicles for women of the kind called] hawaAdij were termed yaziydiy-apN↓. (MF.)
mazaAdN: see mazaAdapN, in two places.

hom.sense: [It is also the pass. part. n. of zaAda, signifying Increased, or augmented; as also maziydN fiyhi.]

entry.sense: mazaAdapN [A leathern water-bag, one of a pair which is borne by a camel or other beast;] the half (XaTor) of a raAwiyap: (Mṣb in art. zwd:) [a water-bag of this kind is represented in a sketch of “Sakkàs” in my work on the Modern Egyptians:] it has two loops, and two kidney-shaped pieces of leather (kuloyataAni), the former of which are sewed to the latter: (TA voce xurobapN:) the raAwiyap consists of two mezádehs (mazaAdataAni), which are bound upon the two sides of the camel with the [cord called] riwaMC: the pl. is mazaAyidu [often written mazaAYidu]; and sometimes the Arabs elided the p, saying mazaAdN↓: (T, TA:) [both of these forms are mentioned in the Ṣ and Ḳ as pls.:] and mazaAdN↓ without p, is [also] applied to the single one (farodap [meaning the single water-skin]) which the rider attaches behind his camel's saddle, having no EazolaMC, [or spout (which is closed by means of a thong tied round it) at one of the lower extremities for pouring out the water; thus] differing from the mazaAdap: (T, TA:) or the mzAdp is a raAwiyap, [app. accord. to some who applied this latter term to a single water-bag,] (Ṣ, A, Ḳ,) or only (Ḳ) such as is composed of two skins with a third inserted between them to widen it: (AʼObeyd, Ṣ, M, A, Ḳ:) and so are the saTiyHap and the XaEiyb: (AʼObeyd, Ṣ:) or the saTyHp is made of two skins put face to face; and the mzAdp is of two skins and a half, or of three skins: (ISh, TA:) or it is [a water-bag] joined (maXoEurbap) at one side; if consisting of two faces (An xrjt mn wjhyn [i. e. of two pieces of skin whereof each forms one face or side]) it is called a XaEiyb: or it is like a rAwyp having no EazolaMC [expl. above]: AM and the author of the Mṣb and some others assert that its medial radical letter is w, and that it is from Alz-awodu, (TA,) being so called because one furnishes himself with water in it for travellingprovision: (Mṣb in art. zwd:) but this is a mistake: (TA:) it is thus called because it is enlarged by the addition of a third skin: (AO, El-Khafájee, TA:) [Fei says that] accord. to analogy it should be mizaAdapN. (Mṣb in art. zwd.)
musotazaAdN: see maziydN, in two places.
yaziydiy-apN, applied to hawaAdij: see taziydiy-apN.

2. zy-r Ald-aAb-apa He (a farrier) twisted the lip of the beast with a ziyaAr: (Ṣ in art. zwr, and TA:) and he put a ziyaAr upon the Hanak [or part beneath the chin] of the beast. (TA.) [In the present day, the instrument here mentioned is generally applied to the upper lip.]

hom.sense: ziyrN [A large water-jar, wide in the upper part and nearly pointed at the bottom;] a [vessel of the kind called] dan-: or a [vessel such as is called] Hub-, (Ḳ,) in which water is put: (TA: [but yEml is there put by mistake for yujoEalu:]) of the dial. of El-'Irák [and that of Egypt]: pl. OazoyaArN: a foreign word. (TA in art. zwr, in which, and in art. zyr, the word is mentioned in the Ḳ.)
See also art. zwr.
Also I. q. zir-N; (IAạr, TA in art. zwr;) the former r in the latter word being changed by some of the Arabs into I in this and similar instances. (Az, TA.)
[See also baSalN.]

entry.sense: zayirN, (Ṣgh, TA in art. zwr,) in the Ḳ, erroneously, zay-irN, (TA,) Angry, (IAạr, Ṣgh, Ḳ, TA,) and severing himself from his companion: (IAạr, TA:) originally zaYirN. (Az, TA.)
ziyrapN: see art. zwr.

ziyaArN [A kind of barnacle, used by a farrier;] an instrument with which a farrier twists the lip of a beast; (Ṣ in art. zwr;) a thing that is put upon the mouth of a beast when he is refractory, in order that he may become submissive. (IAth, TA. [See 2.])
See also art. zwr.
zayozafuwnN: see art. zfn.

1. zaAga, aor. yaziygu, inf. n. zayogN (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ) and zayagaAnN and zayoguwgapN (O, Ḳ) and zuyuwgN, (TA,) He, or it, (a thing, Mṣb,) declined, deviated, swerved, or turned aside, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) from the right course or direction, accord. to an explanation of zayogN by Er-Rághib; and from the truth: (TA:) and zAg, aor. yazuwgu, inf. n. zawogN, is a dial. var. thereof. (Mṣb, TA.*) In the Ḳur iii. 5, (O,) zayogN means A doubting, and a declining, or deviating, from the truth. (O, Ḳ.)

You say also, zaAgati AlX-amosu, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. taziygu, inf. n. zayogN (Mṣb, TA) and zuyuwgN, (TA,) The sun declined [from the meridian], (Ṣ,* Mṣb, Ḳ,) so that the shade turned from one side to the other. (Ṣ,* Ḳ.)

And zAg AlbaSaru, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) inf. n. zayogN, (TA,) ‡ The eye, or eyes, or the sight, became dim, or dull: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA:) so in the phrase maA zaAga AlbaSaru in the Ḳur [liii. 17]: (O, TA:) or, as some say, zaAgati AlOaboSaAru signifies the eyes turned aside from their places; as in the case of a man in fear. (TA.)
2. zay-agotu fulaAnFA, inf. n. tazoyiygN, I rectified the zayog [or declining, or deviating,, &c.,] of such a one. (Aboo-Saʼeed, O, Ḳ.*)

4. AzAghu, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) Eani AlT-ariyqi, (Ṣ, O,) inf. n. UizaAgapN, (Mṣb,) He made him to decline, deviate, swerve, or turn aside, (Ṣ, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) from the way. (Ṣ, O.) Hence, in the Ḳur [iii. 6, accord. to the usual reading], rab-anaA laA tuzigo quluwbanaA, (O, TA,) meaning O our Lord, make us not [or make not our hearts] to decline from the right way and course: make us not to err, or go astray. (TA. [See another reading in the first paragraph {1} of art. zwg.])
And He made him to fall into Alz-ayog [app. as meaning deviation from the truth, or the right way of belief or conduct]. (TA.)

falam-aA zaAguwA OazaAga Qll-ehu quluwbahumo, in the Ḳur [lxi. 5], means, accord. to Er-Rághib, And when they quitted the right way, God dealt with them according to that: (TA:) or God turned their hearts from the acceptance of the truth, and the inclining to the right course. (Bḍ.)

5. tazay-agato She (a woman) ornamented, or adorned, herself, and showed, or displayed, her finery, or ornaments, and beauties of person or form or countenance, to men, or strangers, (AZ, Ṣ, Ḳ,) and decked herself with apparel; like tazay-aqato: (AZ, TA:) IF says that its g is a substitute for n. (TA.)
6. tazaAyugN i. q. tamaAyulN, (JK, Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) An inclining towards each other, (PṢ,) accord. to some, peculiarly, (TA,) in the teeth. (JK, TA.)

zaAgN [The rook;] a small guraAb [or bird of the crow-kind], inclining to white, (O, Mgh, Ḳ, TA,) that does not eat carrion, (O, Mgh, TA,) and is allowed to be eaten; now called in Egypt the guraAb nuwHiI- [or Noachian crow]: (TA:) or a guraAb like the pigeon, black, with a dusty colour in its head; or, as some say, inclining to white; that does not eat carrion: (Mṣb in art. zwg:) or a small black guraAb, that is eaten; also called HacafN, of which the n. un. is with p {HacafapN}: (ISh, TA in art. Hcf:) [these descriptions correctly apply to different varieties of the rook; some of which are distinguished by more or less whiteness in the head and other parts: in the present day, the word is, by some, perhaps generally, erroneously applied to the carrion-crow:] Az says, “I know not whether it be Arabic or arabicized:” (Mṣb in art. zwg, and TA:) the truth is, that it is a Pers. word, [zaAgo,] arabicized; originally applied to crows (girobaAn), whether small or large; but when arabicized, applied peculiarly to one species thereof: (TA:) pl. ziygaAnN. (O, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ.)
zaAYigN Declining, deviating, swerving, or turning aside: (TA:) pl. zaAgapN, applied to a number of men, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ, TA,) i. q. zaAYiguwna, (Ṣ, O, TA,) like baAEapN meaning baAYiguwna. (O, TA.)

hom.sense: 1. zaAfa, aor. yaziyfu, (Ṣ, O, Ḳ,) inf. n. zayofN and zayafaAnN (O, Ḳ) and zuyuwfN, (TA,) said of a camel, (Ṣ, TA,) and of a man, &c., (TA,) He walked with an elegant and a proud and self-conceited gait, with an affected inclining of the body from side to side: (Ṣ, O, Ḳ:) or he went quickly, with an affected inclining of the body from side to side. (TA.) And zaAfato fiI miXoyatihaA, said of a woman, She appeared as though she were turning round, or circling, in her gait. (Z, TA.) [This is app. from what next follows.] One says of a male pigeon, zAf Einoda AlHamaAmapi He dragged the tail, and impelled his fore part with his hinder part, and turned, or circled, around the female pigeon: (Ṣ, O, L, Ḳ,* TA:) and of a female pigeon one says, taziyfu bayona yadaIi AlHamaAmi Alc-akari, meaning She walks with boldness and presumptuousness before the male pigeon. (TA.) And a poet describing a battle says of it zaAfato, meaning The hinder part thereof impelled the fore part. (L, TA.)
zAf, (Kr, TA,) inf. n. zayofN, (Kr,) said of a building, (Kr, TA,), &c., (TA,) It was, or became, high. (Kr, TA.)

zAft Ald-araAhimu, (Ṣ, MA, Mgh, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. taziyfu, (Mṣb,) inf. n. zayofN, (Mṣb,) or zuyuwfN, (Mgh, Ḳ,) for which the lawyers say ziyaAfapN, (Mgh,) The dirhems, or pieces of money, were bad: (MA, Mṣb:) or were rejected, or returned, (Mgh, Ḳ,) Ealayohi [to him], (Ṣ, Mgh, Ḳ,) because of adulterating alloy therein: (Mgh, Ḳ:) or, accord. to the M, simply, were rejected, or returned; (TA;) [and] so zuy-ifat↓. (Mgh.)
See also 2.
zAf AlHaAYiTa, (O, Ḳ,) inf. n. zayofN, (TA,) He leaped the wall; syn. qafazahu; (O, Ḳ;) said of a man. (O.)

entry.sense: 2. tazoyiyfN is said to signify primarily The separating, or setting apart, such [money] as is passable, or current, from such as is termed zaAYif: and hence, the rejecting [money], or returning [it]: and the making [it], or proving [it] to be, false, or spurious. (TA.) One says, zy-f Ald-araAhima, (Ṣ, MA, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. tazoyiyfN, (Mṣb,) He made, (MA, Ḳ,) or pronounced, (Ḳ,) or showed, (Mṣb,) the dirhems, or pieces of money, to be bad, (MA, Mṣb,) or to be such as are termed zuyuwf; (Ḳ;) as also zaAfahaA↓. (Lḥ, Ḳ.) See also 1, near the end of the paragraph.
[Hence, Alt-azoyiyfu in relation to speech, or language: see 2 in art. rml.]

And zy-fhu, (Kr, TA,) inf. n. as above, (Kr,) ‡ He made his blood to be of no account, to go for nothing, unretaliated, or uncompensated by a mulct; or made it allowable to take, or shed, his blood: (TA:) or he made him to be contemptible, ignominious, base, or vile, in the estimation of others: (Kr, TA:) from dirohamN zaAYifN “a bad dirhem, or piece of money.” (TA.)
5. tzy-ft, said of a woman, [like tzy-qt,] She ornamented, or adorned, herself. (O.)

[Accord. to Freytag, tzy-f signifies It was adulterated: and in Ḥar p. 612 it is expl. as signifying SAr zy-fA fI AHwAlh, which seems to have this or a similar meaning; zy-fA being app. a mistranscription for zayofFA or muzay-afFA.]

hom.sense: zayofN: see zaAYifN, in four places.

Also The Uiforiyz, i. e., (Kr, TA,) the Tanaf, (Kr, O, Ḳ, TA,) [meaning the coping, or ledge, or cornice,] that protects a wall, (O, Ḳ, TA,) surrounding the upper part of the wall, (Kr,) or surrounding the walls at the top of a house: (TA:) or, as some say, (O, in the Ḳ “and,”) the steps, or stairs, of places of ascent: (O, Ḳ:) or, as some say, (Kr, O, in the Ḳ “and,”) i. q. XurafN [meaning acroterial ornaments forming a single member of a cresting of a wall, or of the crown of a cornice]: n. un. with p {zayofapN}. (Kr, O, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: zay-aAfN, and with p {zay-aAfapN}: see the next paragraph, in three places.

hom.sense:
zaAYifN One who walks in the manner described in the first sentence of this art.; as also zayofN↓, which is an inf. n. used as an epithet: (TA:) [and so zay-aAfN↓, but properly in an intensive sense:] and zay-aAfapN↓ a she-camel proud and self-conceited [in her gait]. (Ṣ.)
Hence, (TA,) Alz-aAYifu signifies The lion; as also Alz-ay-aAfu↓; (O, Ḳ;) but the latter has an intensive meaning: (TA:) so called because of his proud and selfconceited walk. (O, TA.)

Also, and zayofN↓, (Ṣ, Kr, Mgh, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) the latter an inf. n. used as an epithet, (Mṣb,) or, accord. to IDrd, this is a vulgar term, (O,) or bad, (Ḳ,) applied to a dirhem, or piece of money, (Ṣ, Mgh, O, Mṣb, Ḳ,) to gold and to silver, (Ḥar p. 369, referring to the latter word,) Bad: (Kr, Mṣb, and Ḥar ubi suprà:) or such as are rejected, or returned, because of adulterating alloy therein: (Mgh, O, Ḳ:) or, as some say, such as are less bad than what are termed bahoraj, being such as are rejected by [the officers of] the government-treasury; whereas the bhrj are such as are rejected by the merchants, or traders: (Mgh:) the pl. is ziyaAfN and OazoyaAfN, (O, Ḳ,) [the latter a pl. of pauc.,] or the pl. of zayofN↓ is zuyuwfN, and the pl. of zaAYifN is zuy-afN: (Mgh,* Mṣb:) accord. to some, the zuyuwf are such as are done over with a compound of quicksilver and sulphur. (Mṣb.) [It is implied in the Mṣb that zayofN↓ is the more common term, though, as has been stated above, it is said by IDrd to be vulgar: and it is also applied to human beings: for ex.,] a poet says,
taraI Alqawoma OaXobaAhFA UicaA nazaluwAmaEFA
wafiI Alqawomi zayofN mivolu zayofi Ald-araAhimi
[Thou seest the people to be likes when they alight together; but among the people are bad like the bad of dirhems.] (TA.)

entry.sense: 5. tzy-q He ornamented, or adorned, himself, and applied kuHol to his eyes: (Ḳ:) or tzy-qt, said of a woman, (JK, Ṣ, O,) like tzy-gt, (Ṣ, O,) she ornamented, or adorned, herself, (JK, Ṣ, O,) and applied kuHol to her eyes, (Ṣ, O, TA,) and some add, and decked herself with apparel: accord. to Z, it is from Alzwq; [app. meaning Alz-uwaqu, syn. with Alz-awuwqu; or from zawaAqN, (see 2 in art. zwq, last sentence,) so that it is originally tzw-qt;] or it may be from zyq, [i. e. ziyqN,] with I, [meaning the “builder's string, or line, with which he makes even the rows of stones, or bricks, and with which the building is proportioned,”] because she who embellishes herself makes her state right by adornment. (TA.)

ziyqN The part, of a shirt, that surrounds the neck: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) the collar of a shirt: (KL:) or the border of a collar; (MA;) or the hemmed border of the opening at the neck and bosom of a shirt: (JK:) [app. an arabicized word from the Pers. ziho:] J, holding the medial radical to be [originally] w, has mentioned it in art. zwq. (TA.)
[Hence, † The surrounding edge of the eyelid. (See HitaArN.)]
And The string, or line, of the builder, [also called ziyjN, q. v., with which he makes even the rows of stones, or bricks, and] with which the building is proportioned. (JK.)

ziyqu AlX-ayaATiyni, expl. by Lth as meaning A certain thing that flies in the air, called by the Arabs luEaAbu AlX-amosi, [i. e. the fine filmy cobwebs termed gossamer,] is a mistake for riyqu AlX-ayaATiyni, with raMC. (Az, O, Ḳ.*)

hom.sense: 1. zaAlahu is syn. with OazaAlahu, q. v. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ.)

zAl zawaAlahu, or zAl Qll-ehu zawaAlahu; and zAl zawaAlahaA: see zawaAlN, in art. zwl. And ziyla zawiyluhu and zawiyluhaA and zawaAluhu: see zawiylN, in art. zwl; and for the first, see also zawaAlN, in that art.

zilotuhu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) aor. Oaziyluhu, inf. n. zayolN, (Ṣ,) [first pers. of zaAlahu,] signifies also I put it, or set it, apart, away, or aside; removed it; or separated it; (Ṣ, Ḳ, TA;) namely, a thing, (Ṣ, TA,) from another thing: (TA:) and AzAlhu↓ also signifies he separated it; like zaAlahu. (TA.) See also 4. One says, zilo DaOonaka mino miEozaAka Remove, or separate, thy sheep from thy goats. (Ṣ,* TA.) And zilotuhu falamo yanozalo↓ I separated it [partly], but it did not become [wholly] separated. (Ṣ, Ḳ.)

maA zaAla yafoEalu kacaA (Ṣ in art. zwl, and Mṣb,) is like maA bariHa, both in its [original] measure, [which is maA zayila accord. to most authorities,] and in its meaning, which is [He ceased not to do such a thing, or he continued to do such a thing, for it denotes] the continuing to do a thing [as in the ex. above], and a constant state [as in the phrase maA zaAla zayodN qaAYimFA Zeyd ceased not to be, or continued to be, standing]: (Mṣb:) [using the first pers.,] one says, maA zilotu OafoEaluhu [and maA zalotu, as appears from what follows], meaning maA bariHotu [i. e. I ceased not to do it, or I continued to do it], (Ḳ,) aor. OazaAlu [supposing the measure of the pret. to be originally faEilotu] (Mṣb, Ḳ) and Oaziylu [supposing the measure of the pret. to be originally fEalotu]: (Ḳ:) the verb is seldom [in the Mṣb “never”] used without a negative particle: (Az, TA:) one says zilotu OafoEalu meaning maA zilotu OafoEalu; but this is rare: (Ḳ:) and maA ziyla yafoEalu kacaA, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) a phrase used by some of the Arabs, (Mṣb,) mentioned by Akh, (Ṣ, TA,) as is meant in [some of the copies of] the Ḳ by the addition Eanohu, though Akh is not mentioned in what precedes. (TA.) The verb in maA zaAla and laA yazaAlu is used in the manner of kaAna in governing the noun [which is its subject] in the nom. case and the predicate in the accus. case [as in maA zaAla zayodN qaAYimFA, expl. above]; but one may not say, maA zaAla zayodN Uil-aA munoTaliqFA, like as one says, maA kaAna zayodN Uil-aA munoTaliqFA; for zaAla denotes a negation, [meaning he did not a thing, or he was not doing, &c.,] and maA and laA denote negation, and two negations together denote an affirmation; so that mA zAl is affirmative like kaAna; and as one may not say, kaAna zayodN Uil-aA manoTaliqFA, so one may not say, maA zaAla zayodN Uil-aA munoTaliqFA. (Er-Rághib, TA.) One says also, maA zilotu bizayodK Hat-aI faEala celika and maA zilotu wazayodFA [I desisted not with Zeyd until he did that], (Sb, Ḳ,* TA,) inf. n. ziyaAlN. (Sb, TA.) lamo yazalo [He, or it, has not ceased to be, &c., i. e., has ever been, &c., (see OazalN,)] is said of God, as meaning He has never been nonexistent; and laA yazaAlu, said of Him, He will never be nonexistent. (Kull p. 31.) This [incomplete i. e. non-attributive] verb and the complete [i. e. attributive, which signifies “it ceased to be” or “exist,”, &c.,] differ in their components; the latter being composed of l w z; and this, of l I z: or the incomplete is altered from the complete; being made to be with kesr to its medial radical letter, [for it is generally held to be from zayila or zawila,] after its having been [originally zawala,] with fet-ḥ: or it is from zaAlahu, aor. yaziyluhu, meaning “he put it,” or “set it, apart,”, &c. (Ḳ.)

2. zy-lhu, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) inf. n. tazoyiylN, (Ṣ,) He separated it [i. e. acompany of men, or an assemblage of things,] much (Fr, Az, Ṣ,* Ḳ,* TA,) [or greatly, or widely; or dispersed it;] differing in degree from zaAlahu like as may-azahu does from maAzahu. (TA.) Hence, fazay-alonaA bayonahumo [And we will separate them widely, one from another], (Fr, Az, Ṣ, Ḳ, TA,) in the Ḳur [x. 29]; (Fr, Az, Ṣ, TA;) where some read fazaAyalonaA↓ bayonahumo; like laA tuSaE-iro and lA tuSaAEiro [in the Ḳur xxxi. 17]. (Fr, Az, TA.) [See also an ex. in a verse cited voce duwna.] zay-alotu is of the measure faE-alotu because its inf. n. is as above; for were it fayoEalotu, one would say zay-alapN [of the measure fayoEalapN]. (Ṣ.)
tazoyiylN is also [said to be] an [irreg.], inf. n. of 5, q. v. (Lḥ, Ḳ.)

entry.sense: 3. zAylhu, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. muzaAyalapN and ziyaAlN, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) He separated himself from him. (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ. [See also 1 in art. zwl, last signification.]) One says, xaAliTuwA Aln-aAsa wazaAyiluwhumo, meaning [Mix ye with men in familiar, or social, intercourse, and] separate yourselves from them in deeds, or actions. (TA.)
zaAyalatohu biwajohihaA She veiled her face from him. (IAạr on the authority of Ibn-Ez-Zubeyr, TA in art. bzr.) [See also 6.]
zaAyalonaA bayonahumo: see 2. And see also what next follows {4}.

4. AzAlhu (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ) mino makaAnihi (Ṣ) or Eano makaAnihi, (Ḳ,) inf. n. UizaAlapN (Ḳ) and UizaAlN; (Lḥ, Ḳ;) and zaAlahu↓, (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ, and Ḥar p. 393,) aor. yaziyluhu, (Ṣ, Ḳ, and Ḥar ubi suprà,) or yazaAluhu, like yanaAluhu, (Mṣb,) inf. n. zayolN, (Ṣ, Ḳ, Ḥar,) or ziyaAlN; (Mṣb;) both signify the same; (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ;) He removed it [from its place; as the former is expl. in art. zwl]; (Mṣb in explanation of both, and Ḥar ubi suprà in explanation of the latter;) and so zaAyalahu↓, of which the primary signification is that first assigned to it in the next preceding paragraph. (Ḥar ubi suprà.) See also 1, fourth sentence. [And see 4 in art. zwl.]

5. tzy-lwA, (Ṣ,* Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. tazay-ulN and tazoyiylN↓, (Ḳ,) the latter [irreg., being properly inf. n. of 2,] of the dial. of El-Ḥijáz, mentioned by Lḥ; (TA;) and tzAylwA↓, inf. n. tazaAyulN; (Ḳ;)
i. q. tafar-aquwA [i. e. They became separated much, or greatly, or widely; or became dispersed: or rather, the former verb, being quasi-pass. of 2, has this meaning; and the latter verb, as quasi-pass. of 3, means simply they became separated, one from another]: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) [for] Alt-azaAyulu↓ signifies Alt-abaAyunu: (Ṣ, Ḳ:) tzy-lwA is syn. with tamay-azuwA: thus in the Ḳur [xlviii. 25], where it is said, lawo tazay-aluwA laEac-abonaA Ql-aciyna kafaruwA [Had they been widely separated, one from another, we had assuredly punished those who disbelieved]: (Mṣb,* TA:) and some here read tazaAyaluwA↓. (Bḍ.) [See also 7.]
6: see 5, in three places.

[Hence,] Alt-azaAyulu signifies also AlAiHotiXaAmu; (Ḳ, TA;) a tropical meaning: (TA:) one says, tzAyl Eanohu, meaning AiHotaXamahu [i. e. ‡ He was, or became, abashed at him]: (O, TA:) because the muHotaXim separates himself, and shrinks, from another. (TA.)
[See also mutazaAyilapN, whence it seems that one says, of a woman, tazaAyalato, meaning She veiled her face from men: see likewise 3.]

7. AnzAl It was, or became, put, or set, apart, away, or aside; removed; or separated; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) Eanohu [from him, or it]. (TA.) One says, zilotuhu falamo yanozalo: see 1. (Ṣ, Ḳ.) [See also 5. And see 7 in art. zwl.]
zayalN Width between the thighs; (Ṣ, Ḳ;) like fajajN. (Ṣ.)
OazoyalN, (Ḳ,) or Oazoyalu Alfaxicayoni, occurring in a trad., (TA,) Having the thighs wide apart. (Ḳ, TA.)
mizoyaAlN: see the next preceding paragraph.
Aljyb AlmuzaAyilu [a mistranscription for AlHabiybu] means AlbaAYinu [i. e. The beloved, or the friend, who is in a state of separation, or disunion]. (TA.)
mutazaAyilapN A woman who veils her face from men. (IAạr on the authority of Ibn-Ez-Zubeyr, TA in this art. and in art. brz.)

1. zaAnahu, (Ṣ, MA, Mṣb, Ḳ,) aor. yaziynuhu, (Mṣb,) inf. n. zayonN; (MA, Mṣb, KL, TA;) and zy-nhu↓, (Ṣ, MA, Mṣb, Ḳ,) inf. n. tazoyiynN; (Mṣb, KL, TA;) and OazaAnahu↓, (Mṣb, Ḳ,) and Oazoyanahu↓, (Ḳ,) which is its original form, (TA,) inf. n. UizaAnapN; (Mṣb;) signify the same; (Ṣ, MA, Mṣb, Ḳ;) He, or it, adorned, ornamented, decorated, decked, bedecked, garnished, embellished, beautified, or graced, him, or it. (MA, KL, PṢ: [and the like is indicated in the Ṣ and Mṣb and Ḳ.]) [zaAnahu said of a quality, and of an action, and of a saying, is best rendered It adorned him, or graced him, or was an honour to him; contr. of XaAnahu; as is indicated in the Ṣ and Ḳ: and sometimes means it was his pride: and zy-nhu↓ means as expl. above: and he embellished it, dressed it up, or trimmed it; said in this sense as relating to language: and he embellished it, or dressed it up, namely, an action, &c. to another (ligayorihi); often said in this sense of the Devil; (as in the Ḳur vi. 43, &c.;) i. e. he commended it to him:] zaAnahu kacaA and zy-nhu↓ [Such a thing adorned him,, &c.,] are expl. as said when one's excellence [faDoluhu, as I read for fElh, an evident mistranscription,] appears either by speech or by action: and tazoyiynu↓ Qll-ehi liloOaXoyaMCi [God's adorning,, &c., of things] is sometimes by means of his creating them muzay-anap [i. e. adorned, &c.]; and tazoyiynu↓ Aln-aAsi [The adorning,, &c., of men], by their abundance of property, and by their speech, i. e. by their extolling Him. (Er-Rághib, TA.) One says, zaAnahu AlHusonu [Beauty adorned, or graced, him, or it]. And Mejnoon says,
fayaA rab-i Uico Say-arota layolaI liIa AlhawaI
fazin-iI liEayonayohaA kamaA zinotahaA liyaA
[And, O my Lord, since Thou hast made Leylà to be to me the object of love, then grace Thou me to her eyes like as Thou hast graced her to me]. (Ṣ, TA: but in the former, mina AlhawI in the place of liIa AlhawaI. [The reading in the Ṣ means of the objects of love: for hawFI, being originally an inf. n., may be used alike as sing. and pl.]) tazoyiynu↓ Als-iloEapi fiI AlbayoEi [means The setting off, or commending, of a commodity in selling; and] is allowed, if without concealment of a fault, or defect, from the purchaser, and without lying in the attribution and description of the article. (TA.)
2: see above, in six places {1}.

hom.sense: 4. OazaAnahu and Oazoyanahu: see 1, first sentence.
See also the paragraph here following {5}.

entry.sense: 5. tzy-n and AizodaAna↓, (Ṣ, Ḳ,) the latter of the measure AifotaEala, [originally Aizotayana, and then AizotaAna,] (Ṣ,) quasi-pass. verbs, [the former of zay-anahu and the latter of zaAnahu,] (Ḳ,) signify the same; (Ṣ;) [He, or it, was, or became, adorned, ornamented, decorated, decked, bedecked, garnished, embel-lished, beautified, or graced;] as also Aiz-ay-ana, (Ṣ,* Ḳ,) [a variation of the first, being] originally tazay-ana, the t being made quiescent, and incorporated into the z, and the A being prefixed in order that the inception may be perfect; (Ṣ, TA;) and AzyAn-↓; and Azyn-↓. (Ḳ.) One says, Oazoyanati↓ AlOaroDu biEuXobihaA [perhaps a mistranscription for Aizoyan-ati↓ The earth, or land, became adorned,, &c., with, or by, its herbage]; as also Aiz-ay-anat, originally tazay-anat [as expl. above]; (Ṣ;) and some, in the Ḳur x. 25, read tazay-anat; and some, AzyAn-t↓. (Bḍ.) And they said, UicaA TalaEati Aljabohapu tazay-anati Aln-axolapu [When Aljbhp (the Tenth Mansion of the Moon) rises aurorally, the palm-tree becomes garnished with ripening dates: that Mansion thus rose in central Arabia, about the commencement of the era of the Flight, on the 12th of August, O. Ṣ; and in that region, at, or soon after, that period, the dates begin to ripen]. (TA.) [tzy-n is said of language, as meaning It was embellished, dressed up, or trimmed: and of an action, &c., as meaning it was embellished, or dressed up, i. e. commended, to a person, by another man, and, more commonly, by the Devil.]

And tzy-n also signifies He adorned, ornamented, decorated, decked,, &c., himself. (MA, KL.) [Hence,] tzy-n biAlbaATili [He invested himself with that which did not belong to him]. (Ṣ and TA in art. XbE.)
8. AizodaAna, originally Aizotayana: see the next preceding paragraph {5}, first sentence.
9: see 5, in two places.
11: see 5, in two places.
zaAnN: see art. zwn.

zayonN [as an inf. n., and also as a simple subst.,] is the contr. of XayonN: (Ṣ, Mṣb, Ḳ:) [as a simple subst.,] i. q. ziynapN, q. v.: (Ḥar p. 139:) [and commonly signifying A grace; a beauty; a comely quality; a physical, and also an intel-lectual, adornment; an honour, or a credit; and anything that is the pride, or glory, of a person or thing: in these senses contr. of XayonN:] pl. OazoyaAnN. (Ḳ.)

Az says, I heard a boy of [the tribe called] Benoo- 'Okeyl say to another, wajohiI zayonN wawajohuka XayonN, meaning My face is comely and thy face is ugly; for wajohiI cuw zayonK wawajohuka cuw XayonK [my face is possessed of comeliness and thy face is possessed of ugliness]; using the inf. ns. as epithets; like as one says rajulN SawomN and EadolN. (TA.)
Also The comb of the cock. (Ṣ.)
zaAnapN [mentioned in this art. in the Ḳ]: see art. zwn.

ziynapN, the subst. from zaAnahu, (Mṣb,) signifies maA yutazay-anu bihi [i. e. A thing with which, or by which, one is adorned, ornamented, decorated, decked, bedecked, garnished, embellished, beautified, or graced; or with which, or by which, one adorns,, &c., himself]; (T, Ṣ, Ḳ;) any such thing; (T, TA;) [any ornament, ornature, decoration, garnish, embellishment, or grace;] and so ziyAnN↓; (Ḳ;) and zayonN↓, also, [which see above,] signifies the same as ziynapN: (Ḥar p. 139:) accord. to El-Harállee, ziynapN denotes the [means of] beautifying, or embellishing, a thing by another thing; consisting of apparel, or an ornament of gold or silver or of jewels or gems, or aspect: or, as some say, it is the beauty [seen] of the eye that does not reach to the interior of that which is adorned [thereby]:
accord. to Er-Rághib, its proper meaning is a thing that does not disgrace, or render unseemly, a man, in any of his states or conditions, either in the present world or in that which is to come: but that which adorns him in one state or condition, exclusively of another, is in one point of view XayonN: summarily speaking, it is of three kinds; namely, mental, such as knowledge or science, and good tenets; and bodily, such as strength, and tallness of stature, and beauty of aspect; and extrinsic, such as wealth, and rank or station or dignity; and all these are mentioned in the Ḳur: (TA:) the pl. is ziyanN. (Bḍ in x. 25.) ziynapu AlHayaApi Ald-unoyaA [or simply ziynapu Ald-unoyaA generally means The ornature, finery, show, pomp, or gaiety, of the present life or world; and] particularly includes wealth and children. (Ḳur xviii. 44.) ziynapu AlOaroDi [The ornature of the earth] means the plants, or herbage, of the earth. (TA.) yawomu Alz-iynapi [The day of ornature] is the festival (AlEiydu); (Ṣ, Ḳ;) when men used [and still use] to adorn themselves with goodly articles of apparel. (TA.) And also The day of the breaking [of the dam a little within the entrance] of the canal of Misr [here meaning the present capital of Egypt, El-Káhireh, which we call “Cairo”], (Ḳ, TA,) i. e. the canal which runs through the midst of Misr, and [the dam of] which is broken when the Nile has attained the height of sixteen cubits or more: this day is said to be meant in the Ḳur xx. 61: it is one of the days observed in Egypt with the greatest gladness and rejoicing from ancient times; and its observance in the days of the Fátimees was such as is inconceivable, as it is described in the “Khitat” of El-Makreezee. (TA. [The modern observances of this day, and of other days in relation to the rise of the Nile, are described in my work on the Modern Egyptians.])
qamarN zayaAnN A beautiful moon. (Ḳ.)
ziyaAnN: see ziynapN.
[ziyaAnapN The art, or occupation, of the muzay-in: so in the present day.]
zaAYinN: see the last paragraph in this art.
muzay-anN: see mutazay-inN.
[Also,] applied to a man, Having his hair trimmed, or clipped, [or shaven, by the muzay-in.] (Ṣ, TA.)

hom.sense: muzay-inN i. q. Haj-aAmN [i. e. A cupper; who is generally a barber; and to the latter this epithet (muzay-inN) is now commonly applied; as it is also in the MA]. (Ṣ, TA.)
See also mutazay-inN.

entry.sense: muzay-iynN: see mutazay-inN.
muz-aAnN: see in two places in what follows.
muzodaAnN: see in two places in what follows.

mutazay-inN and muzodaAnN↓ and muz-aAnN↓ signify the same [i. e. Adorned, ornamented, decorated, decked, bedecked, garnished, embellished, or graced; as also muzay-anN↓: and the first signifies also selfadorned, &c.]: (TA:) the second and third are part. ns. of AizodaAna; the third being formed from the second by incorporation [of the d into the z]: and the dim. of muzodaAnN is muzay-inN↓, like muxay-irN the dim. of muxotaArN; and if you substitute [for the d], muzay-iynN↓: and in like manner in forming the pl. you say mazaAyinu and mazaAyiynu. (Ṣ.) You say, OanaA muz-aAnN↓ biUiEolaAmika and muzodaAnN↓, meaning mutazay-inN biUiEolaAmi Oamorika [i. e. I am graced by the making known of thy command, or affair]. (TA.) And AimoraOapN zaAYinN↓ means mutazay-inapN [i. e. A woman adorned,, &c.; or self-adorned, &c.]: (Ḳ, TA:) in [some of] the copies of the Ḳ, erroneously, mutazay-inN. (TA.)
